I can only recommend to buy it with all DLCs!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												The thing about Tropico 5 is that none of the in your face issues about the game never got patched or addressed in the games tutorials or updates, and that is what makes it hard to recommend it on a level in addressing all of the "advertised" aspects of the game. So I guess I'll just make two sections talking about what is really bad or good about the game.The Good: The single player in Tropico is pretty standard where you follow a campain (which is rare but well appreciated in Tropico) as you develope your own little Cuban esc country while siding with different people for different things.  The voice acting is awesome and funny and you'll really come to appreciate the character and personality that the game brings to the table.  The trading system is very confusing when you get past the beginning stages because just because the boat says its bringing in a certain amount of money doesn't mean you will see the impact in your treasury (just a note).  Also if you are a sucker for graphics this game is fine, landscape is a little empty at first, but once you start filling it up you'll be astounded at the bright colors and tropical atmosphere.  If you really want to get the most out of the game I recommend the Sandbox mode and just set everything to a place where you can go on forever (cause it will take you a long time to fill up your island) and the campain makes you start from scartch as you move from island to island so it's nice to have something concrete to hold onto.  Dlc is also alright if you get it on sale.The Bad:Annnnnnnnnnddddddddddd here comes the kicker.  Character selection and custimization is basically worthless most of the time and it's just pointless trying to upgrade them when you could build or do something that will help you much more in the long run, or just have a bunch of lower level characters on your island to have scartered effect which is also a good alternitive.  Going along with characters the manager assingment process in general is just abysmall as I wish that there was a seperate easier menu to see where your managers are rather then going in and clicking on every single building to see.  Then comes the biggest letdown in this game, which is the learning curve.  I have just over 100 hours and I still haven't even come close to mastering this game, the way that the game wants you to build the city contradicts the idea of a city builder completely, they want everything in close proximity  and one supermarket per block and one church per block but thats such wasted potential on something so meaningless and confusing and limiting to the creativity of building your own city.  Then there is multiplayer which is what I would describe as a one night stand, over and over again, because guess what?  You can't save the freaking multiplayer worlds if you are playing with a friend so you will have to start new every single time you restart that world, which is so god dang stupid and should've been patched the day after this game came out.This leads to the conclusion where I'll recommend it dispite it's flaws because at face level and on sale this is a really fun game to play and really get the atmosphere of, and despite all of it's flaws the developers managed to create a game that has some of the most fun and attractive efforts of any city builder game I have ever played.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Buy Tropico 4, not 5 if you want to have fun owning your own island.There are many small annoyances with this new entry to the series. For instance sometimes it feels like I'd rather pull my fingernails off than try getting roads placed where I want in this game. Same goes for buildings, especially on shore regions. What makes this task even more frustrating is the new "fog of not knowing your own island" which can be painstakingly cleared by sending your palace troops to "explore" said areas. Only that the troops are idiots that don't reveal important areas (mines, oil) but rather walk right past them. Have fun sending them again and again (1000 credits every time) to reveal even the smallest of areas. These guys are like Vickers in Prometheus, capable running only straight ahead - except when they can use roads to go around and reveal even less of fogged area than using straight path to marker.The "combat" in this game... whoo boy. Not good. not good at all since you can't control the troops at all and the outcome is based on placement of your building in relation to path taken by attacking forces. What fun.A new console-player friendly task system within campaign missions is like you're playing a tutorial all the time. Do this and do just to get some reward. What happened to being supreme leader? In this game you're just an errand boy.Campaign missions end on victory condition, just to kick you to another island for one mission and then back to the first one. Around we go. Not the smoothest experience and feels like a continuation of tutorial feeling described above.Execution is poor and overall Tropico 4 is so much better than this its not even funny.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												First, a brief history lesson. I was an avid player of Tropico 3, and snatched Tropico 4 up on the first day. I was underwhelmed, as the game seemed more to be Tropico 3.75 than a new game in its own right; for example, all of the UI and art elements were exactly the same. However, over the next several years, patches and DLC helped make Tropico 4 a truly outstanding game, far surpassing its predecessor.Now we're met with Tropico 5, and history seems to be repeating itself. Tropico 5 has a rock-solid foundation. The mechanics and the underlying systems have been streamlined and now make a lot more sense. Building variety has been diminished, but gone are a lot of buildings that you only ever used once (and that was just to find out what it did). What's left has a time and a place, and the only time you won't use a building is if it doesn't suit your playstyle (as opposed to, say, satellite dishes from Tropico 4, which had very little extra-campaign utility). I've yet to experience a crash. The new systems function well. I especially like the introduction of eras. The dynasty system works, I think. I'm not sure. I seem to get all of the bonuses all of the time, regardless of who is Presidente.That said, the game needs work. Some categories (entertainment) are far too sparse, unless you want a dozen cabarets on your island. I've experienced one game-breaking bug: I don't win Sandbox missions despite meeting the victory conditions. Hopefully that gets patched soon. Upgrading buildings is tedious, although I'm happy that they streamlined modernizing them. A big letdown is that the trademark Tropico humour largely falls flat this time around. Instead of the caricatures of various tropes (the drunken priest, the inept second-in-command) and the banter on the radio which could be genuinely funny (I still laugh at General Rodriguez's description of the Museum of Modern Art), you get "Brokeback Mountain" references, predictable flat-out stupidity from Penultimo, and...Lulu. One cannot be told what Lulu is, one must experience her awfulness for oneself.All told, it's a solid game that will likely only get better as time goes on. It's worth the price--you can easily get 30-40 hours of gameplay in its current state. It's still one of the best city-builder franchises out there.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												So, Tropico 5. We meet at last. Do you know why you were brought here, Tropico #5? Because El Presidente believes with the right sort of, let's say, motivation, you could become so much more useful as a citizen of our great virtual island. But as it is right now? I don't know, Tropico 5. I don't know. Considering the work of the four previous Tropicos who have come through town, who have very rarely made any significant changes to the status quo, which I have to admit, around here we can appreciate that sort of slow gradual change considering how everything has been working just fine, you decided you wanted to make a few more, shall we say, radical changes. This has El Presidente very concerned. Let's go over the dossier, shall we?Let's start with what you've been doing around town that's got so many fellow citizens vocally supporting you. One of the biggest changes you've made is to the infrastructure. It's nice to see that you've scaled down the size of the parking garages to something manageable, and look, in the Modern area you've introduced the Metro to our tiny island! Letting citizens get from one point of the island to the other nearly instantaneously is quite the feet. Something that El Presidente truly appreciates when he wants to get out to the llama farms for some quiet and relaxation without having to drive through all of that horrible traffic. Which is another issue we see significantly less of. It is good to see more people walking instead of filling the streets with cars! I applaud you, Tropico 5, for finally resolving that issue. That reminds me, the whole Era thing. It is, if of a somewhat debatable quality, nice to have Eras from which to transition. Going from the Colonial Era to the World War Era is probably the largest change of the four. The other two are the Cold War and the Modern Era. Having the ability to upgrade certain residential units to other certain residential units is nice as the era transitions, and new constructions become available.Having Edicts become available as the Era progresses is another thing to look forward to, until finally you have access to all of them. And the Constitution! Who would have expected something like that to be introduced into our tiny island? The discovery of science, which is used to enhance the Constitution and advance the Eras, was nice as we can finally figure out that whole sliced bread thing.The price of docks is considerable cheaper than they were previously, which allows El Presidente to build many, many docks to help speed up the export of his new delicious cheese. And speaking of money, it's nice to finally be able to have a use for El Presidente's, shall we say 'private' income. Being able to use the Swiss Bank account balance level up El Presidente and his family members abilities is quite good at encouraging you to play multiple maps with the same family so you realize their full power! Oh yes, and El Presidente would like me to pass along his thanks in allowing multiple members of the family to share power on our island.For the workforce, being able to hire managers with minor Presidente-like powers to manage buildings is a nice touch indeed. The people of our island enjoy being empowered in such a way that makes them more useful to El Presidente.But now onto some concerning trends that I am seeing here. The buildings snap to a rather large grid system that while nice when fitting buildings together sometimes, is terrible unimaginative and can leave a lot of extra space between buildings where they meet at odd angles. It doesn't help any that you have taken away El Presidente's favorite toys. No longer can we build statues to honor El Presidente's might. No, now parks and decorations only come in two units, small and large. The small is one grid or two, while the large fluctuates slightly more, starting at a 4x4, and going to such sizes as 4x6, to the mighty 5x5 and 5x6. But what happened to the gardeners, Tropico 5? Did you murder them in the study with a lead pipe? Because we can no longer plant individual trees, or benches, or any of the small single items. This is a great disappointment to El Presidente, for he had quite the green-thumb.Housing has now turned into something of a mess, since, as we said, Tropicans walk far more than they did last time. Now if a Tropican can not find a house near where they live, they will opt to just build a shack near their work-site, even if there is ample housing on the island. I have been told by many who do this, Tropico #5, that they were encouraged to ignore El Presidente's benevolence and build these eyesores around the city by you.And another thing. Why have you taken away the ability of El Presidente to personally manage the wages of our citizens? Not only that, but he can no longer set prices for buildings or services. Everything has instead been rolled up into one "budget" function. Tropico 5, I'm concerned about this power grab. These are function that should be left up to El Presidente himself to manage, not some overly simplified "budget bar" that controls everything. This has actually made it HARDER to manage the economy, since if we want to pay people less, we now have to also decrease the efficiency of a building by lowering the budget. This is a big problem, and I suspect it may be sabotage!I was also shocked to discover that we need to discover our own island now! When we start administering our great government in the Colonial Era, our island is shrouded in mist, and must be explored by our soldiers during "expeditions" that cost a thousand dollars an event! And you can't even control them, you just click on a way point and hope they go the right route in getting there to discover it. Though the discovery of the Compass does negate this, it is none-the-less irksome.And speaking of discovery, why are our people no longer able to improve their skills concerning their profession? Why have you taken this source of pride from our people, Tropico #5? The people are also kept more out of sight as well, as no longer is El Presidente able to see them when they utilize a building. Gone are the queues that show up when you click on a service building. Instead, they are reduced to mere numbers.Having to mine minerals out of very specific "mines" instead of just having to dig it out of the ground did not actually turn out to be helpful. These "mines" take up permanent space on the map, even after they are used up and collapse. Which is another issue! When a resource node, with the exception of the fishing wharf, is used up, it is automatically destroyed, regardless of whether or not the output storage is full! This destruction of El Presidente's property at the hands of no other than you, Tropico 5, is a great crime! It is most irritating and wasteful. If a facility no longer has resources to mine, El Presidente will choose when and how it is removed, not you!And with the Edicts, while we do have some nice new interesting ones, I see the Pope is no longer able to visit our island, Tropic 5. That is a little disappointing.Elections are now quite a bit more boring. Why do you not allow El Presidente to do speeches anymore, Tropico #5? In fact, why is it that El Presidente, and the family, are not able to directly control their actions on the map? Gone are the day when El Presidente could walk up to a construction site and encourage the workers to construct faster, or walk into a service building an inspire greater service. This is very disappointing that you have talked otherwise upright citizens into ignoring El Presidente in such a way.In the end, I find my appreciation for you mixed, Tropico 5. I can stay with Tropico 4 and not really miss much, I think, but I do still enjoy your presence, even if I think you're a half step back in progress.

												great graphics, great soundtrack, been playing the series since the orginal game. my first experiance with tropico was back in the day when i got a pc gamer demo disk and i have been a fan of the series ever since. tropico 5 is faster paced then the rest of the series which i like. there are a ton of mods for the game that gives it great value.  the mp is pretty fun which suprised me i enjoyed co op a lot. make sure your co op partner has proper soldiers to fight off rebels and armies. i had a friend who got molested by the king it was hilarious. plently of humor in the game and i love selling the russians chocolate and rum :). my biggest gripes are the wage system, every building has a budget but that budget ranges are varied some people getting paid hundreds while others make less then 40. i really would love the old wage system back i felt so bad for dock workers :*(. i wish the game was harder and military invasions and rebellions happened more often,  there are plently of mods for this game and overall this was a fun experiance i would love to see another tropico game :).

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Economy building game type thingy. The game looks nice, but as a fan of the genre I do have some gripes with it. First of, it is rather shallow compared to feature packed games like Unknown Horizons or Sim City. Since I'm now used to playing high quality strategy games like that (some for free), I expect commercial titles to go the extra mile.Placing roads is akward at best. Yes, you learn to work around it, but a user interface should work for the player, not against him. During multiplayer you can build roads that stretch far out, but they cannot be demolished leaving you no room to make a single mistake while placing them. That is a tall order considering how akward the road editing is.The game rushes you from era to era and I often struggle to remain in one era because I feel I haven't gotten to use my newly researched technologies enough. This combined with very small map sizes (even huge is rather small compared to other games) makes it a poor choice for the month long builds I'm used to.There is supposedly a way to save/load multiplayer games, but it's not clear to me at this point exactly how. As with seemingly all modern games, it lacks a proper server browser, instead your left with some social network thing for matchmaking and remote hosting. I didn't like it in L4D2 and I don't like it in this game either. Really old games like OpenTTD (which is free) solved load, save and multiplayer features a long time ago. Just do what they did.The game has also crashed a few times, not a segfault, but a hard lock forcing me to get a console up to kill it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												I did like Tropico 3 and Tropico 4. In fact I loved them!. However, Tropico 5 was, let's say, different. The graphics were good and the humour was there too (if not a bit repetative, a joke is funny once, twice, three times, four times -cringe, again, again and so on). Too little dialogue was included.I'm sorry to say the gameplay just didn't work. What do I mean by that? Well, it was boring by comparison!One of the features that unfortunatly dictate how the game is played, is that each scenario is played on a different island. That in itself is not a problem, but two or three scenarios later you go back to the island that you previously developed and you have to try and remember how and where all the resources are and how you developed the 'supply chain'. It was like going back into somebody elses half-played game and trying to work out what's wrong with it - even though it worked when you left it!!!The menus are at times difficult to work with - important features, that can make or break a game, are sometimes buried deep in a menu that you hardly use or struggle to find (even though you might remember it was somewhere).My next comment is strange, yes I agree. But it is like the rebels and armies are random. Now I know that they are not. But I felt like they were detached from what I was doing even though I do understand the mechanics.I have saved my biggest gripe/problem until last. Groan. The price of the DLC's!!! I paid a lot of money for this game £35. Nobody should have to pay a total of an additional £52 for all the DLc's) making the cost of this game a humongous £87 (about $135 american dollars as I write this). This was a huge problem for me IN THIS GAME. Because I felt that I did not get the gameplay that I should have had from the original package and the content just wasn't there!!!I am not against all DLC's. But these were overpriced and the original game was short of too many features. So I did not buy them. The original base game is on SALE now at £12.24. I believe £14.99 would be fair price, maybe.......... BUT this price should certainly include all the smaller DLC's. Maybe £19.99 with all the DLC's included. So it is still not good value even at 50% off.If it was reduced to these prices tomorrow would I buy them? I'm sorry no, for all resons that I wrote about above. The game does not compare to the fun that Tropico 3 and 4 were and I tired very quickly from it.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												I am barely ticking down into the no vote on this one. Maybe "Not Yet" is more accurate. I would not recommend paying full price for this game if you have Tropico 4. The additional content is limited and I suspect you will be able to get a good deal in a few months with a bundle of DLC.I loved Tropico 4 and I am quite disappointed in this installment. It is one of the few city builder games being released though, so beggars can't be choosers. I will likely keep logging hours on it so I won't say it's worthless.-Campaign takes you through only two islands - really dislike this because it just seems like one, long and boring mission. Different demands put on you when you strategically set up for a previous mission. This was obviously a purposeful shift to have a "Dynasty" and age with the island but I don't enjoy the campaign much.-There are no other missions but there is a missions box so it must be coming or unlocks when you beat the campaign? I would bet it will be $$$ DLC though.-Tropico 4 had a crappy scenario creator which limited the amount of user-generated content there was (and hindered the replay value) and I was hoping for a better one in 5 but there isn't one at all-There is a random map generator for sandbox which is an improvementOverall the things I wanted to see in this installment aren't there and mechanics I thought worked well have been changed.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Tropico 5 is a very fun game. It is a distinct experience from Tropico 4. It varies with the competiveness of the campaign missions, the overall features and the core mechanics of the game. It is a very solid continuation to the series, but there is plenty of room for improvement.The core mechanics as compared to Tropico 4 are improved completely. The little things that add to the game are great. There is more of a sense of tightness when it comes to the mechanics.The features and campaign missions vary on experience from player to player, however I feel that it is a good improvement from T4, however is somewhat short and less features than T4.Overall, it is a real good game that I am continuously enjoying and is being supported with DLC and updates regularly. 8/10.----UPDATE as of 2nd August, 2015:I finally got back into finishing this game, and I can say from an updated experience, I loved the final three missions I had to finish in the campaign. The cities are fragile on producing income, but when you have the right amount of buildings, it is sustainable and the missions become progressively easier. The hardest mission for me was building the space/nuclear program and that was half into the second campaign.Updated rating for me increases, but is still rounded to 8/10. Campaign took me a solid 30+ hours to complete. Overall playing time is 53 hours as of now so its hard to comment on the length it took me to finish the campaign, but the majority of those 53 hours went to the campaign.----Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviewsIf you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page. If you liked it, give it a rating.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												TL;DR, co-op is neither co nor op. I bought the 2 pack looking forward to a co-op city building campaign that my buddy and I oculd play together, maybe this was expecting too much. Load up the game (after stealing an old graphics card of his, because my dumbass cant read the stickies, or the game requirements), start the campaign, no multiplayer/co-op option. Fair enough, maybe we expected too much hoping to play through the campaign together, maybe we can just jointly build a city, and go freeform/sandbox on it. the first time we get into game together (why cant we make private lobbies?) we start across map from each other, with "victory objectives", well wait a second, there was an option for co-op or versus, I must've selected the wrong one, because we are on opposing sides from each other, with no clear way to interact.Restart the game, make sure we are on co-op instead of versus, pick a new island just because. Once we get into the game (not a knock at the loading times, it runs quite smoothly) it's apparent that no part of the "co-operative" gameplay will involve interaction between the two of us, he is on his side of the island, I am on my side, and we still have "team 1 victory points" Ummm, there is only one team. His fright ships come in on their own schedule, mine come in on their own schedule. He accepts certain missions (such as sell us 3000 lbs of coco), I accept certain missions, on the ocassions that those missions DO overlap, our counters each fill up independently!! Add to that the unchanging, bullet-fast gameplay (in which we don't have time to properly read the rewards/punishments, a slower option would be nice, if it could pause when dialog is happening would be friggin wonderful), and the complete lack of notification when one of us gets knocked out of the game.. oh and why do all of their buildings and civilians cursedly die upon their leaders flight? ITS A CO-OP GAME, Why dont you let the remaining/surviving partner take over the buildings?this game has a LONG way to go, I am incredibly disappointed.Avoid until, forever?

												All I have to say, despite my rather dull and uninteresting life, at least I can forget about my troubles and focus on my private tropical island when I am down!  Amazing game, it really is!  The ONLY minor complaint I have, and in comarison with the rest of the game it is minor, is I wish we had more control over the various attributes of the dictator like we did in Tropico 4.....  Other than that, Penultimo is hilarious, the music is awesome, building and learning what you are doing is a breeze!  The tutrial is very useful, earning medals is a blast, the economics are balanced and very interesting, and the downloadable content after you buy the game is endless!!!  Far as multiplayer, I have to wonder why every time I try and find an opponent, there are not enough people to play.... but that being said, there is so much else you can do after you finish the campaigns I would STILL say incredible replayablility!  and on top of it all.... I managed to grab my copy for 10 dollars when it was on sale at STEAM..... everyone needs to check this game out!!!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Been playing Tropico 5 for a week now and I must say, though on the surface this game looks like a step in the right direction the inside of this game is 100 steps back. Pros:-Longer game time from the new dynasty eras. (Colonial, World Wars, Cold War, Modern Times)-New ways to power your government through your new constitution-Add members of your family to your government for extra benefits-Bigger islands that need exploring before you can just build anywhere-Multiplayer (All we ever wanted, right?)Cons:-Lacking in everything everywhere (explained below)-Every model of each building is the exact same unlike Tropico 4 where you could change the way they looked.-No more loyalist (my personal favorit faction in T4. no more hardcore dictatorships favoring your loyal subjects)-No more prisons/labor camps to lock away the people against you-No more decorations for your city (Statues of your self, national flag, you know that fun silly stuff)-Only about 5 outfits to choose from all of them worst than the other (Where is my traditional flag suit?)-The Almac is just a tad harder to navigate in (just considering the amout of clicks it takes to find what im looking for)-You cant choose a back story or how the Presidente rose to power anymore (just one and ONLY one stat)-YOU CANT SAVE YOUR MUTIPLAYER GAMES (Who let this one happen?)  -_-I could really just go on and on about how much I really dont like this game. I am beyond dissapointed, this is almost scam worthy. If you already own Tropico 4 and your thinking of getting 5 please, do yourself a favor and walk away, im begging you. Dont fall for this game and it lies. Terrible just terrible.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I was hesitant to buy this game at first because of the reviews but I went ahead and got it anyway because it was on sale and I love the Tropico franchise. This is now my favorite tropico so far.This game got me just as hooked as the others, and hands down it is the most in-depth and complex tropico so far.They have introduced dynasties so you can have additonal characters and vote other dynasty members in during elections and take advantage of their bonuses. Moving the character around to give boosts to buildings has been eliminated. I see this as a good thing because it just seemed like unecessary micromanagement in the previous game. Instead your character or dynasty members give global boosts to production or whatever else they do (military strength, effectiveness of services, etc.)They have also overhauled trading and added trade routes which can be very profitable if you find good opportunites (Not every trade is profitable and sometimes settling for less lucrative ones is desirable.) They are very easy to manage and not annoying at all. Docks are now more useful to provide more ships for trade routes.The difficulty of the game has gone up, which is a good thing for me because in previous installments I'd get bored when I had loads of cash and almost 100% happiness. In this game I've actually had to use my military AND do the voter fraud thing. I had never had to do that in previous games. You no longer need a secret service building to do certain things, which I thought was pretty annoying.They've introduced a constitution which give you decisions to make that will benefit your country. There is no more immigration building but the benefits provided by one are instead on a constitutional amendment. Edicts are basically the same but some have to be unlocked through research. They've also added research, and it's not just buying blueprints like before. Building libraries and staffing them give research points.Armies and military are very important now and are to be utilized. In previous games I would not bother with militaries until the militant faction complained, in this game it is very handy to have a sizable military, especially when declaring independence in the colonial era.There are now multiple eras in the game. I did not have the modern times expansion from Tropico 4 so I will not compare them directly, but the eras add a whole new interesting layer. In the colonial era you should try to increase revolutionary support to buy independence from the crown and move on to the great war era. This is where the military can also come in handy, to declare independence the crown requests $20,000. If you have a sizable military you can refuse and fight off the crowns troops to save that money. It's not extremely difficult to do and is somewhat challenging but it was a lot of fun for me to do.Farms and mines are also much different. Farms are much more asthetically pleasing and larger. The way building upgrades work has also been changed and is more relevant early game. It's not just a statistical advantage to get late game anymore. A previous reviewer has complained about the way the mine looks, but I think it looks much much better than before. Instead of a random patch of land being dug into, mines are now in preselected locations along mountains. Wages & rents are more simple to manage, no longer do you set individual rents or wages but you set budgets which determine worker prosperity. I do not think I can explain it well, but if you set budgets high, the workers income level becomes either poor, well-off, rich, etc. This determines what kind of house they live in.There is now a "fog of war" type mechanic on the island. In the colonial and great war era you need to explore your island to reveal what resources you have available. You use your military for this.The game runs just as well, if not better, than the previous version of Tropico. I honestly think it runs better than Tropico 4 did on my laptop which is surprising. I also feel comfortable hooking the laptop up to the TV and playing this tropico from my couch with my wireless laptop & keyboard. The GUI had been changed and is much better. I also like that they changed the portraits on the message screens. It's not as exaggerated and cartoony as it was before. I also feel like I can't zoom in on my island as far as I used to. Cons: Only bad things I think is that there is no real additional building sprites. I thought this would be something easy to do. The almanac also has a little less info available but the data that it does show is much more useful and better organized than before.I highly recommend it for anybody who likes the Tropico series. I have been playing since Tropico 2 and this one is my favorite so far. Definitely buy, even at full price.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												Tropico 5 changes a lot of systems, yet stays familiar. It simplifies some aspects, yet makes goals harder to accomplish. new installations: Humour. This game turned out to be funnier than I expected! Every single line that your Presidente says is quite ridiculous (like for example "finally Tropico is free from modern medicine!" or "Welcome Tropico police force to its new home! You can strip search me any time dear officers, oh and by the way your forgot your handcuffs at my palace"), every single research message is humorous and even some of the mission statements are. You have less base buildings and their functions have been simplified, however the research track provides many many different extra buildings, that you need to spend time on. dynasty system - you get to choose less perks, however each family member of your can carry perks of their own. You can use your family members on buildings as managers, or you can send them on missions. Is the game worth it? Yes. Most definitely yes. The charm of Tropico has not been lost. It's different in many ways to the previous ones, however still worth playing!

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												The only other Tropico game I have tried was the very first one, which was interesting. This game; However, I found thoroughly enjoyable, though I can't quite explain why. It was fun playing a Quasi-dictator who tried running a democratic state, while juggling the many scenario surprises such as, Russian Invasions, Tsunami destruction, Tornado's, Rebel attacks, Riots and having multiple foreign powers crying for my attention. I spent several hours just getting lost going through each faction member, playing with my population by bribing, arresting, or banishing them to see what would happen. The graphics are not bad, and the mods and add-on content such as, Waterborne add content to make the game even more enjoyable. All in all, I would recommend this game for those who enjoy this type of game. It is worth multiple playthroughs using various tactics.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												When this game came out I read a bunch of reviews that said it was Tropico 4 all over again and passed on it as a result.Boy, was I wrong.TL;DR at the bottomTropico 5 takes everyone's favorite role of "El Presidente" and adds a bunch of fancy new features that really round out the Tropico expereince and take it to the next level.First off, we have a technology component where Libraries and other buildings help you "discover" new buildings, technology and constituional options.Secondly, you have a Constitution; which provides a choice between Global perks / mods that affect how you run your Island.Third, is the concept of "Eras", where we begin in the Colonial Era and Gradually progress into Modern Times.All in all, what this does is create distinct stages of evolution for your island so you truly feel that your island "changes with the times".Combined with this new evolutionary aspect is the concept of the Family in the Regime; your leader will have children who all have different personalities. At every election you can ask a Regime member to run in the election in lieu of your original Leader. They can be sent on missions and kidnapped, assassinated or disowned.  They have personalities which you can "upgrade" with money from your Swiss Bank Account to make them more effective as managers as as Regime members.Also new is the aspect of "managers" where the people running each building can bring a minor perk that you can assign to whichever of your buildings you choose.All this is wrapped in the same familiar "Tropico" packaging that fans of the series know and love. So, Long Story Short, though I am glad I grabbed this on sale for $10, this game is MILES more than Tropico 4 was and any fan of the series should pick it up.TL;DR Great game. Worth a grab at $15 or less.  Enjoy Ruling, Presidente!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Tropico 5 is the new younger brother of the awe-inspiring Tropico 4. Not suprisingly, Tropico 5 has many less buildings then Tropico 4 *cough* expect DLC *cough* but it still manages to be an upgrade to Tropico 4.  El Presidente's notable new toys include better military and companionship (multiplayer). You shouldn't not buy this game just because it wasn't as much of an upgrade as Tropico 4 was for the franchise. But if you don't have any Tropico games I would suggest buying Tropico 4 now and getting this on sale with the destined-to-come DLC later.Edit: It's a year later and I recently purchased all of the DLC (but two minor ones) for 85% off at 11.00 dollars recently(Humble Bundle). True to my predictions Tropico 5 has introduced 12 DLC's so far to fill the void of initial release. I've put in 30 hours at this point and plan to put in more, so I can safely recommend this game. Buy Tropico 5 and its DLC cheap, and I think you will find it worth it. (I should also mention the older Tropicos are almost just as fun and still much cheaper atm.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Lately I've been holding off on reviewing many things, due to the nature of many games being worked on continuously and things changing very fluidly.Today I write a big thumbs up for the Tropico 5 team for pulling through on two things that many in the community thought they had ripped us off on.The first, prisons. Why these weren't there at launch is beyond me, considering they were in Tropico 3 & 4, the community thought perhaps we would get nickled and dimed for a prison DLC. The dev team to the surprise of many, at patch 1.08, have hadded the prison and the ability to arrest citizens for FREE.In addition to this, the second large complaint was the 2000 population limit. Tropico 5 offers various huge Islands for the players to build on, much of which would stay empty due to the low population limit. Not to mention the horrible side effect of this limit and multiplayer - in which the total cap was divided among all players. New with patch 1.08 is the ability to change the max population anywhere between the original 2000, and the new high limit of 10,000.I have to say I am very happy to see the devs change their stance on the population cap after community feedback, and would highly recommend this game to anyone. It's done a lot for the series, and is very unique in its approach compared to T3 & T4. Not to mention the devs, while a little slow on the action point here, nontheless pulled through for the community. With my restored faith I may just buy the large upcomming DLC at full price :)

content:
Posted: January 22
												Viva el Presidente!At first I was a bit reluctant to buy the whole collection on sale, since I didn't know if I would like it, now I'm kind of sad I did not buy it, will do on next sale.Game feels pretty challenging, offers a refreshing take on the tycoon genre with a unique dictatorship style spin, and it was an instant addiction after I got the hanging of it. Good dictatorship simulator, would rule again.The good:-Characters are pretty likable and well thought-Dynamics are nice, great replay value-Several possible ways to beat the game-Mods and custom missions are always welcome-Penultimo is damn funny and gets under your skin in no timeThe bad:-Tutorial covers about 5% of the game mechanics-No voice acting for like half the stuff in-game-Some pesky bugs on transport and housing (tropicans building shacks next to affordable housing)Definitely worth a buy, will buy whole collection on next steam sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												It kept me entertained for a good few hours as I built a successful and thriving island democracy, but everything changed when the rebels attacked.I became a totalitarian, big brother, martial law dictatorship with limited liberties withtin the space of 2 months.It was fun, I won't deny that and some of the new mechanics were a lovely little touch to the game but, there was no where near as much building variety as there was in Tropico 4 and the same goes for your presidente customization. I did love the new eras mechanic that they added into the game, infact it is what makes the game different from all the other Tropico games.My overall thought on this game though is that I don't know where I actually stand with it. It was amusing wih its cheesy sense of humor but, I found it to be a touch lacking in content. £34.99 is a bit much than I'd be willing to pay for it now that I've played it especially considering the game is only 1.9GB in size. Anyway, If you want a laid back city builder style game then by all means get this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												8 hours in and I still have absolutely no idea what people are complaining about. I've been an avid Tropico player since the very first game. I sank and hours and hours into Tropico 3 (on the Xbox360) and have a ton of time racked up on 4 as well. So when 5 was released and everyone started complaining I was kind of confused. I held off on buying the game until it went on Sale and let me just say that I think it is more than worth the full price. So far it has absolutely everything I love about Tropico and more. No longer is it game over when the US or USSR decide to invade. You can defend yourself! Your presidente gets a single trait, and all of the members of your dynasty get one as well, every time there's an election you can decide which dynasty member you're going to have run for office. You can appoint managers to your buildings which offers a bunch of different ways in which to modify the behavior of the game. No longer are protests are just the populace voicing their displeasure. You can choose to negotiate with them and trigger an event that increases that faction's opinion of you if you complete it. The import/export system has been overhauled to great effect and the trade system is absolutely a pleasure to work with. Same with the reasearch section which adds a new element to the game and removes the feeling that all problems in El Presidente's life can be solved by throwing money at them. I have a mid-low end computer and even on somewhat low settings the game looks gorgeous. It runs smoothly and feels well optimized. There's so much more I could probably go on and on about it. I honestly don't have any complaints. As someone who has played these games from the start I've had so much fun watching it grow and change over the years. This newest iteration doesn't disappoint and promises many hours of play in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												The only real issue I have with this game, is that it often creates copies of your ruling family. After playing half the campaign mode, and 1 game in sandbox mode, I had 5 copies of my single ruling family. Not 2: 5. I like the idea of having your family bridge multiple games, but I'll have to throw away 50% of the time spent playing this game if I want to use my family in its most advanced state. It's unfortunate this feature wasn't implimented better.The music and atmosphere of this game is great. It's relaxing to play, and makes you feel stress-free: like being on a tropical island. At the same time, you have a lot of choices to make, and really feel like your decisions are critical for your island's well-being, although quite possibly your citizenry would be well off if you took a ten year nap.. . there are a few annoyances regarding how the game ships resources: effectively all resources are always sent to the docks: if another building on the island requests them, then those resources won't ship off the island--right away--but as your island gets larger, and more demanding, it can be months before resources get picked up. and they end up getting sold instead of transported forward. The addition of a checkbox you could tick to not sell an item if it's stored at a dock, would solve this, but instead the solution is to import much more of a resource than you need and hope some of it's still there when someone arrives to transport it. And don't get all uppity at me and be all "oh, just build more resource moving dudes:" the rate of resource movement is fine when there's a surplus of resources. The issue is that, when your power plant needs iron, and then a ship comes in and all your iron gets sold, and now the task "transport iron to the power plant" gets lost. . . Then another ship imports iron, and the task "transport iron the power plant" is added again, but to the bottom of the queue. Then, before it reaches the top of the queue, another ship arrives and all the iron is sold again. Do you see how this is a problem? Yes, there are some things you can do to outplay the system and get to your own iron before it gets sold, but just having a option to not sell the iron you critically need for your island, would be a much more realistic, simplier solution, which does not exist. Why not?!! I've given you two issues, and these are really the most serious issues I have with the game. Most everything else is clear, and fun to play with. Oh! It does suck that you can't build new buildings during an attack: the time my island got invaded just as a two large military facilities were about to complete, and so I lost: that sucked. The island was in a state of war for a year and half: you're telling me the new barracks couldn't finish training their troops in a year and a half and come to finish off the one enemy unit that survived and slowly plinked away at my manor until it was destroyed?! Okay, so those three things suck, but a lot about this game is really enjoyableI hope that, being more aware of the issues with this game, will help you enjoy it more, because they are issues you can prepare for, and this is really a relaxing, fun, game to play :)

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I would still recommend this game, although I say this with an asterisk. It ceratinly adds to Tropico 4 although doesn't take the concept any further than its simple formula.What I like: -The new buildings and a co-op mode that you can play with your friends, saying that the co-op could be better designed. The new buildings include one that gives you tanks and other jet bombers, so that's pretty cool.-The new factions that change through the time periods. This keeps the game interseting as you have to choose a faction you would like to keep on good grounds.-The trade system. I like this because I can choose trade routhes that suit me if I want to sell a specific resource  at a certain time that I have an adundance of.What I dislike:-The dynasty system and the overall avatar creation. There are like 4 uniforms and the dynasty feels kind of out of place as they never really change. I thought it would add an effect where each dynasty member would stand for a differnet thing in the eyes if the people and that you could replace one dynasty with an other but instead it is just a set of different leaders.- It could be just me but the AI feel a little worse than on Tropico 4, they feel like they have no agency.Overall I would suggest for people who want a new Tropico, but if you are looking for this kind of game with all the things it brings I may still suggest it but I would also equally recommend Tropico 4 with all expansion. I would give it a 7.5 out of 10 as it doesn't feel very fresh compared to 4.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												One word, disappointing. This was the first and last Tropico I buy on release day, you lost a customer Kalypso(for now, until you change how you treat your fans). I can't believe the lack of effort put in, it's so sad because Tropico 5 does have potential.Pros:-Graphics are better by a little bit, but not much. Although there are some awful textures I noticed like fishing spots having terrible looking 2D fish and the newspaper building having a buggy garden texture.-El Presidente customization is slightly better than the old Tropicos and Slightly worse. I like that you can now customize the colours of your outfit and there is a good selection of faces and hair, but the game is severely lacking in outfit choices(DLC money grab sadly)-WASD Movement!! Thanks for that Kalypso.Cons:-The menus are awful, big step down from Tropico 4.-Less buildings, e.g. No more firestation(It's a police station upgrade now)-Still can't paint ground textures. Such a simple but important feature to fix dirt patches in your city, come on Kalypso.-Building variety is non-existent. What a step down from Tropico 3 & 4 and they didn't even have that great of variety but it was better than nothing, which is what we have here.-Hardly any gardens or objects to place(the stuff that makes your city look alive) limited to 10 small gardens and 6 large gardens( DLC later I'm sure, gross)-Can't control El Presidente anymore, and he doesn't fight in battles either.-El Presidente's ability tree has been downgraded since Tropico 4. Limited to one skill now instead of 3, very sad.-Flags, they look nice but depending how you rotate the buildings causes the flags to look like they're blowing in every direction. Looks bad, trust me.-Time moves a little too fast.-Co-op is awful, nuff' saidConclusion: Buy Tropico 4, it's an awesome game, if you want to buy this turd; I'd say it's worth $5 tops, buy it on sale. Don't expect a great game, but do expect to be♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by DLC, sadly. I wish I had my $50 back =(

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Tropico 5 offers a wide range of choices for building a city. Industrial, agricultural, or commercial cities all provide amusement. The era system feels great, and trading in the game has never been better. The missions are diverse and funny, with some being a pain in the neck. Technology is nicely executed. I certainly enjoyed watching my people withstand hardships (since I am a dictator). Foreign relations are greatly expanded, and are more complex, accompanying serious dilemmas that can decide the fate of your city. Military power is straightforward and easy to handle, although I wished for more options. Every building seems to be handsomely illustrated. Concerning transportation, I expected multiple road systems, such as: bridges, tunnels, ext. Tourism in the game is really exciting, but most of its buildings are expensive, which can halt construction for a period of time. DLC? meh, don't even bother. In conclusion, Tropico 5 runs smoothly and is fun to play. It brings this simultaneous feeling of simulation and pleasure. Go buy it if you liked Tropico 4.

												Tropico 5 is a game that I originally didn't think I would get much out of. It seemed too simple or too narrow of a topic. Just focusing on a small tropical nation. However, I quickly found it to be quite enjoyable.Tropic stars you, El Presidente, as you and your family take your tiny colony through the world wars, cold war, and the present. Making choices about how free your people are, economic and political choices, and balancing the needs of your people, your own bank account, and keeping your grip on power. You may start out as a benevolent leader, but you may find yourself having to take drastic measures and fight off the occasional revolutionary or election opponent.4/5 Cuban Cigars smoked. Great game if a little simplistic at times.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Tropico 5 is a good game that has the potential to be great.  In this iteration, the developers seemed to have maintained the core mechanics that makes the game work and took several tentative half-steps in a new and mostly good direction.  This cautious innovation has produced mixed results.  Few of the new changes or features are bad, they’re just unfinished or poorly implemented and it becomes painfully obvious when one plays the game that they were not carried out to their logical ends.  And even though, on the whole, it is still a fun experience the game suffers because of these half-steps.    The Good: -Ambiance and artwork.  Tropico is more scenic and beautiful than ever and the soundtrack is the best yet.  While I don’t find the humor in Tropico 5 to be nearly as amusing as Tropcio 4, it still maintains that sardonic sense of humor that is part of the Tropican experience.  I was also underwhelmed by the voice acting and characters.  While not bad, they lack the personality of the characters in 4.  -The Eras.  This is actually one of my favorite parts of the game.  I like the progression from era to era and the way national and international politics is different depending on which era you are in.  I like the continuity as well.  I like the aesthetic of having colonial buildings existing alongside modern ones.  I thought that the addition of tourist buildings that derive extra benefits from nearby colonial buildings was a nice touch.        The Bad:	-The almanac.  In Tropico 3 and 4, all the information that a diligent dictator needed to run a country was easily accessible and clearly presented.  In 5, the almanac, while still containing most (but not all) of the same information, has made it much less accessible and readable.  	-Rebels, coups and civil unrest.  It is not uncommon, for me at least, during the cold war era to have an approval rating above 75% and yet still have a major problem with rebels which often number in the dozens and seem to spawn out of nowhere.  This relates to the almanac in the sense that it can be difficult to discern what exactly the problem is based on the information provided.  Sometimes when I examine individual rebels it is not uncommon for me to find that they are often gainfully employed, generously compensated, comfortably housed and give my regime high approval ratings.  This makes no sense to me.  In addition, the rebels seem overpowered.  I actually like the idea of not having exact numbers and perfect intel on rebel forces, it adds a level or realism to the game.  However the mechanics that govern their behavior and combat abilities seems broken to me.	-Missing Features and buildings.  This is, hands down, the biggest complaint that I have.  To give one example of this: the police now serve as law enforcement and fire protection.  The latter they do well enough.  The former I’m pretty sure they don’t do at all.  It’s maddening to see people identified as crime lords and rebels by the police, walking around without the slightest fear of being arrested or shot.  And in any case, there’s no jail, dungeon or labor camp to lock them up in.  That’s just one example.  There are several buildings, edicts, and activities (e.g. campaign speeches, official workplace visits from El Presidente, the secret police with their extremely useful and covert skillset.) that are missing from Tropico 5 that really need to be there.  In this respect Tropico 4 is actually, at this point, still far superior to Tropico 5.     The Half-Steps (i.e. good and bad):	-The Dynasty.  The most underwhelming of the new features, the dynasty function feels like it was tacked on at the last minute and is not fully integrated into the game mechanics which is too bad because I think there are some interesting possibilities.	-Research Tree.  While not especially deep or complex, this feature does add a nice progression mechanism to the game.  I like it much better than buildings simply becoming available after a certain year.    	-The Tropican Army.  It’s nice to see that the Tropican armed forces have finally learned how to fight as units as opposed to individual soldiers.  It’s also nice that they’ve learned how to drive tanks and fly jet fighters as opposed to displaying them as useless set pieces like in Tropico 4.  That being said, it is very unfortunate that, for all their improvements, they basically still suck at what they do.  As far as I can tell, when the palace is threatened, all units (that haven’t already been routed by the super-rebels) will converge on it to defend it.  Other than that, there seems to be no centralized command and control mechanic that governs how your soldiers and their support vehicles behave.  	-Multiplayer.  I have not tried the multiplayer mechanic and have no interest in it.  While I’m sure that there are those who enjoy it, I thought from its announcement that it was unnecessary and out of place in a game like Tropico and I wish that the resources dedicated to its development had been tasked to other aspects of the game that are lacking.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												"Chances are, if you’re a “Tropico” fan, you’re going to pick this up anyway despite what reviewers may say.  As such, allow me to address those completely new to the series.  “Tropico 5″ doesn’t exactly redefine the series, but it makes some very ground-breaking additions that make playing the game much more enjoyable.  It unfortunately takes away some really important features (setting rents & wages to an exact value, etc.), but adds almost just as much to keep things interesting.  If you’re on the fence about dropping forty bucks (the price as of 4/30/14), then go and download “Tropico 3″ or “Tropico 4″ for much cheaper.  They won’t give you the full experience (“Tropico 4″ with “Modern Times” comes closest), but will give you an idea if you can handle life as “El Presidente”.  If you can’t, then you’re only out ten or twenty bucks instead of forty.  As a whole though, “Tropico 5″ is a joy to play and I’m looking forward to many, many hours of ruthless dictatorship the likes of which my Tropicans have never seen."Full Review: http://www.dadsgamingaddiction.com/tropico-5/

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I find Tropico 5 to be a decent game. Some of the additions compared to T4 are nice, like the era's. Others feel contrived, like the dynasty system. Assigning managers to buildings becomes tedious quite quickly, and not very rewarding in most cases. Both T4 and T5 ask for a bit of micro-managing, and while T4 makes it feel meaningful, T5 makes it feel like a chore.The game feels less fleshed out and polished compared to its predecessor, and I find T4 a lot more fun to play. I would advice potential players to buy Tropico 4 with all DLC on a sale instead of T5.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Tropico 5 is a really well made City Simulator, with a great storyline in the background to boost. It really makes you think how you want to prioritise everything you do, from resource production to invasion defenses. Not to mention the ridiculous humour the game provides from a variety of colourful characters and factions all out to get each others throats. Definitely worth buying, have not regretted a single moment of it! Have had many hours already both serious time and casual derping, and just never got tired of the possibilities!10/10

												This game will be great (when it's done.) I dont recommend buying this game at this price right now. It's worth maybe $20 and I regret buying it. If they released a huge content addition for free tomorrow I'd change my mind. Seems at this stage to be a demo, albiet a really fun one. The game is extremely easy and has tons of personality, so I had a blast playing it. But, I tried to drag things out not wanting it to end too soon but it did. It's the best so far in the series but man, is it short.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Sadly I can't recommend this game. I am a big fan of the Tropico games and was excited when I finally got my hands on it to play it. But after playing it, beating the missions and doing some sandbox games, there is something definitely wrong with this version of the game. For one thing there seems to be money issues all the time. With no matter what you have set up you are always losing money as you get into the game. Your popularity goes to low  levels that you have no way of recovering from and you get military take overs with no way to get out of that situation. Tropico 4 had it all and fine tuned it and the game was just fun. This one is like Tropico 4 with less options. less fun and more frustration.  The game is supposed to be fun. And for some reason they removed all the elements that were fun in the previous installment. I do like that they tried to come up with new ideas for the series with going through time periods and having family members you can add but instead of removing things that were in prior versions and making the game much harder and frustrating .. how about just improving on the previous edition and remembering that the game is supposed to be fun too? Its not fun always losing money, having everyone hate the president and having less options in the game. Sadly  just not enjoying it like I hoped I would. I played this one a lot as you can see from my time put into it. So its not just a quick play to come to this final decision here. Tropico 4 so much better. Hopefully Tropico 5 will be improved in later patches but I can't recommend this game as it is currently stands. Sorry just was so short and disapointing. No way am I spending another cent on DLC for this mess. The game is supposed to be more fun as you get to the present and beyond. Not ridiculously unfair. Sometimes I think developers are too smart for their own good.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												The idea of the game is pretty cool, but it still lacks the completion and amendments for the game that make it perfect. I played it like five or six hours and literally couldn't stop, you as a dictator governing your own island and manage and watch it pace into more modern stages. Each stage of an era is a new start, you will have new foreign powers influencing your island's future, you will have to trade as much as possible to fulfill your treasury bag. If your first start at a innately rich island, you basically just need to export as much as possible, making your dictated country rich and prosperous. Build more and more buildings, infrastructures, research facilities, education facilities, be the most self-righteous gwuy in the world and implement it to your real urban planning. As I'm bit interesting in urban planning, this game literally give you the chances to build a city on the basis of all your ideas. In other word, be the most ♥♥♥♥ing awesome guy in the world and your countrymen will kneel down as much as possible, if they don't, make them. ;) The idea of owing an island in Carribean Sea is as cool as developing it into something you aspire to. And the ultimate goal I guess is to develop it into a country that is as strong and powerful enough to be able to against superpowers manipulating you for long. Anyway, till here, the game is kinda cool, but there are defects that it has to address.Typically, the battle element. The game focuses on mostly construction and governing, but the battle is awful. You can't build anything during a battle, you can't save your palace as long as you don't have enough manpowers to fight back, and literally watching it collapse (WTF?!). And the invasion of superpowers are just op, your squads of soldiers literally do nothing but wandering around and getting high I guess, they just get beaten up one by one or just basically get vanquished. And one building only produce one squad of infantry, which is painful, you basically don't have anything to against superpowers army when you only built three or four military facilities. And once your palace is compromised, the game is over, you lose and you have to start it over. And rebels, they are just as annoying as your neighborhood granny, once you stepped into more modern eras they r like periods basically wouldn't stop and appearing periodically. And once appeared a rebellion force you will have to eliminate them, and we start to talk about battle. Yeah, battle is just painful and bad. I wondering why they still haven't fix it or upgrade it since the game has released almost one year and a half and more, and there are people complaining about it.  You can't take peoples money and do nothing. That's basically it, think before you buy.有没有官中无所谓，简单一句话，战斗太蛋疼，被打的时候还不能造兵怎么让我好好大独裁!?

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												In a word: Over-complication. T3 and T4 are some of my most favorite games. Each with their own liitle quirks, but totally enjoyable. T5 manages to improve on one of my biggest pet peeves from previous installments: Farms now have clearly defined areas in which to grow crops. And that is ALL T5 does for the series. Every single other action is over-complicated to the Nth degree. I can barely enjoy sandbox mode because, surpirse, it's no sandbox. No matter what you do, or what you WANT to do (that is the point of a sandbox, afterall), you're going to be following the same damn repetitious timeline for each and every game. Nevermind the fact that it's boring and complicated, it just doesn't feel finished. Thoroughly dissappointed in this game. Haven't lost hope for the series, hopefully someone at Haemimont is paying attention to this stuff.

Posted: August 21, 2014
												Enjoyable overall, but far too streamlined. Somewhat of a disappointment, if you want to play Tropico play Tropico 4, especially with the Modern Times expansion. The Dynasty feature was my favorite part, but too many quests, too easy, too much hand-holding. An example- workers no longer need to walk to their place of business to count as working. Hooray, right? Well... If you hate garages and the entire set of infrastructure that went along with that. The walking was very frustrating- but it made the game more satisfying when you figured it out. In Tropico 5 you don't need to figure it out. I was halfway through the campaign before I realized you could scroll down on the almanac. Just too easy.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Wow, while so many other franchises are releasing lifeless clones made with more modern middleware. Tropico 5 adds gameplay to the existing strong strategic game mechanic, while increasing the graphics and streamilining the gameplay through use of often comical npc interactions which keep the game moving, adding TRUE online multiplayer, featuring a masterful invite friendlist ready system as well as a join random games list. The TRUE ONLINE MULTIPLAYER GAMEPLAY is done exceptionally  well too. What a superb addition to an already bright futured franchise. I can honestly say this is the first game I can remember enjoying its sequel more than its original... We couldnt be more happy with this title. If I had to find some cons to the amazing list of pros this title boasts, I would have to say the lack of a multiplayer save function and no Lan option. However because the Online multiplayer has been working so exceptionally well since day two, You probably will not miss LAN very much. The only worry I have is when we manage to last hours and one of us runs out of time, the game is effectively over. I hope they will add the multiplayer save in the future. What a great game I highly recomend! ^^PS great music too, but thats not news with this franchise :)

												Tropico 4 was a slightly more polished Tropico 3 with a few more buildings. Tropico 5 is far from a remake of Tropico 3 or 4 - But not in a good way. The features and mechanics of this game are, in addition to beeing unpolished, just bad features. The mulitplayer is a complete joke. What bugged me the most is still the way you regulate a buildings budget. This system is supposed to reduce micomanagement (just what the city-builder needs) but ends up giving you much more micomanagment and less control over your citizens development.This might be a good game after an expansion and a couple of dlcs. But I would still not reccomend buying this game and rewarding Kalypso for releasing what is, plain and simple, just a bad game

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Tropico 5 expands on the old things that made the Tropico series great. I love the new combat system, it was always a pain to never be able to fight off foreign invasion despite having a huge standing army, I mean, come on, Cuba won the Bay of Pigs, didn't they? Anyways, although the game is great and the expansions are also great, it would be very nice to see Haemimont/Kalypso expand from the regular Tropico theme. I know that Tropico 2 was comparatively a failure and its pirates theme was probably part of that, but I'm not asking for that much of a deviation. The one thing I would absolutely love for Tropico to do is to take the same everything its known for and place it into different nationality themes. Its great to be Castro for a while, but maybe sometimes I want to be Kim Jung Un, or Idi Amin, or even Erich Honecker. I would love to see a game exactly like Tropico that let me do everything tropico does but with a different ethnicity of people, a different flag, and a different climate.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												I love Tropico and have done since my first experience as El Presidente in the original (i love it so much that i rebought 1-4 on steam). For a long time all I ever played were city building games, and I will say that the Tropico series are my favourites. While yes Simcity (the old ones) and even the new Cities Skylines are enjoyable, I usually get bored of the city I'm building after a while with the whole zoning, waiting for people to come to the city and build house/shops/industry build some services then repeat. The Anno series steps it up with you building each building, production chains and the occasional quest making it more engaging for me. Tropico gives me that but it also brings a fantastic humour to my megalomania experience (sorry in advance if I over use humour/funny etc, but it's true) that has me laughing out loud every time I play it and after nearly 300 hours of play I'm still not bored.In this latest instalment the humour that has kept me endlessly amused in previous games is still fantastic (I wish we could all have a Penultimo in our lives). The building models are done with great detail, the colours and textures of my island paradise are amazing. I sometimes like to zoom the camera right in and tilt it so it's like you standing at street level and watch the occasional sunset/rise.I used to feel that I never really had enough time lording over my adoring subjects (benevolently lording, most of the time anyway), especially in sandbox with games 3 and 4, but with the eras setup in this latest instalment I’m in El Presidente heaven. The addition of the colonial time is really nice, when declaring independence I always say 'let the redcoats come, I ain't paying the crown anything' (I'm actually British before anyone says anything). And the era specific random quests have fantastic humour in their delivery. There's one quest during the world wars era where La resistance needs messenger animals, the result of each animal tried - pigs are too tasty and become bacon before reaching their destination, still make me laugh every time. I know there have been a lot of disagreements over the whole DLC thing, I have to admit with other games I've thought they were a bit of a rip off, but with Topico's I've been really quite please. For £2.50 the small single mission ones have kept me entertained for at least a weekend on each play, the 2 £14.99 new campaign ones at least a couple, so I see them as good value (I have played them all more than once). The new random 'side quests' that accompany the DLC's are just as funny as those in the vanilla game and playing through the main campaign again with them popping up can drastically change how things play out. I failed a mission during my 10th play through of the main campaign after the addition of the Mad World and Espionage DLC's, due to a revolt caused by my overuse of banish/kill of crime lords and enemy spies. It was hilarious. So I have bought them all and I probably will continue to buy anymore that come out - if anyone from Kalypso is reading this I loved Pirate Cove, so if you wouldn't mind doing a piratey DLC. As Lulu say's everything is better with pirates!The one thing I will say I don't like and that's the complete reduction in advisors/representatives. I miss Miss Pineapple and her love of spanking (her little guest appearance visiting the fish people in one of the new side quests from the Waterborne DLC was a nice addition). Where's El Diablo telling me to stop letting the riffraff in. And while I love Lulu's radio show, Sunny and Penultimo's banter in 4 was just as fun (maybe they could do a guest spot). What happened to the other nations diplomats? Sometimes I could do with the 30,000 instead of the promised camelI’ve would definitely recommend Tropico 5 to anyone who likes city building games and I hope that Kalypso will continue to bring us more life as El Presidente

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												I don't think this is a terrible game, and if you're bored or not worried about the cash - sure, buy it.But it's not great.  I think the series (or developer) has gone a little bit creatively bankrupt .. clearly struggling to find new ways to reinvent the game.  (Which, strictly speaking, I don't think you need to do - you can just improve on the existing formula).What I mean is - rather than look for substantial changes, make iterative ones - make the underlying financial simulation stronger, make the graphics better, make the islands larger ... and then make it all about the story-telling and controlled challenges in the scenario.Instead, it feels like they've kind of tried to reinvent a bit .. consolidating concepts that came up in Tropico 4 DLCs (like changing eras) and introduce them into this game.  Problem is it all feels shallow.  There's this dynasty concept where you can have children, raise them, have them fulfil roles in your dynasty (but you yourself don't die, apparently).  There's just .. I don't know .. a shallowness to it all that makes you start yawning before you're even halfway through the game.They've also left core elements out of the game, and a lot of the stuff that made Tropico 4 interesting (such as balancing the factions) has been de-emphasised in Tropico 5.It feels to me that Tropico 5 is kind of like the wanna-be cool grandad of Tropico 4 .. it's actually older and less edgy, but it tries to dress up in a younger persons clothes and act cool .. but you can kind of tell it's struggling to keep up the charade and running out of ideas.It was hard to decide whether YES I DO recommend this game or NO I DON'T.  For me it's marginal .. if you're looking for a city builder with it's own personality, why not ?  It's not a terri♥♥♥♥♥♥game .. it's just not great.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												I DIG city builder games and I went into this with as positive an attitude as someone possibly could.  After 10 hours of repetitive gameplay unfortunately the experience is incredibly 'lightweight' and disappointing.  Much of my time has been spent alt+tabbing to find the solution to something on a Steam guide, which sometimes turns out to be 'just a bug' or 'guesswork'.Cons:- City builder elements are very shallow.  You upgrade Police Stations to put out fires as there are no Fire Stations. Tropico lacks the essential city building elements of its rivals, and it doesn't do a good job of explaining or giving information on the elements that it does have.  There is no 'traffic', and no feedback or information as to how your production network even runs.- Strategy elements are near non existent.  You plonk down some houses and some farms then after a while you get enough money to plonk down the next thing.  You do get attacked by rebels but there is zero strategy involved with how it plays out.- A huge issue with lack of information.  How many construction offices do I need?  How many Teamster offices do I need?  How much stock makes up the 'other' stock which is about to be shipped out - why can't I expand that window to see how much I am actually producing?- Communication ambiguities, for example, 'setting the budget' on a house actually means 'raising the rent', not the budget you give towards the upkeep of houses, like you do for other buildings.- Housing bugs, for example citizens refusing to live in houses and instead declare themselves 'homeless' even though you have set their salaries high and the rent of the houses low.  No information is given as to why citizens would be homeless, and after searching online though guides, this is possibly a bug.- Lack of building variety, even with the DLC buildings, which are very unreasonably priced.- Voice acting is used sparingly.- 'Advanced trading mechanics' - lol, good one.- Even when on amicable terms, signing an alliance treaty with the Axis results in them invading you, then you defeating them, and then them immediately agreeing to the alliance after they declared a 'mini-war' on you for initiating an alliance treaty.  That's not what I'd call a believable simulation of the diplomatic and strategic implications of an alliance...Lastly the population is capped at 2000, you have the option to raise it up to 10000, but raising it above 2000 comes with a warning message about game stability and bug issues.  If I can only populate 10% of an island then where's the fun in that?
