content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I do not recommend this game because of its various bugs and flaws. First of all: This is like the 4 games before in this series. The concept is not new: build your island, control your money, eliminate rebels, do a tiny bit of diplomacy. After one or two tries you will realize that this game is much to easy compared to other simulations.And there are some really annoying things about this game:- You can't control immigration. Even if you restrict immigrants to only educated people you will get swarmed by them. They will be homeless and unemployed and rebel costantly.- You can't control stored goods. Even if you essentially need goods like Uranium, the game will sell it. You even can't check how much goods you have stored. Only in your harbor and that's where you don't want to have them- the transportation system is completly bugged. If you add tourists your roads will be one single traffic jam. But your people completly ignore alternative roads but simply pick the shortest route. Even if it takes years. Also you are forced to place production buildings directly next to the resources. Otherwise they will never get them. And later in the game even that doesn't work. If you want to play a city simulation that really works then try Cities Skylines. This one will only frustrate you.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I was one of the many die-hard Tropico fans who was suckered into pre-ordering this game. Tropicos 1 - 4 were all amazing, I can't even begin to count how many hours I've blown playing them on PC and X-Box. And I don't regret a minute playing any of them. So when I heard Tropico 5 was coming out, and it would include features like multiple eras and even a Constitution, I got very excited and pre-ordered ASAP.Big mistake. The game is buggy as hell, some things they refuse to fix. The Constitution options for immigration? Forget about it. They don't make a lick of difference. Even if you ban immigration you still get bunches of immigrants (illegal aliens, anyone?). The entire game has been simplified and dumbed down. And forget about better graphics. Buildings may look sleek from a distance, but zoom in and they are flat and pixelated in the extreme.Just about everything I loved from Tropico 4 was cut out of the game, and precious little was put back in to make up for it. This game is bland, boring, and a complete betrayal of the fan base. Do yourself a favour: buy Tropico 4. I promise it'll be more worth your money than this piece of crap.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Tropico 5 expands on the old things that made the Tropico series great. I love the new combat system, it was always a pain to never be able to fight off foreign invasion despite having a huge standing army, I mean, come on, Cuba won the Bay of Pigs, didn't they? Anyways, although the game is great and the expansions are also great, it would be very nice to see Haemimont/Kalypso expand from the regular Tropico theme. I know that Tropico 2 was comparatively a failure and its pirates theme was probably part of that, but I'm not asking for that much of a deviation. The one thing I would absolutely love for Tropico to do is to take the same everything its known for and place it into different nationality themes. Its great to be Castro for a while, but maybe sometimes I want to be Kim Jung Un, or Idi Amin, or even Erich Honecker. I would love to see a game exactly like Tropico that let me do everything tropico does but with a different ethnicity of people, a different flag, and a different climate.

												If you're going to play a tropico game, play either 3 or 4, they are superior in almost every way. 5 is nothing more than nickel and diming (screw over) the customers. It's been proven some of the so-called dlc's were PART OF THE GAME AND DISABLED, so you are forced to pay for them to turn them back on. It's like buying a car, but forced to pay extra in order to start the car, or use the lights, etc, etc. The only reason I got the game is because it was 80% off. And the only way I'll get the add-on is again, 75% or more off. It is NOT worth more then that. So many buildings are missing, it's pathetic.  Again, if you want to play tropico, only play 3 or 4, unless you can get it for 75% or more off.As for tropico 5 play, it's frustrating. You are forced to play only 2 maps. Your own city builds. Win too quickly and you auto-screw yourself for a auto-lose. Like one mission is timed and you are required to do research to be allowed to build something. You will never make it if you won too quickly on the previous mission of that island.Other things will♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, like many entertainment buildings LIMITS how many are allowed to visit and therefore limits your profit. That alone really screws up the city build.There is also a HIDDEN rating system like even though happyness in the charts show 55%+, your rating on the tab says 40's%. ZERO chance to guess why. Maybe housing, maybe limits of the entertainment buildings. Screws you up trying to get re-elected.Some missions AUTO-LOSE if you take too long as well. Or force hotels to never fill even though they filled to the max the mission before on that island over and over. Many parts of the game almost made me destroy my keyboard a few times. Something tropico 4 or older never did.It's like you would love the game, if it didn't screw you over so many times in so many different ways.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												I love Tropico and have done since my first experience as El Presidente in the original (i love it so much that i rebought 1-4 on steam). For a long time all I ever played were city building games, and I will say that the Tropico series are my favourites. While yes Simcity (the old ones) and even the new Cities Skylines are enjoyable, I usually get bored of the city I'm building after a while with the whole zoning, waiting for people to come to the city and build house/shops/industry build some services then repeat. The Anno series steps it up with you building each building, production chains and the occasional quest making it more engaging for me. Tropico gives me that but it also brings a fantastic humour to my megalomania experience (sorry in advance if I over use humour/funny etc, but it's true) that has me laughing out loud every time I play it and after nearly 300 hours of play I'm still not bored.In this latest instalment the humour that has kept me endlessly amused in previous games is still fantastic (I wish we could all have a Penultimo in our lives). The building models are done with great detail, the colours and textures of my island paradise are amazing. I sometimes like to zoom the camera right in and tilt it so it's like you standing at street level and watch the occasional sunset/rise.I used to feel that I never really had enough time lording over my adoring subjects (benevolently lording, most of the time anyway), especially in sandbox with games 3 and 4, but with the eras setup in this latest instalment I’m in El Presidente heaven. The addition of the colonial time is really nice, when declaring independence I always say 'let the redcoats come, I ain't paying the crown anything' (I'm actually British before anyone says anything). And the era specific random quests have fantastic humour in their delivery. There's one quest during the world wars era where La resistance needs messenger animals, the result of each animal tried - pigs are too tasty and become bacon before reaching their destination, still make me laugh every time. I know there have been a lot of disagreements over the whole DLC thing, I have to admit with other games I've thought they were a bit of a rip off, but with Topico's I've been really quite please. For £2.50 the small single mission ones have kept me entertained for at least a weekend on each play, the 2 £14.99 new campaign ones at least a couple, so I see them as good value (I have played them all more than once). The new random 'side quests' that accompany the DLC's are just as funny as those in the vanilla game and playing through the main campaign again with them popping up can drastically change how things play out. I failed a mission during my 10th play through of the main campaign after the addition of the Mad World and Espionage DLC's, due to a revolt caused by my overuse of banish/kill of crime lords and enemy spies. It was hilarious. So I have bought them all and I probably will continue to buy anymore that come out - if anyone from Kalypso is reading this I loved Pirate Cove, so if you wouldn't mind doing a piratey DLC. As Lulu say's everything is better with pirates!The one thing I will say I don't like and that's the complete reduction in advisors/representatives. I miss Miss Pineapple and her love of spanking (her little guest appearance visiting the fish people in one of the new side quests from the Waterborne DLC was a nice addition). Where's El Diablo telling me to stop letting the riffraff in. And while I love Lulu's radio show, Sunny and Penultimo's banter in 4 was just as fun (maybe they could do a guest spot). What happened to the other nations diplomats? Sometimes I could do with the 30,000 instead of the promised camelI’ve would definitely recommend Tropico 5 to anyone who likes city building games and I hope that Kalypso will continue to bring us more life as El Presidente

												I played Tropico 4 and fell in love with the series, that game was near perfection for a city building series. I then played Tropico 3 and loved that too. When companies do that to their games it strips the quality in the game and you can tell if you just get the base game. Do yourself a favor wait until the game is like $15 with all the dlc content packaged together. You'll save yourself money and MIGHT actually enjoy it in the end.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												The latest iteration of Kalypso Media's Tropico series, you take the reins of controlling your very own dynasty in order to create thriving metropolises right smack in the middle of a tropical island. Those familiar with the Tropcio series will feel right at home here with the fan favorite city building style that Tropico has to offer, but with some distinct gameplay, UI and graphical changes that spice up the series. For those unfamiliar with this game as well as the previous installments, the series is very Sim City-esque but with a refreshing take on the city building genre, giving you free rein on your citizens to do what you please. Want to be a absolute dictator, policing your city completely, riging elections and stopping the immigration of people all together? You can. Overall, I highly recommend this game, as well as the previous Tropico games. It might be worth it to pick up Tropico 3 or 4 with all DLC's if they go on sale before buying this game to get a feel for the series.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Tropico 5 is still a Tropico game through and through, although it is a slight step below Tropico 4.There has been a lot of reviews that say that Tropico 4 is better, and it is, but Tropico 5 is still a fun game and that doesn't mean you should skip it.In Tropico you still play as a lovable dictator leading his latin america island to glory. You have to manage the economy, population happiness, military defence and politics in order to survive.There is flexibility in what economy you want, whether it be exporting raw materials like iron and coffee, turning them into goods like steel or canned food, or tourism.Politics is more advanced than in Tropico 4, where you have the Constitution which affects your country in different ways, and what you choose will affect your standings with the external world powers and also the internal factions in your country.The things that Tropico 4 did better are little things like Penultimo being voiced by a goofy hilarious voice actor, but in Tropico 5 he sounds like a monotonous person with no charisma.Tropico 4 also had nice music with the singing, but Tropico 5 doesn't.These little things however create the funny and fun atmosphere that Tropico is famed for, and something that is slightly missing in Tropico 5.Overall Tropico 5 is still a good game for people who love the franchise. But if you have never played Tropico 4, that game may be more worth your money.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Well , if you have already played previous tropico's then this review is for you , BUT if this is the first tropico you have ever play , then this review is for you aswell :DAlright , for the previous players of tropico you may find this one is easy , with slight compeition and more realistic ways of getting things done , how? well they have added exporting/importing system to be more ''manual'' than just an automatic process , meaning is you can sell your production with higher prices if you get yourself a nice contract , and importing with all its types needs to be done manually. this might be abit harder for the players who first time play tropico through this 1. also the animation of military has been improved , got to be more realistic and more variable. soldiers / tanks / aircrafts / gun towers etc.-The humor in this tropico is slightly less than the previous ones but it didn't vanish.-The dosage of fun when you play either campaign , or single/multiplayer has much more improved than previous ones.-Graphics , textures , buildings has been improved to fit a realistic standards without damaging the purpose of the game.-Choices choices choices , well you get to do more things in this one , so u get to have everything in old tropicos with bounses. BUT HOW COME THEY FORGOT TO ADD PRISONS !!!!??? -Resources variation has been increased , also manufactoring system has been improved , to better.in other words , if this is the first time you play tropico , you will find it one of its kind between the other games in this similar genre , and if tropico 5 isn't your first experince with this title , you will enjoy the variation and upgrades that shows the effort that was put on this one. i recommend having this game either in full/discount prices 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Such a fun but horribly flawed city builder.  I spent the time I have in this game developing my island into a democratic, high liberty, and manufacturing mega plex. Single player only review.Positives-You can develop your island as you see fit (manufacturing, tourist focused, agriculture power house, or any combination)-Streamlined development options for your island-Start in colonial era and work your way into the modern era-Foreign affairs with robust trade options for several other countries-Robust government management (write a constitution with various effects and issue edicts, LOTSA edicts)-Many interesting and unique buildings *IF* you purchase the DLCs (I got them all for .99 during holiday sales)-Military options and invasions (see negatives)-Great graphics, entertaining voice acting, good cha-cha music, humurousNegatives-Poor implementation of the military aspect (if you are going to implement something do it right). Poor pathfinding, very little or no control over military units-Rebels everywhere! No matter what you do you are going to♥♥♥♥♥♥some faction off and they will attack frequently.  It doesnt matter how nice your island is. It dfoesnt matter how free your government is.  It also doesnt matter if you have a 95% happiness rating. It doesnt matter if everyone is filthy rich and living in a mansion.  You WILL get attacked by rebels.-Strange citizen behavior.  Example: Your filthy rich bankers will erect a shacks below a luxury high rise.  This happens often and is very annoying.  Example:  You have guys and gals that just wont get a job no matter how many open jobs there are.  Then these citizens get mad b/c of no work and join the rebels! Example: Your citizens choose to  live in a shack rather than commute to thier job site (even with mass transit available)!-'Cha-Ching' DLC policy by Kalypso (this is nothing new)Overall a fun as hell game with a few annoyances.  Would definately recommend if you are into an interesting city builder where you dont want to worry about micro managing things.  Rating: 80% FUN! 20% Aggrivation with a dash of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off thrown in.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Quick pros and cons of Tropico 5Pros:-Grander scope-You can research techs (as opposed to Modern Times where you had to wait for buildings to unlock)-Constitution is a fun dynamic-Trade routes are a great addition and extra docks are more than just another pick up point for exports-New edicts and edict system ("freebies" to the people aren't a sure fire way to please the people I've actually had to repeal free food in some cases)-More unique raw resources and industry options-More robust politics and diplomacy-No more "one economy fits all" economic strategies-Less "build building x to make people y happy" missions-Campaign is greatly improved, you play on two islands that remain unchanged mission to mission-Building upgrades no longer exclusive to industrial and residential buildings-"Repair All" button after a disaster is a welcomed additionCons:-Learning curve might be a little steep for newcomers compared to older Tropico games-Politics can be muddled at times-Spending money to explore the island is dumb-Invasion combat seems one sided as my defenders have only won twice despite being fairly robust-Building aesthetics through the eras are unchangedOther Thoughts:-Managers system is a little useless in the early game-Dynasty system is interesting but there's no real introduction to it-It's slightly more difficult to gauge what your citizens want so popping up a few churches, clinics, and markets is not a sure way to make your early game citizens happy-I saw a lot of reviews saying most of the humor was taken out of the game which may be true when it comes to building descriptions and the radio broadcasts but the dialogue of your advisers and foreign powers is still pretty funnyIf you're a fan of the Tropico franchise or city builders this game is easy to recommend. However, if you were expecting the same old Tropico you may be little disappointed at first.

												This is the first Tropico game I played, and although the game is not really complex, it delivers. At first I felt close to my people, I wanted to make their life better. But as time passed, and industrialization kicked in, I started been more concerned on my exports and how much could I earn for a specific good. My citizens weren’t all that happy, but i told myself, after I set up this industry I'll  be financially independent and with that base ground I will attend their concerns. Just as in most dictatorships, that day never came, and after a few hours I was in front a monstrous city, struggling to keep up construction and industry profitable enough to avoid default...Force was the fastest way to dissolve protesters, while I was building my so call autarchic society. Sadly I found myself in the same road taken by most dictators today…

It has about 2 sandbox games worth of VO content that tends to be very amusing. Cities all feel the same in the late game though, and there tends to be a "correct" way to play, which doesn't gel well with me. A lot of systems are odd. It's almost great. A few alternate building models, some buildings dedicated to avoiding natural disasters, some more interesting mechanics for trafic and roads and pollution, and it would be a different, awesome game. As is, and knowing what I do now, I wouldn't buy it for more than 15 dollars.Suitably amusing.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Really funny city simulator.The campaign is solid and its objectives are really nice.There are several different (and all valid) options to get fast cash, from farms to factories, from tourism to offices.In this game you are the people manager, for real - not only the buildings positioner -, you need to understand how many educated citizen you have (high school and university), how many not educated, and how your economic development choices will impact on the high school / not educated ratio - for example a farm based economy just needs not educated ppl / a offices based economy needs all ppl from university. Besides the education the population is sorted by age, wealth and preferences, since the population is divided in factions, often asking the opposites, like nationalists vs globalists. During my almost 40 hours play-through I experimented several different economies and I had fun with them all, which is the most important thing to me.To succeed you have to find the right balances between multiple contemporary conditions, all spiced up by random disasters and the various rebellions / invasions.Suggesting the game, my personal score is 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												If you love City Building Games then I highly and most certainly recommend this game for sure. It is by far the most interesting and tedious city builder there is to date which covers a lot of ground to keep you busy and reeled in for hours on end.There are only two major complaints I still have about this game - read why below.1 - The Multiplayer was horrible at first and because of that the game got a really bad wrap from the get go so players stopped playing it online due to the issues it originally had. On a positive note most of those problems were fixed and it does work very well online now. However, due to that bad start it may be hard to play it online unless you go to the community or get a friend to join you.2 - One of my biggest problems that I have always had with this game with each of it's following game sequences is that the buildings are way too repetitive as in all of the building types are the exact same. So once you get further into the game you'll notice that you have lots of areas with houses and buildings but they all look exactly alike with absolutely no variance whatsoever. I have repeatedly complained to them about this in every series and nothing has been done and I doubt now that it will ever change either unless a ton of people start to do the same. One thing though that does make it a little better is the different building types and the added buildings from the dlc but still if you have a bunch of houses and similar buildings you will notice that and it may become an annoyance. If you can look past that then you'll enjoy it! On top of that the Eras also do help aid with that in changing the look of several types of buildings after upgrades have occurred from advancing in time but many do not such as housing unfortunately.Anyhow though, aside from those two issues it is still an epic game and I definitely think it's worth the price in full but if you'd rather wait for a sale then I would certainly recommend grabbing it for sure to say the least!

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Bad enough to prompt me to write this review. Stats that are no longer linked and missions that have nothing to do with your island. "New Steel Mill" when I have no coal mines - it's too god damn expensive to import coal to make it worth it. Rebellion every 5 minutes even though my Almanac consistently says 0 Rebels on the island. "Budget" is a confusing mess of dollar symbols.Do NOT spend your money here, Kalypso does not deserve it this time. See the comments too.I have played for more than 100 hours at the writing of this final piece. Tropico 5 is a badly designed, badly implemented, really pretty version of Tropico 4 that was made for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in diapers who have never played a city builder and need hand holding to the max. Replayability: 0. Expect the SAME THING every time. Put it on a higher difficulty? Don't expect it to be logical or even challenging in a humorous way like T4 was, it will just be a BIG WASTE OF YOUR TIME AND MONEY. Campaign? Oh, play the same 2 islands that will get bugged out and impossible to play the campaign if you try to do anything other than what your hand holder tells you. Multiplayer? Don't waste your time, the rest of the game is terrible. One way stat progression, one way tech trees, mines and mines of useful information that is buried 15 layers deep in the game, time-flow corruption (i.e: your trade ship says it will be here in 6 months, the election doesnt happen for 8 months. Somehow you lose the election before your trade ship gets back to dock.) Not to mention it's so god damn FAST. By the time you have researched "power plant" in the world war era, its already time to advance to the cold war and you are in massive debt from trying to keep up with the tech tree! Economy is BROKEN BROKEN BROKEN on any higher level difficulties, with or without trade it is nigh impossible not to go into debt while trying to keep ANY factions or people over 50% happiness, let alone one at a time. Disasters want to feel like they are broken but really some noob game dev at Kalypso decided it would be a "good" game addition for disasters to break everything all the time. Don't even get me started on the TERRIBLE voice acting and the ATROCIOUS sound effects, as well as the three whole songs that loop on repeat OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER.PLEASE DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY HERE. Kalypso has made some good gems and a lot of terrible trash. This game is terrible trash with faux gems hot glued all over it.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												I bought this game, in the hope to find a good city building game, which I'm sure it was, however despite this: I found that the game would not function properly as far as the game would not go in full screen correctly, the taskbar would still be on the screen, whilst the game running in full screen mode so some of the screen would be unaccessable, meaning windows would still be running in the background thus affecting frame rates and how the game runs etc. I run a 1920x1080p monitor, a common resolution yet I got this problem; I tried to fix this by trouble shooting however the fixes did not work such as ALT+ENTER etc. I attempted a reinstall many times however the problem persisted. Luckily, I got the game for £12 on sale, so not as much money was wasted, however a game that has been out for almost a year and is pumping out DLC already, shouldn't have any issue along these lines under any circumstances. Despite this, I was very lucky because steam offered me a refund due to its issue. On another related topic: I would, from the gameplay I've seen, heard from friends and the brief while I played, I would reccomend this game for gameplay however, if you have a 1920x1080p monitor, I would say it's not worth the risk, especially at £30. As advice to people who may have purchased this game and experience this issue or any game affecting issue significant enough for the game to not be playable, it is against UK law(only applicable if you bought and use this game in the UK), and you are entitled for a refund, however luck and good tech support is required, which I was fortunate enough to have.Thank you for reading, for the developers on the other hand,Please fix your games and don't let this happen again.

content:
Posted: March 31
												This is in my opinion the best version of Tropico. Many people complain that there are not so much statistics, and infos are missing. They are not. Even the famous "empty buildings" statistic is there. The only things which are missing are the first person view and the speeches before the elections. But these few things that are missing can't compare to the things which are added. Four epoches, many more buildings in total, new units and finally some suspense. The best features are the slightly harder difficulty and the controller support, trade missions,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ colony status at the beginning, more fights (which are by no means the center of the game, but it's better than the games before when nearly no one was attacking you). The graphics are nice, the music is great as ever and the humor is always there.A really nice game to relax, to shape your town, to do mad or bad or good things, listen to caribean music and watch your people embrassing their beloved leader (or trying to kill him).

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												- Voice actors are worse than 3 and 4, especially Penultimo- Character variety, faction leaders typecasting and funny plotlines are less than other games- Actually, in general the game has lost its funny and sarcastic nature compared to old games- Only 2 maps for campaign and you continue next missions where you left off.  This seemed to be a good feature at first but after four or five mission it's getting annoying- New trade system is frustrating and complicated.- Constitutions change nothing, there were still religious tasks/demands/protests/riots even though i proclaimed "atheist nation"-Campaign scenario is weird, Every new mission starts at Colonial Era no matter how far the date progress on previous mission. But plot, buildings and character interactions stay chronogical. This is a very stupid thing.- Zoom-in is restricted to about 4-5 meter top down view and you can't see the Tropicans closely or even El Presidente.- By the way There's no controlling El Presidente anymore- I didn't like the new radio host. She is not funny and don't compatible with events that happen on island.- El Presidente customization is barren, you can't even customize your first name. Wt* actually?To make the long story short; Tropico 5 is a big disaster and fail. Absolutely not recommend it, buy 3 - 4 or both instead.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												(Note my comments are strictly holding to the base game.  I have not played a single expac/dlc.)  T4 just felt like a more compelling and engaging product.  Managing the army felt better, and also playing the tourism side felt more interesting.  The Campaign for 4 definitely felt superior too.  5 has some improvements: less guess work with construction, and I like managing the plantations/ranches in 5 (unless you are talking hydroponic farms.  Really Calypso?  High school graduates?!  You don't think that doesn't totally bork your game?)  but I do miss running the prison farms from 4.  In short, I may remember a few small details wrong because it's been years since I played 4, but I do remember being super satisfied with my experience with 4.  Not quite with 5.  I liked it enough, but I wouldn't recommend it. Oh and Calypso, after playing Prison Architect, the only way you are getting me to buy the eventual T6 is if you provide  a layout mode.  Guessing, placing, cancelling construction, replacing, maybe cancelling again, etc. until i get the building placement perfect (I hope) for my future plans is something we need to get passed.  Presidente' has access to paper and pencil.  It is well within his/her capabilities to plan ahead.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												I can't recommend this title, despite it being somewhat enjoyable to play. The cheeky story and humor are there, but, if you're looking for an experience as deep and challenging as Tropico 4, you will be disappointed.Unfortunately, as with many games of recent issue, this game suffers from dumbing down for console play. Lots of things that experienced Tropico players know and rely on to really add depth to the game are gone. The most useful overlays, such as occupancy, profitability, employment level, newspaper, television, and rado station types... all gone in favor of being able to play the game on limited hardware with just a few buttons. In fact, radio stations are gone altogether. You cannot directly set wages at buildings anymore, in favor of a "budget" system that supposedly sets wages, but in reality allows you NO control over wages to properly prioritize your economy. Rents and entry fees on homes and service buildings also gone, in favor of a simple button saying "Tourists Only". You can see these glaring oversimplifications everywhere you turn.The campaign is far too easy, and I was able to complete it in about 20 hours with no failures, really. The dynasty system seems pointless and can be ignored without affecting gameplay in any way. In short, Tropico 5 is to Tropico 4 as the Texas flag is to the US flag... a dumbed down, easy reader version of the original.Also, I got the "Big Cheese" DLC as part of my pre-order for free, and this is a good thing, because I would have been really upset if I had paid for it. All it adds is a singlee building, the creamery, and ONE, count em ONE mission... which is 100% more missions than the game came with outside the original campaign.Look, I'm not a console player. I don't like console games, because I prefer something a bit deeper. That said, there are some console-type titles I have enjoyed and do enjoy playing. If this is the future of the game industry, then there are some pretty dark times ahead. I'll be putting this back on the shelf and playing user content in T4 instead.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												While the only other Tropico game I have played is 4, I can say that Tropico 5 makes a number of enjoyable changes to add freshness and more depth to the gameplay. The era system introduced in this game, alongside the campaign that involves playing on two different maps and selecting whihc one you believ that you have already built up to be the most useful for the next mission makes for an interesting change of pace from the constant blank slate starts of Tropico 4. Managers are also a welcome change, bringing new ways to help your economy grow. While overall I would say the game is very good, there are a few small problems, the first being the research points system, whihc while I do like better than purchasing blueprints from Penultimo, I find ot be a bit dull as I always find myself choosing to do my researches in the same order. Additionally I feel the number of wacky quest giver characters to be reduced greatly. The final issue, and perhaps the only big one is the cost of the DLC, which for what it gives is simply too high, but the base game is plenty of fun without it, and Im sure it will eventually go on sale for a reasonable price.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												While it is by no means bad, I feel that this game is a lesser version of its predecessor, lacking a certain depth and variety that Tropico 4 enjoyed. The addition of a 'snap-to' grid that allows for easier building placement is welcome, but with so fewer buildings available, my cities are just never as vibrant as before. The changing of eras throughout the missions is nice, but no replacement for the genuine humour and excellent voice-talent that is sadly absent.Even the soundtrack lacks the panache that was present in Tropico 4. It's still a competent, enjoyable city-builder that's worth a play if you're new to the series, but even then, you'd be better served by picking up one of it's predecessors, much more cheaply.

content:
Posted: April 2
												This game doesn't seem to be finished.  They've added some cool concepts since the previous title, but seem to lack some of the previous things.  For example, there's a grade school education level, but there doesn't seem to be a grade school anywhere.  There's a huge lack of management screens as well.  There's no way to see the price of exports before exporting them or having a trade route established and it's not as simple to see factions' desires.There's not enough character customizations.  I can't even customize the first one's name, but rather choose from a bunch of "Tropico names" where I just press left/right starting from A...  Also there's hardly any real customizations for like, clothing or hats and such.  They have the basics, maybe 4 or 5 that look somewhat decent, then a few more that I can't imagine using.  Like, who would use a pacifier or snorkel?  There's even Napoleon and steampunk - and don't get me wrong I love steampunk, but this isn't steampunk lol.Possibly the worst part of this is it feels like it takes the customization out of everything.  The game randomly generates mini-quests which change everytime you play the campaign.  So you might start off with it telling you to make a couple meat ranches or sugar plantations, then the next time you come back to this map instead of going with something like a cannery quest or rum - it suggests planks.  Or you'll have a couple wharves already made and the quest now needs a couple more - I'm out of fish already.  And if you take initiative and try to make your population happy by building clinics and such, the next quests might be to build a new clinic or mission - wtf.  So I find myself more often just sitting back and following the quests instead of doing anything on my own.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												This is a bad game. It's pretty to look at, and an interesting idea for a game (so interesting they made it four times already), but when you actually play it, you find that most of the difficulty comes from wrestling with frustrating and unclear game mechanics rather than competent game design or an intentional learning curve. I think this game may have made me smile twice; once at a Pirates of Penzance reference that seemed completely at odds with the offensive characterchers and cheap gags populating the rest of the game, and the second time when I uninstalled it and could sigh with relief that the experience was finally over and that I hadn't paid a dime for it, unlike the other sad souls leaving reviews here.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Really funny city simulator.The campaign is solid and its objectives are really nice.There are several different (and all valid) options to get fast cash, from farms to factories, from tourism to offices.In this game you are the people manager, for real - not only the buildings positioner -, you need to understand how many educated citizen you have (high school and university), how many not educated, and how your economic development choices will impact on the high school / not educated ratio - for example a farm based economy just needs not educated ppl / a offices based economy needs all ppl from university. Besides the education the population is sorted by age, wealth and preferences, since the population is divided in factions, often asking the opposites, like nationalists vs globalists. During my almost 40 hours play-through I experimented several different economies and I had fun with them all, which is the most important thing to me.To succeed you have to find the right balances between multiple contemporary conditions, all spiced up by random disasters and the various rebellions / invasions.Suggesting the game, my personal score is 8/10

												I don't know. I like the idea of research with the tech tree and such. It's just too bad it's so linear. Which I just hate- once you've done it once, there is no fun to do it again. Also, once you've researched every tech, you have three options to pick from every year or so(kinda forgetful). I would rather have more freedom with tech trees. They can even just go the lazy route and have you research for a happier populace but gives you some whacky penalty. But I guess if you did that, you would probably have to get rid of edicts? Again ... I don't know. It's not a fun feature.The graphics are alright. So ... you got that.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Really funny city simulator.The campaign is solid and its objectives are really nice.There are several different (and all valid) options to get fast cash, from farms to factories, from tourism to offices.In this game you are the people manager, for real - not only the buildings positioner -, you need to understand how many educated citizen you have (high school and university), how many not educated, and how your economic development choices will impact on the high school / not educated ratio - for example a farm based economy just needs not educated ppl / a offices based economy needs all ppl from university. Besides the education the population is sorted by age, wealth and preferences, since the population is divided in factions, often asking the opposites, like nationalists vs globalists. During my almost 40 hours play-through I experimented several different economies and I had fun with them all, which is the most important thing to me.To succeed you have to find the right balances between multiple contemporary conditions, all spiced up by random disasters and the various rebellions / invasions.Suggesting the game, my personal score is 8/10

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												This is a bad game. It's pretty to look at, and an interesting idea for a game (so interesting they made it four times already), but when you actually play it, you find that most of the difficulty comes from wrestling with frustrating and unclear game mechanics rather than competent game design or an intentional learning curve. I think this game may have made me smile twice; once at a Pirates of Penzance reference that seemed completely at odds with the offensive characterchers and cheap gags populating the rest of the game, and the second time when I uninstalled it and could sigh with relief that the experience was finally over and that I hadn't paid a dime for it, unlike the other sad souls leaving reviews here.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Ever want to be a leader of your own nation? With it's own set of rules, laws, and regulations? plus the ideological factor that drives your nation so? Then this game is for you!I had a blast while playing this game and you will too! There is a lot to do in this game, which can make time fly fast which is nice. Like in Sid Meier's Civilzation V you have to keep an eye out on your happiness, and your production level! Too litte, and your nation will starve of resources and rebel against you, Too much, and you will have constant invasions by the outside world. You need to find the right balance, plus make sure you choose your edicts wisely, pick the wrong ones too early and you will be at a disadvantage, pick the right ones in the right point in time might just help in your favor, or not depending upon whether or not you choose to upgrade your armies and defenses.You can 'customize' your dictator, with outfits, looks, first name and last name. However, the first name is randomly generated so that's the downside to that. Plus you can upgrade your 'dynasty' members to be better, which is highly advise. Another downside is that it's not like Crusaders Kings where you can marry someone and have a child, it's randomly generated with a look, and the only thing you can customize is the outfit itself.The locations are very well done, each island offers a unqiue spin on how you want to build your nation. If you pick a tiny island you have limited resources to build your country, If you have a huge island you have endless opportunity to build whatever it is you want to build. Like real life you must geographical plan out where you put your buildings and roads, plus your defenses and what not. The last you want is have a full fledge invasion, and your military defenses is sub-par, plus your guard tower locations are out of whack.The music in this game while it's fun to listen too, It can get a bit repetitive so becareful there. I am honestly surprised there is no mod workshop for this game, i can see the potential in what kind of mods this game can produce. Lastly, the achievements are easy to earn. And the tutorial is really simple and easy to understand.If you want in-depth nation building then this game is for you. Recommend!

												This is the first Tropico game that i have played in the series, That in mind : PROS : fun & funny!Amazing soundtracks.Amazing sound assets.Beautiful atmosphere.Beautiful graphic assets: High quality models, textures, surfaces (terrain), you name it.Awesome gameplay as long as it lasts!CONS (Just one but a huge one) : Awesome gameplay as long as it lasts, And it lasts halfway through the game.The late game gets easier and of course, Easier means BORING.This game / series seems promising, This is the type of game that you already have a strong solid gameplay core for, Now the developers just need to go wild with it, Sadly, They didn't go wild with this game (hence the boring late game), If they did, This game would have been easily ranked as my favorite city builder/management to date.once a presidente, always a presidente﻿!

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Tropico 5 - Sandbox Play Through Each Age 

			Views: 74		

			I present to you, Tropico 5! This is a great development of the series. A common complaint for Tropico 4 was that it was too much like Tropico 3, so this is the answer for those that wanted something...		

Tropico 5 is a great development of the series. A common complaint for Tropico 4 was that it was too much like Tropico 3, so this is the answer for those that wanted something different. Luckily they didn't change anything about the game that made the previous ones so great. I recorded this video with no music, because sadly Youtube griefs me anytime I've done that for any Tropico game... so the video is a bit lacking. Just play some Hispanic music in the background and you'll be all set.The age system is the biggest difference in this iteration of the game, other than perhaps multiplayer, and although it is a valiant effort... it becomes tedious after progressing through it a few times.  It works ok for the story mode, but the best part about the age system is that it can essentially be turned off during sandbox games by setting the starting era to Modern Times. Multiplayer looks good... but I haven't played enough to really get a feel for it yet. The best change to Tropico 5 is the Dynasty system. Building your dynasty is fun, and finally gives you a reason to have a fat stack of cash in your slush fund. So all in all, I'm really happy with the game. I sometimes miss the simplicity of the older games, mainly because of the addition of the age system, but the Tropico series is still my favorite city builder, and I expect to play Tropico 5 for many, many more hours to come.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Went ahead and familiarized myself with the tutorial levels to what new has been added to this already excellent game series; and I have to say, Kalypso has outdone themselves. The engine is smooth, AI works more accordingly, changes to buildings such as updgrades and expanded timelines with technology research has made the next piece in the Tropico anthology an obvious gem.The reactions from foreign powers and consequences against your little island paradise are vast and far reaching. Random events and disasters are far more balanced; and politics and trade are a bit more in depth, giving players a chance to either maximize profit or be able to work up foreign relations through trade.Most notable in the Tropico game series, is implementing different era's for your island to push through with a new technology tree, allowing one to progress in numerous paths when deciding there tropical paradises fate.For any looking for an excellent city building simuation, Tropico 5 is worth the price-tag.Edit: Update on gameplay:So I get to a population of about 2,500 and things are looking good not only financially but my diplomatic stances with foreign nations were all warm, if not neutral. However there was discontent brewing over the past decade, the nationalists were becoming increasingly vocal and taking up arms in small rebel actions against my regime. I began noticing arresting rebels belonged to a mixture of the nationalists and environmentalists. Years of an open immigration policy, immigrants on almost every boat to port for the past couple years. Then recently I managed to receive 60 Chinese immigrants.Immediatly rebel action began to scale up with a series of attacks on my cash crop farms, and they were succeeding with every other attack. I chose to put my foot down and lure the rebels numerous times, thinning there ranks and arresting identified rebels. But of course I had many citizens who were very loyal, I met all their desires, the militarists, globalists and capitalists were almost eating out of the palm of my hand.Well one fine morning I put the finishing touches on putting the last of identified rebels down. Moments later the uprising began. Markers began popping up everywhere as my military scattered to intercept any rebel forces. There were people fighting for my regime, but many more fighting against. I watched as my population counter suddenly dropped by fifty in mere moments. One by one guard towers fell and the mob slowly gathered together in an unstoppable show of force. My fighters bombarding the crowd to no avail, there were to many to stop now.After a drawn out battle with some few loyal forces I had left who trekked over half the island to my palace were to late as the rebels burned my personal fortress into ashes, three square blocks on fire or bombed out. The revolution was over, it wasn't even sunset yet.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Although I was a big fan of Tropico 4, I can not in good faith recommend Tropico 5. Massive chunks of content were taken out from the previous game. What little has been added is sort of a "one step forward, two steps back" scenario. While the constitution and era mechanics are nice, it doesn't make up for the fact that most buildings were taken out. Not only that, but several GUI elements have been removed entirely, like being able to see the monetary balance of specific buildings and being able to see population maps. There are even fewer political factions as well. Just about everything in Tropico 5 is a downgrade, and it's a real shame because I was rather excited for it. All in all, you can probably squeeze a few hours out of this game, but I'd recommend getting Tropico 4 instead. 4/10

Moments later the uprising began. Markers began popping up everywhere as my military scattered to intercept any rebel forces. There were people fighting for my regime, but many more fighting against. I watched as my population counter suddenly dropped by fifty in mere moments. One by one guard towers fell and the mob slowly gathered together in an unstoppable show of force. My fighters bombarding the crowd to no avail, there were to many to stop now.After a drawn out battle with some few loyal forces I had left who trekked over half the island to my palace were to late as the rebels burned my personal fortress into ashes, three square blocks on fire or bombed out. The revolution was over, it wasn't even sunset yet.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Absolutely terrible in every way. This game is one of the worst I have played in recent years. Every single game I own that I frequently play supports 4K no problem, this game only does 1440p. When you turn 4K on, it's pretending to be 4K but really it's exactly the same as 1440p. On 1440p AND 4K mode, the scroll/camera rotation rotates at least 100 times at the slightest touch. The only way to make camera rotation work is to run it on a low resolution like 1080P and turn V-sync off. However, every few minutes with v-sync off on ANY resolution will cause my screen to get visual artifacts in the middle then flash black over and over causing my graphics driver to crash and the card to over heat. I have never experienced such a faulty game since tropico 4, which right after I purchased my 4K monitor started glitching and flashing black, then corrupted all of my save files. I don't know if the developers are ignorant or incompetent, but whatever it is, they're obviously not very professional when they can't make a game without significant bugs. Will try to get a refund.

												7.8/10In terms of "new" city building strategy games, you cant get any better than this.heres a list of the things I think are good and bad so far.Pros-Nice refined graphics and an up to date art style.-Gameplay hasn't changed much, but in a good way!-Good system of "leveling" through the ages, with buildings and policies refering to each period, e.g, cold war+uranium-Better trade system, a lot simpler and makes more sense.-Dynasty system allows you to boost your economy and can be upgraded with Swiss bank account.-Better Military system alround.-Multiplayer (its always good to play together)Cons-Fewer Factions alround, easier to "appease" everyone. focusing more on Housing, entertainment etc.-Lacking Customisation, clothing for dynasty members, and different "housing" styles and colours.-Dynasty/President members traits are less focused, "Religious Zealot" or "Capitalist Dog" or "Power to the people"-Fewer buildings/not much in the way of new added buildings.-Less Secret Police/specialist buildings and actions, and theres not a lot added in relation of this.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												OverviewTropico 5 is a fun, light hearted yet deep city builder game.  You can create your "El Presidente", and through the course of the game, their dynasty.  You rule over an island over various eras and need to build it up, focusing on housing, food, money making, employment, religion, healthcare, happiness, diplomacy among other things.  For fans of previous versions, Tropico 5 is more of an evolution of the series rather than a revolution.  New & Improved features (A sample)- Dynasties - Can have more members of your family, can make them managers, send them on missions or make them El Presidente- Eras - Can start from the Colonial Era, under the tyrrany of the crown, up to the Modern era. - Managers - Can now employ different kinds of managers to buildings to grant bonuses. - New buildings- Improved AI - Especially construction priorityPros: The game has a lot of depth and challenge, that gets more challenging to handle as your island grows.  Managing employment, military, production, diplomatic relations, security are just some of these.  The game has a nice, tongue in cheek humor that I like and it looks great.  A lot of the annoying AI issues in the previous version seem to be fixed.  The campaign is fun and does a good job of taking you through all the areas of the game.  Also, the Dynasty / Manager system is a nice feature allowing you to provide good bonuses to key areas / buildings. Cons: The game, like the previous one, suffers from lack of information tabs.  While it does a good job at providing the basic information you need it lacks the ability to get a more detailed look, for example, to compare production vs transport capacity, unemployment by area, free jobs by location etc.  While with practise and some manual effort you can get some of this information, it really should be provided to you in an easier way.  As such, it leads to a reactive nature, reacting to issues instead of being able to be pro-active, especially when your island grows. Summary: An evolution of the series that has fixed most of the issues from previous versions while adding some nice new features on top.  The lack of in depth analytical info is a shame and I can imagine some Tropico Vetrans might be dissapointed with the lack of new content vs previous versions.  But for those new to the series with an interest in city builders, this one comes highly recommended. Score: 8/10 - Good Solid City Builder

content:

												 While I found Tropico 4 the pinnacle of the series, I enjoyed Tropico 5 as another aspect to the game play that has made the series a darling.  Tropico 5’s timing seems slower paced than 4, but the consistent humor and different ways to build your nation is never repetitive.  The only thing I wished was better was the DLC package.  The DLCs are more add-ons rather than enhancements to the game.  For example, the Waterborne expansion allows me to utilize the ocean, but it’s an “okay” feature that doesn’t enhance the game.    Regardless, I’m a sucker for these games and I keep buying the DLCs in hopes that they’ll make a Tropico 6.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
My experience playing this game is solely based on vanilla singleplayer sandbox mode.I enjoyed Tropico 5 quite a bit. It's a bit different than CIties skylines but I would say that for me it has atleast the same entertainment value if not better. Tropico 5 was definitely better than EA's simcity. Nevertheless, I think Tropico 5 (or 4, more on that on the end of the review) is a must buy for everyone who like building games or economic games in general.I must add that Tropico 5 is more difficult, atleast I found myself struggling with economy on my first two runs. This is because you rarely receive constant income like in other city building games, but instead you receive money when trade ships show up and buy your resources, and the income you get from a single ship is very irregular. For example one day you might receive 1k for selling bananas and weeks or months later when next ship arrives 10k for jewelry. And meanwhile you are constantly losing money to upkeep your production facilities.Tropico 5 is quite solid actually, no bugs or anything that I've experienced. Only thing I was a bit annoyed about was that everytime autosave happened my game went to a loading screen and after that for some reason wanted to change my dynastys name, so I had to press cancel and second loading screen followed. But that can be avoided by reducing or disabling autosaves in options. Loading screens were also fairly short so I wasn't too bothered really.It is quite common that Tropico 5 can be bought at discount, especially outside steam, but I can recommend it for full price as well if you like building games like I do. Many reviewers seem to say that Tropico4 is better, so check that out before you buy and make your own conclusions.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Buy this game.Every Tropico released since 3 has felt like a refinement since, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. This series has always been right where it needs to be in terms of gameplay, humor and style; it's just been a matter of perfecting it. While Tropico 5 brings the series closer than ever to perfection in an absolutely beautiful iteration of the series, it's had to take some things that fans love away in the process. But I trust Kalypso to continue to refine the game in later updates and expansions. I'd wholly recommend this game to fans and newcomes alike. Viva El Presidente.Pros:- Graphic updates bring you a gorgeous, sun soaked Carribean.- Difficult. In previous Tropicos I never had an issue getting elected with the majority of the vote. Now I'm constantly on the offensive trying to figure out what needs fixing.- Fantastic little details crammed into every corner.- A new sense of depth to the gameplay, new strategies to be brought out, and new ways to plan your regime.- More of the fantastic humor that's always made the series a joy to play.- New trade and political options.Cons:- Faction advisors gone, no more Sunny or Ms Pineapple to update you on the latest situation.- Difficult UI, a bit of a hassle trying to sift through all the citizens to uncover the root of a problem.- Buildings could have used more variety and height as in previous iterations. While the graphic updates are charming, there could have been more options.- Seriously. I miss Sunny and Penultimo's banter.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												For those, who do not have Tropico 4 and do not plan to buy it, buy Tropico 5. The game has decent gameplay, nice graphics and good sound effects. The story, while not that importaint for the game of this genre, is still nice.For those who do have Tropico 4, I'd say you should still buy Tropico 5. The gameplay is somewhat different form the previous installment, and you might find it fun and entertaining. While not as hot, the game is still playable."Yes, there are problems".First of all, the game has been somewhat dumbed down comparing to Tropico 4. There are much less micro, and all in all it is easier to complete missions.There are much less jokes as well. Lulu's radio is not as hot as Sunny's, and characters are not as funny. Still, some do hit the goal, especially white flag one. :) It might have been better if Lulu was more talkative, but she only pops out that often.Still, the game seems to have a great potential, and I hope we would see patches and addons which fixes these problems. Meanwhile, I'd give the game 7/10.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Tropico 5 is a welcome sequel to a great series. Many fans were underwhelmed by Tropico 4. While the game was solid it did little to innovate on Tropico 3 and its expansions. Tropico 5 took notes, and now offers a very different gameplay experience.The biggest changes are the multitude of little tweaks, such as how farms work, a new research system, new specialist system, the dynasty mechanics and a dozen other little things that overhaul the game hugely. Each is well implemented with the level of detail and balance we've come to expect from the series.The new time based campaigns are also something that Tropico players have talked about for a long term- persistent islands. Traditionally each level in Tropico is its own map, but no longer. You have only two islands in this game, and you develop them through the campaign. This requires much more foresight and planning and led to me needing to restart the campaign twice because I didn't think far enough ahead. I thoroughly enjoyed overcoming this great new challenge.If you've never played Tropico I'd suggest starting with 3 or 4. 5 is a very different game but it maintains the tone, feel and gameplay shape of its predecessors. As such you can spend a little less seeing if you like the style before you commit to spending more on the recent title.If you know Tropico and love it, then you'll love Tropico 5. Faithful, but not afraid to break new ground. And they break it with extreme competence and authority.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												The game has amazing music and humorous dialogue. It provides a good challenge while simultaneously offering a relaxed and even casual play time. The new Waterborne campaign is fun and worth the money. Multiplayer is fun but few people seem to take advantage of it.  The Tropico line of games continues to impress and is a fan favorite. The company would not hurt from giving attention to a few minor details like ensuring the correct accent is given to the voices in the game (Carribbean Spanish accent versus Spain or Mexico Spanish) and other little details.I feel like the game could do a better job with tutorials by offering advanced tutorials that show players the ins and outs of economy at a detailed level to include how to maximize trade and edicts. Also, constitutional choices and how they affect factions and political standing.. Explanations on why my island might have 100 job openings and 100 unemployed even when I am making them pay for their own healthcare and food would be nice.The game has much more potential especially if they focus on multiplayer. Allow each player to have their own islands and conduct trade with each other, setting their own prices, etc. Marine and Air warfare. Corporate espionage and sabotage. Paying pirates to invade th other players. Joint ventures.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												I personally am new to the Tropico series and have heard of the complaints that this game is lazy, overpriced, doesn't improve upon the past titles, and is a DLC fiasco. I believe these arguments are probably true, but I cannot deny that I've had a lot of fun with this game. The content within the game is comparable to that of city builders like SimCity, but is quite unique with its castro style setting, including a corrupt government, constant foreign aid, and an island atmosphere. Although this may be the case for the other Tropico games, I can say that it was an enjoyable experience for me personally as a first time Tropico player. That said, I do not think that the game is worth $40 at all, and that it should certainly be bought while on sale. Also note that the game has decent graphics requirements, so don't try and play it on a scrub PC or else it won't work.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												I've only played Tropico 4 and 5 and since most people have been commenting and reviewing on the differences between the two of them, I figure I'm qualified to review this accurately.I highly enjoy Tropico 5. I find it very addicting as I'm a complex strategy player at heart and enjoy the extra content, options, and challenge it provides. I think the dynasty mechanic is pretty interesting, it helps you overall in game though it does suck you can't control it a little more, specifically the first names and skill trait your heir gets.You definitely have to use your head! This is a simulation of you being a dictator after all! ANY decision you make will typically either affect you positively or negatively. How extreme depends on previous decisions you've made like who your allies are or will be and whether or not you've taken precautions to keep social unrest down. It's a lot more scale tipping than Tropico 4 and you have to have a short learning curve to enjoy this game for what it is. It's highly political and invasion is more likely from people you♥♥♥♥♥♥off than Tropico 4.Overall I think it's a more realistic rendition of a dicatorship simulation. Even at "Occassional" freaking random disasters, riots, conspiracies, etc happen regularly. I love it.If you don't actually like critical thinking strategy games, rely on foreign aid like a crutch all the time, or only played Tropico series for the humor then I wouldn't recommend this to you. If you love a true leadership simulation including managing, building, arresting, bribes, banishing, political gambles, and all the little aspects that come with it or just love world history, I do recommend this game!Likes- More challenging overall- Nicer Graphics- Dynasty Members Mechanic- In Depth Import/Export Trade Mechanic- Politics Game- Love having building managers to increase overall production/job/building function!Differences | Dislikes- *BIG* Less humorous than previous Tropcios IMO. They have jokes but it's like "Ha. Ha." More than hilarous imo.- Wish I could name and pick the trait (other than the 3 provided) for my heir- Would like more outfits than currently provided for avatars (Might be future DLC)- Wish I could purchase/attract more trade ships other than building a dock per trade ship ratio.- While I like the Eras mechanic, find it a little hindering BUT NOT IMPOSSIBLE for things like tourism or imprisoning/arresting etc not able to be done earlier in the game.- There is less of a subtle teaching mechanism in Tropico 5 than 4. You pretty much trial and error play blindly until you find yourself out of a job and have to restart the game with what you've learned. I can handle it personally but it might be a turn off for other players who need a bit more guidance in a game. (Took me a while to figure out how trade works and that I could send squads to unveil the island. No instructions on that.)Tips- Save Regularly. It does autosave but since crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥happens in short amounts of time, you may want to change a bad outcome.- I reccommend doing a little research before playing the game. If you aren't familiar with actual world history or the game's new mechanics it will behoove you to look a few things up ahead of time like what technologies/resources and trade will be available in future eras so you can plan accordingly.- Check the trade routes before you designate farms/ranches/mines. You can profit more with something in demand.- Send out the squad from your palace to open up other areas of the island. (Costs $1000)- Don't be afraid/panic if you go into the negative in your treasury a bit. You have a -$10,000 Defincit allowance.- If you have 51% love of your people, I don't recommend doing an election if you can't improve in 12 months. I've literally lost an election like that hitting 49% by 12 months. And when in doubt if you've already agreed or suddenly lost a lot of support dont be afraid to call Martial Law to stop the election!- Always expect the unexpected.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												A singleplayer game worth your money. Tropico 5 is a fair game for a fair price, an enjoyable Dictator simulator that while borrows many visual assets from previous games, has gameplay rebuilt from ground up. As a player who never touched campaign mode, the focus on a deep and richer sandbox mode is exactly what I wanted. Here are some ups and downs from my experience.-DON'T BUY FOR MULTIPLAYERAnyone buying Tropico 5 for multiplayer should definitely wait a long time, its a half-baked feature that may very well need an entire expansion (or two) to get right.-ALMANACThe new Almanac technically has most of the information you could get from 4, but its not very intuitive.  It takes a long itme to figure out where the important info is scurried away. Sometimes you need to scroll down, sometimes its behind an inconspicious word button. You have to explore every nook and cranny to find what you need. +DYNASTYThe Dynasty mechanic was kind of a letdown. Its an upgrade from T4, where each skill doesn't go into a massive pool, but is tied to a specific character (who can potentially die in certain circumstances.)+ERAS AND MISSION STRUCTUREThe Era system is the real game changer. If you've seen TotalBuscuit's T5 preview, you'll know the game has a very rigid, formulaic mission structure at the start, the Colonial Era. This is the most defining and brilliant of changes made to the Tropico series.These Colonial missions are guide you to very specific objectives, ignoring these usually  results in a premature ending. This is done to prevent you from falling into a routine which in prior games, would kill the fun of these games after awhile. These mission chains will seem binding, that you HAVE to do exactly what these missions tell you or fail. However, as your understanding of the game mechanics come together, you can figure out how much breathing space you have to fulfill the missions while building the Tropico you have in mind. +-COMBATCombat is all about expectations. Its no RTS. Its a little hands off, but for me personally its hard to react to changing circumstances. Your firepower comes only from three sources: guard towers, soldiers and tanks. If all of these sources of attack power are gone, you're effectively done. The most depth I've found with the system is grouping Guard Towers, so that the tankiness of the towers are complemented by consistent firepower which can kill enemy units and actually turn battles around. There should be ways to react to a bad situation, by cutting deals or accepting demands.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Topico 5 lacks much of the charm that made the earlier Tropico games memorable. The songs are all weak instrumental tracks rather than the awesome vocals tracks of earlier titles. There is none of the fun advisor commentary from earlier ones ("You are making qute a lot of enemies, Presidente!"). Even the simple pleasure of clicking on a random citizen and getting to know who they are and what they are doing is gone. The people instead scurry around as faceless drones that can't be interacted with. That takes all of the fun out of crushing a rebellion. The developers seem to be abandoning the roots of what made the original Tropico (and Tropico 3) special.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Tropico 5 is a fun city builder type game. It is not the same as Sim Cities or similar games so don't expect it to be.You get to play as an oppressive dictator, what else could you want? Stalin 2.0The main difference aside from some parts of gameplay is the single player story mode which ties together a large portion of the game.You might be wondering how a city builder can have a story mode, which is exactly what I asked myself.Oddly enough it was not horrible, mildly confusing, but it brought out a lot of game play mechanics you might have otherwise avoided or missed in sandbox.I have yet to try out the multiplayer and probably wont so nothing to say there.The game play is similar to Sim Cities, but it is in no way the same. It's hard to explain, there are a lot of similarities and differences at the same time so you'll have to see for yourself.It's a fun alternative to any other city building game because you have more control over the region and less people (WHO STILL HATE YOUR GUTS) to worry about.I have not played the DLC, but from what I know it adds more story to play which is probably the only part you'll touch so you'll enjoy that and more buildings if you liked the original.8/10Pros:- You get to be a dictator.- Resources are more prevalent and important than in other city building games.- Trading is a fun and important aspect of the game.- Sandbox is fun to play with infinite money.- Graphics are good, no texture popups, and generally polished all around.Cons:-  An oppressive government doesn't work, who knew.- Riots everywhere, not the good kind either, so much murder.- Combat is garbage.- No way to pre-plan your city.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Viva el presidente!So, lets address the elephant in the room. Yes, this is another city building game, a distant relative of Sim-u-know-what. Surfing thru the ages gives you a new challenge, particularly because you need to carefully reshape your city every now and then as the main campaign progresses. One of the issues I had at first is that the game forces you to jump between two islands, giving a false sense of “choosing”. You pick first knowing next to nothing about the resources available at the start, but then the game forces you to alternate between them making sometimes a really hard time, specially if you created a “military powerhouse” for some mission, and then pushed back to turn it into a “tourist heaven”.Having said that, whatever you are required to do, always think you may need to revisit your island, so make it as self-sustainable as possible. If you sacrifice population growth, happiness or food production for some short term objective, you may have a nightmare to deal with in the later episodes.Oh, the freaking military troops.. that is really annoying how they spread and head to the enemy's objectives instead of attacking the incoming troops.. man! How many battles lost because only a single troop faced 3 enemy squadrons while the other 4 where zipping mojitos at the gold mine or the farm “waiting” for the enemy to reach them. For the invasion times, try to built towers and army thingys close to the shore.Now for the good side:Loved the political puns, especially Penultimo quotes. Was kind weird hearing the same sentences once you're throw back in time and some technologies have to be “re-invented” though, if he is a time traveler as you are, why to repeat those? (ok ok, nitpicking here).The music is catchy and the visuals pretty good. Being able to see the little tropicans walking everywhere I zoomed in make me feel important lolI bought this on a Steam sale, and I'm really glad. If you like sim games, this one is a really good addition to your library.

Posted: February 28, 2015
												This game is a great game if you like creating a perfect utopian society where everyone is happy with you leading them.  It also compliments those who would rather take a different route with their country and make it a military powerhouse, industrial king, or even one of the best tourism supported countries to ever rise.  Personally I love being able to construct a simple city that can be self-sufficient and have a low crime presence.  This game does have something that I believe needs to be improved, and that would be the multiplayer because while playing with my friend on multiple occasions one of us would get disconnected and no matter how often we saved it seemed to not be able to restart from savepoint.  Other than the multiplayer I would highly suggest anyone who is a lover of strategy games and city build games to purchase this.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												I give Tropico 5 4.5 pairs of fancy El Presidente Brand Sunglasses out of 5. The other one got broke when El Presidente single handedly broke the noses of the Premier of the USSR and President of the USA with a swing of his beard. Seriously, this game gets a 4.5 out of 5. Another of the great series of city-building dictator sims that made me fall in love with city-building sims again in the first place and have a personality that makes it so few people can turn away after beginning to play with them, it delivers much of what it promises, but there's tarantulas in those crates of bananas. The first and foremost is that the voice acting has degraded, and things are less funny, than its predecessor Tropico 4. The storyline shares some mirrors to that game, ultimately, but is enjoyable despite this fact. The addition of tech research and a static continual build of your islands throughout the campaign (Which is something I greatly greatly missed in the Tropico 4 game, wishing it existed) provides a cohesive story and more believability, while keeping things humorous. Add in options like crafting your nation's constitution and it has plenty of playability, eve if your fun per minute might be lessened and ther's less commentary about your actions.Sandbox mode remains solid, especially with the addition of a random generator for islands. The multiplayer is a GREAT GREAT GREAT addition to the game, but that crate of bananas has a tarantula in it, too. What is that, you say? There is absolutely no save mode at all in it. So if you and your friends play 2 hours playing a multiplayer game? YOu'd better finish it because you won't be able to come back to it, you either have to devote a large chunk of time to it or play on small maps, in the end.Finally, there are plenty of bugs and glitches, even now, including things like the menu stuttering (at least 30 people including myself had this problem, which was because an intromovie playing in the background had horrible frame rate issues) but there are easy enough fixes of these until official fixes from Kalypso come forward.Over all? The game is a solid addition to the genre and the Tropico family. IT could have sailed higher, and it might still with DLC, but it's already far more enjoyable and far more playable for computers with lesser capabilities than its competitors in the city building genre, especially with very real trade, invasion, and competitive options in the multiplayer making an already deep game deeper.
