number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												I'll finally post my review of Tropico 5, sort of as my swan song to my long history with a game I've come back to countless times since it was released back in 2014. Back then I bought at full price, same for the two extensions (Waterborne and Espionage), and many of the DLCs (mostly to get my hands on new maps). I've not regretted a cent of that cumulative purchase price; it's come out to about $1 for 10 hours of pure play time. I spend $3 every day for my morning coffee, and about 6 bucks to throw a dart at a balloon at the county fair to win a pink elephant which I couldn't even convince my girlfriend to carry. If you niggle about a dollar or two more or less for this much value that you get with Tropico 5, there's something wrong with you. If you still haven't purchased it (either you've lived behind the moon or you just took up strategy gaming), it's so cheap now for what you get, just buy it. End of THAT discussion.I'm finally posting a review also to counter the many posts from the good people who love their Tropico 4, and post negative reviews on this board. It's a blessing and a curse for any creative to create something that is so strongly adopted by many. You may have followed the saga of the unfortunate Alden Ehrenreich, who Disney cast to be the young Han Solo in new episodes of the Star Wars franchise. Mr. Ehrenreich will not live another happy day on social media because the die hard, self appointed guardians of the Star Wars fantasy galaxy will rather have a septuagenarian Harrison Ford act out a young Han Solo than - heresy - a young and fairly unknown Mr. Ehrenreich. Something similar seems to be going on with Tropico 4 and now Tropico 5. Tropico 4 created a unique world that sucked people in, and with which they became so familiar that anything that breaks with tradition becomes a bridge too far for some. But to continue a successful franchise means sometimes having to take things into a new direction. Tropico 4 already got cluttered, and its graphics and tool tips and drop down menus betrayed its origin in the age of desktop computers running Win XP Pro with a middling graphics card. At a certain point, the economics of game development are inescapable: you have to be able to address a user base beyond your hard core niche players (who aren't getting any younger either), and open up to new systems (consoles). Firaxis did the jump with going to Civ 5 from Civ 4, and the reactions were similar. In the end, I've logged many, many hours on Civ 5, seen the modders base for that game grow exponentially and churn out awesome free mod products, and wonder with hindsight what the heck all the fuss was about in the first place. Same with Tropico 5. The devs had to break with some traditions, and what we got - and what you should get - is a game with beautiful graphics (don't buy this with a marginal graphics card, you want to run this on max resolution with all effects and all texturization turned on) and wonderful replayability.This is personal, and may not apply to you, but I found a few decisions the devs took unfortunate. For example, they lost me from ever playing their campaign again when they force you - warning: spoiler -  to switch islands right at the start. There's no rational reason, no macguffin brilliant enough to somehow explain that story-wise, so the devs didn't even try. They just send you on another island. That took me completely out of my little world they had me in, and I never touched their campaign again. You may also find that the wit of the base series is lacking from the DLCs, which veer into slapstick and - again for me personally - made them too silly for me to care. I did wholeheartedly adopt Sandbox mode, in which I think Tropico 5 truly shines. Again, it's a special beast: those who wish for a city builder a la the old Sim City franchise before EA inexplicably decided to drive that against the wall, or the more recent Cities:Skyline, will find Tropico 5 odd in some aspects. You have to put up with the silly story lines and some extreme abstraction in some aspects of gameplay. The amount of information available to El Presidente is also somewhat limited (but then, you can always just consult the T5 Wiki). But Tropico 5 has something that makes it addicting: personality. If I build a perfect city in a city builder, fine. Yawn, eventually. But with Tropico 5, I found I can build cities, like real cities. With slums. Traffic jams. Political shenanigans and NIMBYs you just can NOT get along with. And you know what? You won't have to. Just have them come out on the street, then roll over them with your tank. And after the mayham of another revolution put down, sit back in your presidential lawn chair on your presidential lawn with your presidentially strong pina colada in hand, and look from atop high out over your sprawling, smelling, living, breathing, but strangely beautiful city, and take in that gorgeous sunset painting the sky behind all those houses in the most magnificant colors any citybuilder will give you. That's Tropico 5 to me, and that's what made all those hours I played it time well spent.

												I've only played Tropico 3 on the Xbox (briefly) and have extensively played Tropico 4, but Tropico 5 takes the cake for me. content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Tropico 5 (Review from a guy that'd never played it ever)TL;DR Version. 7/10 Its good, like addictively good but the tutorials are sub par and barely teach you a damn thing. Elaberation; Its good don't get me wrong but it does lack some real sort of direction. First age "Get Independence." Okay, well I got that. "Good job now your economy completely changes!" Wonderful, lost in my own fish bowl and in the middle of a world war. Alright, I can deal with that. "Oh by the way, Rebels want to raid your Sh*t. Good luck with that." Okay, not bad but- "Hold on there, don't forget about your elections!." Oh yeah! Nice not bad. "Okay age over time to make peace with the axis and allies! Even if you were not at war and they both like you F*CK IT, make peace of stay there." Right.. and I'm assumeing if I tell them to shove it up their respective bums I can expect invasion. At this point things are getting a little strange but hey lets advance. "Welcome to the cold war! Now, get your economy working and move forward." Alright, well I expected worse but I get it now. At this point I looked up a tutorial on how the hell the economy works. With about an hour of researched I got it down and now I'm not having to much trouble. Again its a good game but the fact that the tutorials teach you 10% of everything is a little trashy. They are not called "Tutorials" for nothing.If you need a break from Sim city or Skylines, its a good buy. However the extensive DLC for the game. (DLC which is little things for 4$ each.. Seriously?) Seems interesting but I personally will not waste my money on the DLC unless its offered as a good priced bundle.7/10 Decent Buy. I'd recomend it. LONG LIVE TROPICO

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Tropico 5 is a welcome sequel to a great series. Many fans were underwhelmed by Tropico 4. While the game was solid it did little to innovate on Tropico 3 and its expansions. Tropico 5 took notes, and now offers a very different gameplay experience.The biggest changes are the multitude of little tweaks, such as how farms work, a new research system, new specialist system, the dynasty mechanics and a dozen other little things that overhaul the game hugely. Each is well implemented with the level of detail and balance we've come to expect from the series.The new time based campaigns are also something that Tropico players have talked about for a long term- persistent islands. Traditionally each level in Tropico is its own map, but no longer. You have only two islands in this game, and you develop them through the campaign. This requires much more foresight and planning and led to me needing to restart the campaign twice because I didn't think far enough ahead. I thoroughly enjoyed overcoming this great new challenge.If you've never played Tropico I'd suggest starting with 3 or 4. 5 is a very different game but it maintains the tone, feel and gameplay shape of its predecessors. As such you can spend a little less seeing if you like the style before you commit to spending more on the recent title.If you know Tropico and love it, then you'll love Tropico 5. Faithful, but not afraid to break new ground. And they break it with extreme competence and authority.

Posted: May 11, 2016
												Tropico 5 is just not as good as Tropico 4. Now I wouldn't say that makes it a bad game, but it does mean that I can't seem to judge it on it's own merits because the other games in the series are there to remind you what it should have been. Your building options are a lot more limited (because of the eras) so it feels a lot less open and free, it hardly feels like you are building your island as much as being told to build someone else's island. You can make the choices, but there aren't really that many to make. It has some nice new ideas, but they are executed in clumsy and simplistic ways that take away from the gameplay rather than adding to it.And Tropico 4 is cheaper too.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												This is the first Tropico game I've played.  The concept is cool and really refreshing.  It has a great level of detail and the there is so much depth to this game (actually, almost too much).  It has a lot of potential to be fun, but there area few problems that took away my recommendation.As a newbie, I don't know what I'm doing.  If it weren't for SimCity, I'd be completely lost (and yes, I tried the tutorial).  I play on all medium difficulty settings and I'm finding myself struggling to get an approval rating above 50%.  I give the people everything I can give them and yet they're still unhappy.  Many of them claim to be bored, but I can't build anything except taverns.  They whine about how boring the house is, but all I can build are country houses and mansions (and I'm not buying a mansion for a farmer).  So you could say "why not lower the difficulty?" but then the game becomes boring.  I want a challenge, not an impossibility.  When you rely on approval ratings and the people hate you for reasons outside of your control, that's not fun.  You could say "so just become a dictator" but that defeats the purpose of having a choice in the way you play.The game is also a little overwhelming when it comes to management.  Just too much stuff that no president/governor actually does.  They might be cool features to some degree and they could be why I failed the first level, but it's just a little too much to juggle.  It'd be nice if it were more similar to SimCity, where you just zone areas and have the people figure things themselves.  I see no problem with having the *option* to intervene, but this game *requires* it, and I consider that more tedious than fun.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												I would recommend this game BUT, and that's a big but!!! The game has a lot of future potential. Meaning the content and overall design of the game is outstanding. However, it is lacking in some key aspects.One of the biggest issues in Tropico 5 is bugs, this alone would have been fine and I'd still recommend the game even with the bugs. It is the second big issue that is the problem on top of the bugs namely that there are some important design oversights in the game.It is mostly in little things, here one little thing and there one little thing. All these little things really add up though to cause a great deal of loss to personal enjoyment of the game. Combine these little design oversights with the bugs in the game and you have yourself a recipe for a day of fun gaming - ruined!For example, if you play on Sandbox mode with all difficulties set to medium and give yourself unlimited money. You’d think with this unlimited money you could make the so-called perfect island, this however is simply not yet possible in Tropico 5 due to a combination of design flaws and game bugs.Firstly, unlimited money is not really unlimited, meaning there will be many times in the game that certain things will say you do not have enough money for it! Wow, well lot of good unlimited money setting did me!Then there are the design flaws, as you play in sandbox mode with unlimited money (and same issue exists on normal modes), your city naturally will grow to become quite large and fill the entire island. The game simply has no good management tools to manage such a sheer number of different buildings. This task is made harder by the game’s bugs. For example if you set “all buildings” to the same budget level. This only sets the current buildings of that exact type. Meaning you still have to set it for each different farm that farms a different crop. It also means when you build new buildings they all start at the default budget regardless.Secondly, you have the design flaws in both the UI and the actual game mechanics hampering your play. Some buildings allow you to upgrade all to the new version. However, not all buildings offer this functionality oddly enough. It is as if the developers were not working in a team and one developer thought, hey! I’ll add this feature. But no one else knew about it on the development team. Thus only the buildings that one developer designed has those functions. Then the small upgrades completely lack them. If you have 20 buildings to upgrade, well you gonna have to click 20 freaking buildings individually! Crazy right!If this wasn’t bad enough, the game mechanics are pretty messed up. I gave my citizens all the rights in the world, built them all the stuff they wanted. But apparently 20 Cathedrals on a small Island just is not enough to satisfy religious needs... what??? To add more insult to injury, I made everyone on my Island filthy rich, gave them all the best entertainment, luxuries, environment, everything possible within the game and STILL I had rebels by the dozens, I had 100s of citizens leaving my Island. I just don’t get it, I had so many empty jobs and as soon as I’d hire foreign nationals they’d leave in a heartbeat despite having all their needs fulfilled to the maximum and happiness ratings in the 90 range on all elements except religion (due to the above issue).As a result this really has discouraged me from playing. I love challenging games, but I hate it when a game is challenging not due to design, but due to design flaws and more importantly, game breaking bugs and issues.And it is a real shame, as there is so much potential for enjoyment to be had in this title. Multiplayer modes (full of issues still though), great single-player content, a wide array of different buildings and technologies. But yet it is all lost due to the game bugs and design flaws.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Ok first Tropico game I bought so no expectations going in. Neat game. But.....I was completely confused on what the point was. I thought I would play through the game on one island, build it, maintain it and go through the eras. Instead its like jumping through hoops, jumping to different islands but with similia goals. I wanted to finish my island from start to the end. SO after finding that out, Chapter 1 complete, removed from PC. I understand there is a Sandbox to build how you want but there is no end to Sandbox. I dont want to give myself goals to play the game. I liked it up to the point when I won my indpendence, but jumping from different islands for the story purposes and carrying out pre-made checkpoints to then jump to another island just did not suite my taste. Read other reviews on IGN, Gamespot, Gametrailers and you will get a taste of what I am talking about if I was not clear. Recommend only when on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												It looked promising at first, which is why I was one of the many people that pre-ordered the game. I regret it since I only played literally a few hours before I realized I was playing the same exact game but cut down  in content. The new features WERE a fresh breath of life into the series but to see them spam out DLC that is not worth the asking price only makes me feel even more regretful of my purchase. I never asked for a refund due to the fact it was my fault to begin with for pre-ordering the game and I had false hopes that they would atleast fix up the game and give out free content for a short while where things were missing, since it was obviously missing most of the content that they are now ramming out in DLC. Note to self: Never pre-order a game again. First and last time I'm doing it.Note to Kalypso: The current PR you are going with is only making you lose more and more customers that were once loyal to you. Once you lose your oiginal fanbase, you only start to see a decline in future sales. Yes you get a quick return in money spent on developing the game, but in the long run you hurt your future sales to make any profit. Note to future customers: Don't buy the DLC until its on sale for half price or 75% off. Otherwise they will continue with this greedy cash grab. It's just not worth the asking price considering a modder could dish out more content for FREE.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Noticed this was "free" in my Steam list for 24 hours so played 9 straight hours of sandbox mode, which is essentially a cheat mode, and the tutorial. Verdict? Imagine communist-based jingoistic Sim City with some very forced "humour" and you've pretty much got Tropico 5.You can really see how this game tries to ape a simpler Sim City but like most clones misses some of the subtler part of the game play. For example while the game would love to push random, sometimes nonsensical tasks like "Place Llama farms next to Waste treatment farms" in your face, it fails to instruct or inform you until it's too late that you population is dieing due to lack of food; an interesting game mechcanic it would have been nice to know even existed fairly early on in the game!

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												Good game with good graphics and humor. Special appreciation for a good music theme, and good sound quality without interruptions.A bad thing is a mouse rotation in game, which was made poorly - its jumping tilting manner make whole gameplay experience less enjoyable. Developers/publishers better release a patch to fix it.Another questionable thing is loader which is looking just like cheap blocking screen virus.And you can't expand ingame music stream with your own mp3 playlist.And yet, after weighting good and bad, i'd prefer a good side. I enjoy playing this game. I'd recommend it if asked. :-)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												This game is fun but quite limited.  I managed to squeeze some time out of it, but overall it gets monotonous quite quickly.  The gimick of you playing as a dictator start of rather funny but, the humour slowly becomes cute before descending into repetitive and annoying.  The ceilling of what you can build and advance to felt far too low and also quite restrictive.  The choices you may make, again while funny initially, don't seem to do all too much outside of changing some numbers.  It's a weak city building/management game wrapped in gimicks.  While I did have fun, I cannot reccomend it on account of how incomplete this game felt.+Fun for a bit-Not worth the money-Low ceiling for progress and creativity in the game-GimickyI cannot say the experience was bad, i did not dislike playing it by any means.  Rather, it was lackluster across all facets of gameplay.

content:

												Had only 8 dollars and tropico 5 is on sale , hmmm hey friends what do you think? should i buy it or i would just let em for maybe an other offer i may like more? dude go ahead and watch some videos and then make a decision *1hour later* >alright am going to buy it i hope it could get me for 10hours at least *installed it* start the game , make my caracter , look to the graphics *woah* this look amazing *said* i will try it just a bit then tomorrow i will play it , hmmm 2 hours passed its okay just a bit more , its already morning and 5 hours done in game*tomorrow wake up* time for more tropico 5 and yeah find myself now at 11.6 hours and i feel like am going for 50hours or even morewhat i like about it? 1. pretty lovely graphics and details too good for a strategy game2. challenging economy and election 3. have to explore the whole map looking for important resources like gold , oil , uranium 4. makes you feel like a real leader , looking after your homeless civs and assuring their happiness and health care5. trades are pretty complicated and deep6. farming , you need to pick nice places and give  them good saleries so you can assure some good profit 7. develop and advance , high building , electrecity and uranium and more( still didn't reach everything yet )should you buy it? yeah i absolutely advice you , this game will make you feel peacefull , no stress and oblige you to thinkMultiplayer 1. best MP real time building side to side ( not like cimsity each one on his own island )

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												Probably THE Best Game I have on Steam. It's sooooo much fun! You basically go to an island and try to make a civilization out of it. You can make it the island whatever you want. But if you start in the Colonial Era you want to get out of that era quickly (or don't go in the Colonial Era at all) because you are in the hands of The Crown and you depend on missions to extend mandate, and if your missions end, or if you don't get a mission in time, you lose the game. But the World Wars Era is different, you depend on elections. This game is soo much fun and I recommend this!

content:
Posted: February 10
												A worthy addition to the series. Being able to advance through ages as a very interesting mechanic, and revisiting your older islands and building atop them in new eras adds some awesome strategic depth to gameplay.Unfortunately the DLC missions (apart from the big expansion packs) are not as satisfying because they don't use the 'through the ages - replay the islands' mechanic - and so are not very interesting. Still, I bought this as the huge 'GOTY' pack though, so its nice to have everything, and I guess I used some of the DLC buildings in other missions.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I'm new to the Tropico series and haven't played any previous installments so I'm not sure how this game compares to other Tropico games but for the most part I've had an awesome time playing it. It has a lot more depth than other city-building strategy games by adding the political dynasty element. The mechanics are easy to get used to and the design, concept, and writing all really augment the experience. The tutorial doesn't give you enough info to really play the game. I spent a lot of game confused about why my happiness was high but my approval low or why approval was high but civil unrest was growing. In that regard a lot of the details of the gameplay fall a little flat. That aside the problem solving political aspect is at least enjoyable if nothing else. Whyever revolutions keep continually popping up on my island dealing with them is always an exciting element. Though it stagnates a lot and could use some better tutorials overall I forsee myself spending many more hours in this game. (A side note: I got it on sale for 10 bucks so this review is entirely contingent on I didn't drop a lot of money on this game. 10-20 dollars is exactly the amount I think this game shoudl retail for. 40 dollars for this game, in the state it's in, seems excessive. )

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												I was expecting a light-hearted city-building sim, and I got that for the most part.  But the game isn't at all pleasing to play in the long term due to issues with the UI and hidden mechanics which aren't easily understood except by lengthy trial and error.[PRO] * Light-hearted military dictatorship game, with really cheesy and surprisingly dated humor.  (How long was this game in development?  Simpsons quotes from twenty years ago!)[PRO] * Fairly simple building UI.  Drawing roads is annoyingly finicky, though.[PRO] * Initially looks like it is really simple game but does have some depth when you scratch the surface.[PRO] * Production values are quite good for this style of game.  Graphics are fine, voice-overs are fine, sound and effects are fine.  It's no Sim City 5 but I would say it's on par with an older Maxis game, like SC4.----[CON] * HEY.  HEY.  HEY, LISTEN.  Your advisors will be popping up constantly, interrupting you.  New build requests, new edict requests, new declarations, etc.  I can't count the number of times I was about to change some micro-managed setting only to have everything backed out when the dialog opens.[CON] * Combat is lame and poorly executed.  You either typically pwn the enemy or get rolled over, and it's never entirely clear why.  I've also seen a tank squad try to drive to the other side of the map by its lonesome self, because an intended target was some far-off mine, but the enemy was halted by guard towers along the way.  (Meanwhile, said tower gets destroyed because my tanks are out sight-seeing.)[CON] * Poorly thought out era system.  Some buildings are era specific, in particular military buildings.  There's no way to upgrade or change them so they are useful for newer eras.  Eras also feel like artifical limitations on what the player can build or do, in order to lengthen the game.  (It's frustating to have severe crime problems in colonial era that you can't do anything about until the World Wars, when you are allowed to build a police station.)[CON] * A lot of the game mechanics are hidden from you and not exposed in the UI.  There are stats that I wish I could see in the Almanac or graph that are not visible -- Which is frustrating when you see the data (and graphs) exposed for other things.  The devs already had code for making pretty drill-down nested lists and graphs, why couldn't they use it everywhere?  Another example:  Buildings give certain bonuses and modify other sim values (such as a water treatment plant reducing pollution), but the game doesn't give you visual feedback for how far these bonuses/modifications reach, leading to expensive trial and error city layouts.[CON] * Obtuse gameplay elements.  For example: Factions become very important in later eras, but it requires that you click an unmarked, hidden label on your Politics screen of the almanac to get information about factions.  Even so, the information is obtuse.  You know a faction hates you but the game does not make it clear how to please said faction.  Generally you can use common sense (ie: communists want more free social services, militarists want more guns to play with, etc) but when it comes to constitutions and edicts, this isn't always clear.  Lots of trial and error are required, and the game doesn't let you experiment easily.  For example, you can only change your constitution infrequently, so you are stuck with a bad decision for several in-game years.[CON] * Disasters are random.  I wouldn't mind a tornado or volanco eruption to spice up the game where there has been a lengthy period of inactivity, but when I am under attack from a foreign power, my treasury is bankrupt and civil rest is high -- And then the game tosses in a natura disaster?  At the same time?  I just feel like I am being kicked in the teeth by a random number generator.[CON] * Dynasty system is initially neat, but then you realize you utilize your family members for simple building managers (or, later, building new empires).  I find myself just skipping past all the customization stuff since I'll never see these people outside of a random event face icon or a generic indicator in a building info panel.[CON] * Single player campaign is a mess.  What the game does not explain early on is that you have two islands, and the campaign missions take place over either of the two islands.  (Sometimes you can choose what island, otherwise the island choice is fixed.)  You retain your buildings and your empire setup between missions.  It is INCREDIBLY easy to screw yourself over in later campaign missions by having a "thrown together" or imbalanced empire.  ie: You build just what you need to complete a mission scenerio.  On the next mission, your prior choices might be detrimental and you might find yourself in sudden and unexpected debt, as task bonuses (which were given in prior missions) are removed.  Playing the campaign requires foresight and understanding of late-game mechanics, which is a bit too much to ask of new players.In conclusion:  I would pass.  I hear Tropico 4 is a better game, but I suppose that will have to wait for my Tropico 4 review...

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												I wanted to like this game, I really did. I have bought all of them and really had high hopes for this iteration. It fell way short of expectations for reasons listed in many of the reviews below. Horrid pathfinding, numerous bugs, and an entirely dumbed down interface that lacks all the detail of older versions. The game feels watered down, even from 4. DLC was disappointing too, not nearly as useful as it could have been.It does have it's good points, but it loses out to clunky controls and losing so many good pieces of interface since the last iterations of the game. I miss so many pieces of the old overlay and almanac, it makes me long for the days of the original Tropico when Kalypso had it's integrity. It could have been good if it had been finished, but it's just another game pushed to an unfinished early release now nickel-and-diming it's customers.I hate to say give this one a pass, but i have to. The older games are just so much better compared to this.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												It looked promising at first, which is why I was one of the many people that pre-ordered the game. I regret it since I only played literally a few hours before I realized I was playing the same exact game but cut down  in content. The new features WERE a fresh breath of life into the series but to see them spam out DLC that is not worth the asking price only makes me feel even more regretful of my purchase. I never asked for a refund due to the fact it was my fault to begin with for pre-ordering the game and I had false hopes that they would atleast fix up the game and give out free content for a short while where things were missing, since it was obviously missing most of the content that they are now ramming out in DLC. Note to self: Never pre-order a game again. First and last time I'm doing it.Note to Kalypso: The current PR you are going with is only making you lose more and more customers that were once loyal to you. Once you lose your oiginal fanbase, you only start to see a decline in future sales. Yes you get a quick return in money spent on developing the game, but in the long run you hurt your future sales to make any profit. Note to future customers: Don't buy the DLC until its on sale for half price or 75% off. Otherwise they will continue with this greedy cash grab. It's just not worth the asking price considering a modder could dish out more content for FREE.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												You are the president of a tropical island, you build, manage and raise your Tropico to become the ultimate Tropico. Tropico is a game that requires you to think before you act, to use all of the opportunities to your benefit. The people of Tropico must love you, your resources and trade must provide for you and your people and importantly you must complete any challange that comes your way whether it be joining the Axis side in World War 2 or claiming independence. The game is great fun along with a great challange. You must deal with the uprise of rebels, natural disasters and even world wide issues such as the World War and the Cold War. You get tasks randomly, demanding things that will make your people happy. Sometimes you are required to build a school, a library, raw resource industry. Even required to make the Crown happy until you claim independence. So the gameplay is smooth, challanging and interesting in what makes your people happy. Every game you start won't be the same. The mechanics are stable, I have never experienced a crash. For now, I am playing on a low end PC and it is still very VERY stable. The gameplay is all good fun, you have complete freedom as to what to do. Build a school, build a military barracks, concentrate on education or military or industry. You get to choose what industry you dominate, choose what you people get, what your constitution includes, what benefits your people get, what your government concentrates on. You can even click on your citizens, and they tell you everything good and everything bad about your Tropico. You can even patrol the streets yourself and find rebels, crime lords, rebel leaders. The game is always different, you start a new game and you will always have new problems and new tasks.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												I approached this game, two years after release, with playing Tropico 4 in my mind.It's a whole different game, literally and gameplay wise.You are not playing as one immortal dictators, you're playing as one of many immoral dictators coming from a dinasty. You are not passively importing and exporting stuffs, you are actively seeking import-export markets.You are not going to ignore world powers, you are playing with and being played by them.And you are not going to get your buildings automatically in time, you need to do researches.And those researches are divided by historical eras.And fishes, fishes deplete. And no longer you will have endless gold mines, you will need to import.It's a whole new game, with its up and down compared to Tropico 4. My heart is still with Tropico 4 though, but Tropico 5 is still a good experience.Especially with jet fighters flattening the rebels. Fun!

Posted: August 8, 2014
												Ok first Tropico game I bought so no expectations going in. Neat game. But.....I was completely confused on what the point was. I thought I would play through the game on one island, build it, maintain it and go through the eras. Instead its like jumping through hoops, jumping to different islands but with similia goals. I wanted to finish my island from start to the end. SO after finding that out, Chapter 1 complete, removed from PC. I understand there is a Sandbox to build how you want but there is no end to Sandbox. I dont want to give myself goals to play the game. I liked it up to the point when I won my indpendence, but jumping from different islands for the story purposes and carrying out pre-made checkpoints to then jump to another island just did not suite my taste. Read other reviews on IGN, Gamespot, Gametrailers and you will get a taste of what I am talking about if I was not clear. Recommend only when on sale.

												Tropico 5 is broken. That's the bottomline. Have you played Tropico 4? Well imagine if they sawed Tropico 4 in half, and then improved the graphics. That's it. Half the content of 4, despite having tons of unneccessary and greedy DLCs in which you usually get about 1 building and maybe 1 outfit. You get hardly any variety in buildings, hardly ANY overlays, so you'd be hard pressed to understand what's going on at any given time. Okay food satisfaction is low, why is that? I have a ton of farms, I have places distributing food, WHAT IS THE PROBLEM? Do I need yet more farms, more workers, more markets? No idea, just guess work. In 4, and in fact in every previous itteration of the game EXCEPT FOR 5, you had overlays for pretty much everything, not so in 5. Oh and good look finding a building and seeing at a glance what buildings you've already built, what areas are serviced with what etc. Unless you're looking for one of the many gaudy eyesores that don't fit in anywhere on your island, like the circus tent, one of the extremely few available entertainment buildings.Compared to 4, you get almost no chance of influencing the elections or the people in any way aside from what you build and the edicts. If you go into an election with less than 50-55% approval rating, you're going to lose. Penultimo as always asks if you want to "rig" the election, only in 5, he's hopelessly incompetent because he gives you so few extra votes that you won't win unless you were going to anyways or were balancing on a razorblade. Yeah, some dictator simulator.In 4 you got the option of making a speech, giving promises, it was a great way to keep your head above water, you appealed to the largest group of voters and if you held your promise, great! In 5, you don't even have a faction overlay or anything resembling it anymore. There are factions, and they are discontent, but you don't know how many there are of each, what they want etc. And there are no election speeches, basically it goes like this; Election time, have you satisfied most of all our needs beforehand despite struggling with money and gotten 50-55% Approval? Great, click election, keep improving and HOPE you´ll win. No? Okay, click no election, get instant mobs with 8000hp crushing your puny millitary and bringing down your palace. Or click yes for election and lose anyways. Not even in the very first Tropico did this system function so very poorly!So on islands with rebel threat and unrest, you stand no chance. No really, you don't. You need millitary buildings to fend off rebels, but those take up valuable highschool workers you could be using for factories and services. What's worse, despite having millitary, despite having all the upgrades and beefing up, the millitary doesn't stand a chance against a simple mob of people. A millitary unit has about 3500hp, a mob has 8000hp! You can build tanks in Tropico 5, the mobs kill them WITH EASE.Oh and get this, thanks to the newest feature, the Dynasties (which is a useless feature much poorer than the ones in 4), you get to revisit your previous islands for each new time period during the campaign. Hey great, no longer do I need to start from scratch with every new mission! Yeaaaah, there is that, BUT you also need to make sure your island is tip-top, because when you re-visit with a harder mission, you're gonna have a much harder time. And that would sound fair, if it wasn't for everything I've already mentioned, so basically if you struggle early, your whole campaign might go down the toilet, and you won't know it until several missions later.Tropico 5, is broken. Play Tropico 4 instead.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												I was expecting a light-hearted city-building sim, and I got that for the most part.  But the game isn't at all pleasing to play in the long term due to issues with the UI and hidden mechanics which aren't easily understood except by lengthy trial and error.[PRO] * Light-hearted military dictatorship game, with really cheesy and surprisingly dated humor.  (How long was this game in development?  Simpsons quotes from twenty years ago!)[PRO] * Fairly simple building UI.  Drawing roads is annoyingly finicky, though.[PRO] * Initially looks like it is really simple game but does have some depth when you scratch the surface.[PRO] * Production values are quite good for this style of game.  Graphics are fine, voice-overs are fine, sound and effects are fine.  It's no Sim City 5 but I would say it's on par with an older Maxis game, like SC4.----[CON] * HEY.  HEY.  HEY, LISTEN.  Your advisors will be popping up constantly, interrupting you.  New build requests, new edict requests, new declarations, etc.  I can't count the number of times I was about to change some micro-managed setting only to have everything backed out when the dialog opens.[CON] * Combat is lame and poorly executed.  You either typically pwn the enemy or get rolled over, and it's never entirely clear why.  I've also seen a tank squad try to drive to the other side of the map by its lonesome self, because an intended target was some far-off mine, but the enemy was halted by guard towers along the way.  (Meanwhile, said tower gets destroyed because my tanks are out sight-seeing.)[CON] * Poorly thought out era system.  Some buildings are era specific, in particular military buildings.  There's no way to upgrade or change them so they are useful for newer eras.  Eras also feel like artifical limitations on what the player can build or do, in order to lengthen the game.  (It's frustating to have severe crime problems in colonial era that you can't do anything about until the World Wars, when you are allowed to build a police station.)[CON] * A lot of the game mechanics are hidden from you and not exposed in the UI.  There are stats that I wish I could see in the Almanac or graph that are not visible -- Which is frustrating when you see the data (and graphs) exposed for other things.  The devs already had code for making pretty drill-down nested lists and graphs, why couldn't they use it everywhere?  Another example:  Buildings give certain bonuses and modify other sim values (such as a water treatment plant reducing pollution), but the game doesn't give you visual feedback for how far these bonuses/modifications reach, leading to expensive trial and error city layouts.[CON] * Obtuse gameplay elements.  For example: Factions become very important in later eras, but it requires that you click an unmarked, hidden label on your Politics screen of the almanac to get information about factions.  Even so, the information is obtuse.  You know a faction hates you but the game does not make it clear how to please said faction.  Generally you can use common sense (ie: communists want more free social services, militarists want more guns to play with, etc) but when it comes to constitutions and edicts, this isn't always clear.  Lots of trial and error are required, and the game doesn't let you experiment easily.  For example, you can only change your constitution infrequently, so you are stuck with a bad decision for several in-game years.[CON] * Disasters are random.  I wouldn't mind a tornado or volanco eruption to spice up the game where there has been a lengthy period of inactivity, but when I am under attack from a foreign power, my treasury is bankrupt and civil rest is high -- And then the game tosses in a natura disaster?  At the same time?  I just feel like I am being kicked in the teeth by a random number generator.[CON] * Dynasty system is initially neat, but then you realize you utilize your family members for simple building managers (or, later, building new empires).  I find myself just skipping past all the customization stuff since I'll never see these people outside of a random event face icon or a generic indicator in a building info panel.[CON] * Single player campaign is a mess.  What the game does not explain early on is that you have two islands, and the campaign missions take place over either of the two islands.  (Sometimes you can choose what island, otherwise the island choice is fixed.)  You retain your buildings and your empire setup between missions.  It is INCREDIBLY easy to screw yourself over in later campaign missions by having a "thrown together" or imbalanced empire.  ie: You build just what you need to complete a mission scenerio.  On the next mission, your prior choices might be detrimental and you might find yourself in sudden and unexpected debt, as task bonuses (which were given in prior missions) are removed.  Playing the campaign requires foresight and understanding of late-game mechanics, which is a bit too much to ask of new players.In conclusion:  I would pass.  I hear Tropico 4 is a better game, but I suppose that will have to wait for my Tropico 4 review...

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I'm new to the Tropico series and haven't played any previous installments so I'm not sure how this game compares to other Tropico games but for the most part I've had an awesome time playing it. It has a lot more depth than other city-building strategy games by adding the political dynasty element. The mechanics are easy to get used to and the design, concept, and writing all really augment the experience. The tutorial doesn't give you enough info to really play the game. I spent a lot of game confused about why my happiness was high but my approval low or why approval was high but civil unrest was growing. In that regard a lot of the details of the gameplay fall a little flat. That aside the problem solving political aspect is at least enjoyable if nothing else. Whyever revolutions keep continually popping up on my island dealing with them is always an exciting element. Though it stagnates a lot and could use some better tutorials overall I forsee myself spending many more hours in this game. (A side note: I got it on sale for 10 bucks so this review is entirely contingent on I didn't drop a lot of money on this game. 10-20 dollars is exactly the amount I think this game shoudl retail for. 40 dollars for this game, in the state it's in, seems excessive. )

content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Tropico, a gem of a series -- witty, fun, engaging, well-made, great music and characters, and just a real pleasure to play. And each edition better than the last, with Tropico 4 being a polished diamond.Then along came Tropico 5. Tedious gameplay, badly voiced characters, pointless scripting, and truly horrible, oversaturated graphics -- which once were one of the game's simple delights, as you crawled into the teeming, detailed maps or plopped rows of palm trees and gardens while waiting for the trading ship to dock. (If you don't know the series, grab and play 3 & 4, you won't be disappointed.)I don't think anyone who created the series is still left at the developer to give this game the guiding vision and TLC it deserves, and this release shows the series has entirely lost its way. RIP, Tropico, you were great while you lasted. Truly a shame.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												I am a latecomer to kalypso's Tropico titles, so my perspective is that of someone who isn't all too experienced with city-builders in general. Keep that in mind.I always read reviews before I buy stuff, and the majority for this game said to buy Tropico 4 instead. So, that's what I did. I bought tropico 4 and played quite a bit, and then I bought tropico 5, and I've played them within days of each other.I think Tropico 5 is the better game. The graphics upgrade is... substantial. I don't know if people say to play Tropico 4 instead because they've been long time followers of the game and weren't impressed with the new mechanics or what, but Tropico 4 is just too easy. Time consuming, but easy. Tropico 5 is hard. Much, much more challenging than Tropico 4, and it adds in some new elements and removes others. The "Faction" system seems to take less of a precedence, and foreign politics and a trade system seemed to have taken it's place. The trade system, the rebel system, the edicts, and the constitution all make Tropico 5 the more challenging and worthwhile title, in my opinion.Now, don't get me wrong, I didn't dislike Tropico 4 even when compared to Tropico 5. I've played more hours of Tropico 4 to date, but I believe I'll play more Tropico 5 in the long run because it's just kicking my♥♥♥♥♥even on low difficulty. That's why I reccomend Tropico 5 over 4.The DLC mess the company does I won't comment on, because it doesn't effect me negatively too much especially since the game was on sale and I definitely feel like I got my moneys worth. But if you have a problem with the DLC scheme, I'd just go with another game. :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Tropico, a gem of a series -- witty, fun, engaging, well-made, great music and characters, and just a real pleasure to play. And each edition better than the last, with Tropico 4 being a polished diamond.Then along came Tropico 5. Tedious gameplay, badly voiced characters, pointless scripting, and truly horrible, oversaturated graphics -- which once were one of the game's simple delights, as you crawled into the teeming, detailed maps or plopped rows of palm trees and gardens while waiting for the trading ship to dock. (If you don't know the series, grab and play 3 & 4, you won't be disappointed.)I don't think anyone who created the series is still left at the developer to give this game the guiding vision and TLC it deserves, and this release shows the series has entirely lost its way. RIP, Tropico, you were great while you lasted. Truly a shame.

												Livid at this game. I have played every tropico before this one. Been a fan since the beginning. But now I'm stuck on this Nucleur program campaign. I have played it at least 10 times. You have to build up a bunch of research facilities to be able to build the nucleur program. So I did that, it's almost impossible because there are constant rebel attacks, tsunami's, earthquakes and the people trying to throw you out of office that when I finally learned the technology I was so happy. Only to find out now it costs 30k to build!!! What the hell! So this mission is almost impossible and the autosave keeps saving over my last saves and making me redo everything back from the very beginning. IF they allowed cheating, I know that sounds terrible, I could at least get through this ridiculous game ending mission. I AM DONE WITH THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												If you enjoyed Tropico 3 or 4 - don't get this. It's a watered-down knock-off.In most respects, this is a simplified version of Tropico 4, with fewer options and less customisation. The few additions, most notably the eras system, don't really add anything to the game except arbitrary limits on development at various stages, effectively capping your happiness and increasing the risk of rebellion.The game has a far higher emphasis on combat then previous Tropicos, both versus rebels and foreign invasions, but it retains the autonomous nature of your army - you can't issue orders, so you get to spend a great deal of time watching your island get overrun while powerless to do anything about it.Tropico 4 had very weak low-budget graphics - just compare it to other games of around the same age like Anno 2070 and it's clear they're not playing in the same league. Tropico 5 adds higher system requirements in exchange for a very marginal improvement: it's still far worse looking than games released several years ago, but a marginal improvement is at least an improvement. In contrast, the music and the voice acting are markedly inferior to Tropico 3 and 4.And then there are the bugs. Like Professional Army actually *reducing* your army's effectiveness, or mission 2 of the campaign not actually loading without a workaround. Put alongside the frustrating and unenjoyable gameplay versus previous game in the series, I somewhat suspect this game hasn't received any playtesting outside of the development team.Pretty much the only good point I can come up with is the humour - there are some good jokes and references in there, very much like the previous games.Overall, this feels like a small low-budget indie release that's inexplicably sold at AAA prices. In a few months when the worst of the bugs are fixed and there's a slew of DLC re-adding features deliberately removed, then it *might* be worth picking up if it goes to 75% off or more. Otherwise: avoid.

Posted: December 22, 2016
												Do you like Tropico? This is more Tropico. I'd say it's worth $15-20, all DLC included. The campaign is not great, but the overall island-building economy simulator deal is still there, still fun. Tropico is very much an acquired taste, and whether or not you liked the previous versions will likely dictate whether you enjoy this one.It's not Simcity, and it's not Skyline. It's simpler, and narrower in scope, and at certain very specific things, better at what it does. Worth it if you ever wanted your own Banana Republic.

Posted: July 17, 2016
												Tropico 5 is fun or at least I agree to the Discounted price. it was a steal. I love both Tropico 4 and 5. but there is a huge difference between the 2. game system has change. it has some flaws but it has some good.So here is the change.1. no more blue prints, you now need to reaserch to unlock advance buildings and Edicts.2. if you are playing in colonial era, maps are unexplore. until you research Drydocks/compass in the next Era.3. Easier to recruit soldiers as you don't need generals. and soldiers are uneducated by default.4. you will need military to survive rebels and invasion. but they are cheap to maintain. so build a lot of gaurd tower around your castle.5. salary increase is repalce with budget. you can increase building budget. which I recommend you do this to all NON-residential buildings.6.  trait customization is removed and replace with dynasty. this is a flaw. I prefer Trop4 Trait customization. they add depts to gameplay.7. Trading are change... there is so much to discuss here.. but I'm lazy to tell you. so my rating is.   8/10  get this on discount.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												update: yeah so found 2 GIANT flaws with the game, export ships have limited cpacity unlike previous games, so every time by the time you hit the modern area youll go into an unending debt because ships are taking industry items and no more raw materials netting you -$$.  second major problem is teamsters dont work proberly at all. not sure what they did to them from trop 4 but in that one, theyd choose industry buildings first and docks last, so if you have tobacco itd always go to the cigar factory (if you had one) then to the dock to make you more money. now in tropico 5 they just dump it randomly between the factory and the dock making the first flaw very very very apparent. another way teamsters suck is that they will rarely grab imports, they mostly leave them in the dock and eventually they clog up the dock like in the first flaw.  THIS NEEDS TO BE FIXED, MAKE SHIPS HAVE UNLIMITED CAPACITY PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE THIS WOULD FIX MOST OF THE ISSUESi liked this game i played tropico 3 and 4. 5 is a little different it dumbs down a lot of things making it hard to understand because it is very different, some new buildings and some old buildings. the buildings now are very squared off and fit better in the areas unlike trop 4 where everything exploded around your palace, now its everything is crammed into your palace. im not a fan of the export system because it requires multiple docks for import ships so your exports will be spread around 5 different docks making income hit or miss when a boat shows up, i liked trop 4 where it was you gave the dock an amount of money you were willing to buy imports like 15k and it would buy many different things your island needed to have based on which structures allowed raw material imports, now it is you have import ships for SPECIFIC items like 1 ship for iron, 1 separate ship for gold, and 1 separate ship for uranium, that means building 3 docks to support these ships. To make matters worse in 4 if you didnt have the money you couldnt buy imports, in 5 itll sometimes spend money you dont have on imports. im unsure how co-op works, the budget system as to the old trop4 version which was easy to understand, and im unsure how the manager system for buildings helps them function. the new military system is great and ACTUALLY BEING ABLE TO REPELL AN INVASION FORCE is the best as to in 4 its just you lose since you were invaded.

content:
Posted: February 8
												The fifth instalment of Kalypso's banana republic simulator has little to offer in strategic depth and an occasional amusing but generally unfunny, hyperbolic sense of humor.The game seems to hide information that is essential to learning its model. There is too little information to understand both the supply and demand of your economy to make decisions. In the late game, odds are high that your otherwise happy and well fed citizens will bring an end to your rule in large part because your army can't be bothered to assemble before attacking. They all arrive and charge the rebel mob one by one on their own, impaling themselves like Persian Immortals on the 300 Spartans.To its credit, the game is delightfully pretty and briefly satisfying.

												Do you like Tropico? This is more Tropico. I'd say it's worth $15-20, all DLC included. The campaign is not great, but the overall island-building economy simulator deal is still there, still fun. Tropico is very much an acquired taste, and whether or not you liked the previous versions will likely dictate whether you enjoy this one.It's not Simcity, and it's not Skyline. It's simpler, and narrower in scope, and at certain very specific things, better at what it does. Worth it if you ever wanted your own Banana Republic.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												If your on the fence about getting this game get it. It's after I've played all of the Tropico games (with the exception of 2 I believe which didn't come out on the PC for some reason..) What's cool about this game is: 1 Trade routes. - If you like to play sandbox the game is so much better. You run out of resources, and what's cool now is you can set up trade agreements at different prices to import/export. And in order to make good money and have your buildings function you will need to import. 2 Multiplayer adds a nice touch; it's not my #1 in a Tropico game, but it's a nice side thing to do when you want to goof around with other dictators. :) 3 The research trees are nice; they could be more detailed, but they are a nice addition. 4 Some of the buildings were NOT available in Tropico 4 without buying Tropico 4 modern times, yet they are in 5 such as modern apartments, offices, etc. 5 Your dynasty is just that. You eventually will have more rulers in your dynasty and you can level them up with enough $$$, and they have different skills.. 6 There are a LOT of managers with different skills. You get them via people attending colleges. You can then assign them to buildings. 7 The islands are decent size, AND random maps can be generated just like in T4. 8 This game is selling much more than Tropico 4 did. Does it mean it's better? No, it means that you will have people to play with in multiplayer mode, and the game is pretty good. I liked 4, but like 5 more. The options in sandbox with trading after you've researched everything are nice.. I used to get bored in Tropico 4 in sandbox because once you have a lot of money it seemed pointless; this is not the case in Tropico 5 with resources running out and the need for trade.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Tropico 5 a good game, don't get me wrong.  However, if you try to play the game in sandbox mode you quickly learn that the game is designed to be mission based, like Omerta was, rather than a true sandbox like the previous tropicos.You have 4 stages, the colonial era, the world wars era, the cold war era, and the modern era.  You progress to the next era by fulfilling objectives, even in sandbox mode.  In sandbox mode the game does not even tell you what the objective are, but once  they are fulfilled your "reward" is to advance to the next era until you win.If you played the previous Tropicos for the campaigns this game if probably for you, however if you want a true sandbox city builder, Tropcio 4 is a better option.  This Tropico seems to care more about the campaign than the sandbox mode.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												I've been a fan of the series since Tropico 3. Tropico 3 and 4 are roughly similar, with Tropico 4 adding more content. They're wonderful games, and I hightly recommend them. On the other hand, tropico 5 has had a serious overhall. There are some similarities, but the whole feel of the game is very different for me (other reviewers disagree). Here's a quick overview of the differences between Tropico 4 and Tropico 5:-First and foremost, this game is HARD! The previous Tropico's were a piece of cake. You could easily win an election 85% for you 15% against (on average, without trying). In Tropico 5, if the people love you, you're usually riding around 65% for 35% against if they love you. Usually it's more 50%/50%, to a lot less. Electrion fraud is often a necessity, and even then it won't guarentee a victory. With rebel attacks, uprisings, and invasions... there's no "you get one to two chances before you lose" deal. If you can't repel them, they'll burn down your palace, and you'll lose the game.-Tropico 5's timeline is more well developed than Tropico 4. Tropico 5 no longer keeps track of the actual year (AD) but rather the Dynasty's time in office. You begin in Colonial times, and progress through WW2, the Cold War, and Modern times. Just like in Tropico 4's expansion "Modern Times", buildings and edits become unlocked as you progress through the eras. However, you don't progress through the eras just by letting the time pass. Certain objectives need to be met.-The Blueprints from Tropico 4 are non-existant. Instead it's been replaced by a research system. You need to build a library, hire researchers, etc. You get to choose which research (edits, upgrades, buildings).-The international relations has been completely redone. Other nations/pirates/etc can invade. In tropico 4, an invasion by a world super power means you lose the game. In Tropico 5, your army is pitted against the invader's army. You're also able to establish trade roots between you, and other nations/pirates. This will either increase or decrease your relations with certain parties, as well as offer more or less favorable prices for specific goods.-Building managers are included, which can provide a specific benifit to the building.-Instead of being able to control wages, you invest money into a specific building. This increases wages, job quality, etc.-You have to pay to send out explorers to your island. Without this, you cannot discover new resources, or build beyond your prediscovered area. This is annoying, and I've read many complaints on this. But it's more realistic than Tropico 4.-Building placement has been improved. Farms and ranches work within defined perameters, rather than having patches spring up near the farm wherever is best. Also, it's a lot easier to fit buildings closer together and make the most of your land.-The graphics have been "updated". In my opinion, it's a bit of an eyesore compared to Tropico 4. With this graphic update, I've heard of people having issues with the graphics running at all on their machines. My computer is only two years old, and had the latest, top of the line graphics card when I bought it. Never even had a so much as a stutter playing any AAA title, and yet I had to turn down the graphics for this game to run smoothly.There's also one major con I want to point out to those who are not familiar with Kalypso media. There will be between 5 to a dozen DLC ranging between $4-$6 that add minimal content and brush up the game. This is true for almost every game they've published since steam, and they're usually "patch update" quality. It's one of the things I dislike most about the company, and it is certainly this way with Tropico 5. You're not paying for the complete game. For that, I'd expect to chip out another $40 over the next few years.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												I've been waiting for this game to come to Mac since May. I played at least 150 hours of Tropico 4 (Mac App Store version). But I was nervous about this T5 release because of all the bugs and missing features reported by PC gamers. I got it anyway on sale from Humble Bundle and I'm so happy I did. The developers have been hard at work since May, fixing many bugs, making gameplay smoother, and creating this wonderful Mac version. The graphics are amazing, especially compared to T4. The buildings and decorations are beautiful. Optimizing buildings with upgrades, budget, and managers is more fun and easier. The humor is fun. The research system and edicts work well.I played the tutorial and a quick sandbox game up through the Cold War era on medium difficulty settings. I had no problems with managing happiness, rebels didn’t appear out of the blue, teamsters didn’t get stuck in the docks, my military performed decently, etc. So it seems like the game-breaking bugs have been fixed (at least for Mac). Minor complaints:I went onto multiplayer, but no one else was there. Granted, this was at 3 am CST. :pI miss being able to zoom down to street level and “walk” around my city.I hate the way the grid overlay looks. It was perfect in T4. Now all the lines of the grid are thick and they glow, making it difficult to see the ground for good placement.Looking forward to more updates for more polish. And once all the planned DLC comes out in a bundle, then I'll buy 'em.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Much too laggy, mainly on multiplayer, as well as the main fact that sometimes even after 20 minutes, the game becomes impossible to play every multiplayer round due to the fact that there are many issues that bog down gameplay (intense rebellions, even the developers commented on the arbitrary amount of rebellions even if your island is a paradise). I also feel rather suspicious of the direction that Kalypso is taking this game, and most of the models get rather quite repetitive and boring (it took me a while to memorize all the models) like how,all the houses have the same model, and the Time Era's are nothing really but sections of the game which lock up certain buildings from you later in the game. All the tanks are literally the exact same T-34 1940 edition with a different paint job. It doesnt matter of its 2005 and you're fending off China or its 1917 and you're winning the Battle of the Somme on the German side, everyone has T-34s. The 3 main issues with this game is 1. When you upgrade buildings or hire managers and the perk menu says something like 'generates funds off nearby houses', it doesnt say how far 'nearby' means, and for a game made in 2014, i really would like some more clarity. 2. Rebels are far too high in numbers, even when i have 82% popular support and 46 soldiers along with 9 tanks, rebels will still bulldoze through my highly trained Commandos and commit arson on my palace, therefore me losing the game due to a coup. That part mainly gets rid of the stalinist dictator feeling, sadly. 3. Man, is Kalypso sure hardballing us with DLC. $4 USD for 1-2 buildings with questionable usefulness, an outfit you probably won't use, a mission that you'll burn through in 20 minutes, and a music track (Despite me not owning any of the DLC, I have met people who do own DLC and have mainly said those comments). Would probably repurchase this game if it were cheaper and DLC was consolidated into main game.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												I have played a few campaigns in 5 so far, and here are my initial impressions.Pros    I like the graphics. They look beautiful. Enough said.    I like the music. Not as good as 4, in my personal opinion, but still good.    I like the trading system changes, or what I've seen of them so far. It adds some depth to the trading, which is something I didn't know Tropico needed until now.    I like the snap-to-grid effect when placing buildings/roads. It makes it a bit easier to set up your island.Cons    I don't like the overlay system. It is hard to see underneath all the trees. It looks nice, but personally I find it just makes it hard to judge where to drop ranches/plantations/etc.    I don't like the amount of gated content. There is the research gating (which is fine on its own) and the war requirement gating (which is annoying and unnecessary in a lot of cases). Obviously, the war gating makes sense historically most of the time. In-game, I think the amount of content gated by the wars is a bit extreme. I should be able to have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little clinic before the first war if I have the cash for it.    I don't like the lack of WASD camera controls. The devs did announce that they'd be implementing them soon, so its not a huge deal. It just seems like it should have been put in to begin with, as I remember quite a bit of clamoring for them in 4.    I don't like the new voice actors or characters. This is a serious issue for me. Way more serious than it is for others, I'm sure. The NPCs seem flat and bland. Even the new characters' pictures are less caricature-like than they were previously. The voice acting is sub-par compared to 4. The humor and silly voice acting were what made me fall hard for Tropico. If I had played this game first, I'd probably never try the others and I probably wouldn't play after finishing the campaigns. Seriously. I never thought I'd miss Sunny. The new Penultimo sounds like a toolbag compared to 4's. I miss Lord Chuffney.Overall, I'm enjoying it but am I little bit disappointed at the same time. I'd like to mess around in multi-player before I can say if this game will be eating up all my free-time in the near future or not.Check out my Let's Play series for Tropico 5 for more info:


YouTube™ Video: Tropico 5 Let's Play Campaign - Mission: A New Dawn - Episode 1 Gameplay 

			Views: 67,438		

			Tropico 5 Let's Play! Welcome to part one of my Tropico 5 city building playthrough.Our Tropico V Let's Play series, will take a look at the exciting gameplay behind the campaign missions of Tropico...

Posted: June 8, 2016
												I wanted to like this as much as Tropico 4. There are a lot of improvements to how the economy runs, the graphics are beautiful, and in general the feel of the game is less chaotic. The 'Era' and 'Technology' pieces are neat additions as well.Ultimately though, this is a soulless game that tries too hard to make you like it. The characters are grating, the "It's a new era, now everyone hates you!" is obnoxious at best, and most of the game is spent preparing for the 'end of era invasion'.. because that's the biggest "challenge" and frankly the most fun part of an era. No more can you do fun things like pander to the religous and environmental factions and force everyone else off the island. Now it's "Faction A" vs "Faction B".. and that's it. Oh, and if Faction A doesn't like you, it blows up your stuff. Yay..I would maybe buy this game if it and all of its DLC's are on a huge sale.. maybe.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Okay, now that I've put almost a full day of my life into this, I feel the need to re-write my review. After 6 hours, I really didn't have a good idea of what kind of flavor Tropico 5 had in comparison with the other games. As a certifiable Tropico junkie, I have to say that Tropico might be my favorite city builder series of all time. I know that this might rub people the wrong way, but whatever. Anyway, I felt the need to completely re-review the game. I have some complaints, some compliments, and some other things that I feel are perfectly valid. First of all, Penultimo's voice actor still sucks. I still wonder why they would get something so incredibly terrible to do his voice acting. They could've just paid the same guy to do it again. Other than him, the voice acting isn't terrible. The soundtrack is an improvement over the previous installments, but it's still basically the same. A few songs, boring after one mission. There's a much higher emphasis on doing ABSOLUTELY EVERYTHING ELSE rather than focusing on city building in Tropico 5. After reading other reviews of the game online, I can't figure out how they can necessarily compare it to the older games and describe it as "too similar." - It's really not. There are some staples that are of course left in Tropico 5, the edict system, etc, - but now you have different challenges and things to deal with. You have to have heirs, and you create a dynasty - this is just unintentionally irritating. I don't like this feature - mostly because you don't have NEARLY the same amount of options to design the dynasty members as you do to create your initial "El Presidente" character if you choose to go the custom Route. And in any case - you get one trait. Someone else pointed this out to me before, but I didn't realize how much of a detriment this really was. Give me a break. One trait? I'm guessing it's supposed to balance out when you can assign managers to different buildings for various bonuses, or in some cases, things that don't really make any difference/might even be a drawback to your buildings. In other words - the Dynasty building/manager assignment system is totally unnecessary and keeping up with it is extremely irritating and ruins immersion. Just how I see it. Also, having to build a dock for every single friggin' ship is both unnecessary and makes trade slow and difficult. I don't know if I stated this earlier, but the difficulty level of Tropico 5 in comparison with the other games is ramped WAY up. You build plantations and ranches to export goods, as well as building mines and and harvesting other resources just like you did in the other games - only now, you need to assign a proper manager to that building, open up the trade routes, and work even harder to improve your foreign relations. In this way, it's more realistic, and I don't necessarily mind having more gameplay elements - but it could've been executed better. Again, this isn't going to stop me from playing the game. The sharp increase in learning curve with Tropico 5 in comparison to the earlier games is not the problem - the problem is that they took a lot of what made Tropico fun - basically giving you a big Zen Garden to play with, and took it out. Certainly, after playing all of the other games in the series, I have a biased view, and releasing the same game again would be pointless - but how about introducing some of the elements as the game progresses at a more natural pace, instead of making it a mad dash to do anything at all? When you're bleeding money because your plantations are producing too much to actually export the goods, unless you build 30 more docks, which you can't do because you're bleeding money. The game is much more linear than previous installments, where you could stall doing certain mission tasks in order to play around more - not so in the campaign for Tropico 5, you're better off just to do everything as fast as possible, and even then, it can become quite hard quite quickly regardless of how easy the settings are for the game. I don't want it to sound like I'm complaining TOO much about the changes, again, because releasing another Tropico 4 would be pointless, and Tropico 4 seemed much like a smooth, pleasant UI update and graphics update for Tropico 3 than anything. Tropico 5 IS, most definitely, a different game than the others, but it takes a lot of the freedom out of what you're trying to accomplish. Making you pay to explore your island in order to expand is one of the most annoying factors of the new gameplay - why do we have to build a dry dock to unlock the friggin' map? Lame. Missions that ask you to find certain things that are either in extremely short supply or not there at all also completely waste your time and money, and your citizens are much harder to keep happy. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, as the citizen interactment was something I thought was well-balanced in Tropico 4 - not so well balanced this time. More or less, to a certain point, if you don't have Conscription activated, you're just screwed - you can also very easily build yourself into  oblivion and regardless of what you do, your military will probably suck. That is, unless, you about 10 guard tower for every building you have and have Conscription turned on, then it's not so bad. The idea of tenaments degrading over time is also great - I don't know why I like that idea, but I do. Everything looks much better, and more modernized, than most other city builders that are coming out right now and I can certainly appreciate a pretty game to look at. But it still feels a bit cramped while at the same time feeling bloated and artificially limited in options. I still love the game, I'll still play it until the end, but I feel like putting 150 and then some hours into it like I did with Tropico 4, or as much time as I have in the other games, is kind of a waste, and most of it will be from things that were put in the game JUST to purposely slow you down so the game can seem longer. Not quite as exciting, much harder, and much more to keep up with that has nothing to do with city building, but more to do with dealing with jerks. Extremely de-emphasis on city building, and much more emphasis on politically stuff. In a way, the increased focus on being a good El Presidente and representing your people and what you think is best for them is great, but at the same time, is Tropico a series known for city building or for being a dictatorial jerk who has citizens trying to kill them every 3 minutes, so they can't explore the island or really protect themselves from someone hurling an underarmed golfball at a guard tower that you didn't place quite close enough to one of your docks? Not as good as previous installments, but still good. Tropico 5? more like Tropico: More Politics, Less City - STILL worth the money, and still extremely fun. But comparing it to previous installments is fairly pointless beyond certain things that they really couldn't take out of the game.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Much like the previous game, emphasis on the same aspects in that it's very clear what the game is trying to do. You play ruler of a tropican island and it's your job to have the island prosper and grow while juggling your relations with the big superpowers as well as your own growing population.The game is now built around 4 time periods or Eras; Colonial, World Wars, Cold War and Modern Times. Special events happen all the time throughout the game, depending on which Era you are in. This brings a lot of variety to the game and is a nice addition from Tropico 4.Multiplayer has been added to the game, which is exciting - I haven't played it much but it seems decent enough. Nothing really worth invisting too much time into - If you are thinking about buying the game, buy it for the Single Player modesThe music is excellent and probably the only thing about the game done to perfection. It's mostly instrumental music unlike Tropico 4 and i have to say they pulled it off perfectly. You never feel like it's' too much and listening to the same music isn't getting in the way of enjoying the game.I'll recommend the game to both fans of the series and newcomvers, but don't expect fireworks. 7/10
