content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Much like the previous game, emphasis on the same aspects in that it's very clear what the game is trying to do. You play ruler of a tropican island and it's your job to have the island prosper and grow while juggling your relations with the big superpowers as well as your own growing population.The game is now built around 4 time periods or Eras; Colonial, World Wars, Cold War and Modern Times. Special events happen all the time throughout the game, depending on which Era you are in. This brings a lot of variety to the game and is a nice addition from Tropico 4.Multiplayer has been added to the game, which is exciting - I haven't played it much but it seems decent enough. Nothing really worth invisting too much time into - If you are thinking about buying the game, buy it for the Single Player modesThe music is excellent and probably the only thing about the game done to perfection. It's mostly instrumental music unlike Tropico 4 and i have to say they pulled it off perfectly. You never feel like it's' too much and listening to the same music isn't getting in the way of enjoying the game.I'll recommend the game to both fans of the series and newcomvers, but don't expect fireworks. 7/10

Previous games had much better beats.Kudos on finally getting the issue of farm fields sorted out though.(Frankly nothing beats Tropico 3)

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												As is the tradition with Tropico games, the next in the series really has nothing "new" to offer, that the previous already had.  Sadly, in the case of this game, Tropico 5 actually has LESS than Tropico 4 did.First off, and most noticable is the change in (good) voice actors, and huge reduction characters.  Sunny is gone, as well as many other favorites, which in turn cuts back on the humor and charm that makes Tropico so much fun.  There's now a more stream-lined way to build (ie plantations vs farms) which is sometimes good, but mostly bad -- it cuts back hardcore on your building options.If you're new to Tropico, stick to Part 4 and it's DLC.  Veterans of Tropico will most likely feel cheated by Part 5.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												If Che Guevara made Sim City, Tropico would be the result.Tropico 5 is an Island Defense game.  Everyone wants you dead & you must maintain power.  The ways to die remind me of a rogue.  The ciy is very sim grown up with real issues.  The strat is mostly defensive.  Perhaps because of all this, Tropico has grown into its own, setting the standard for multiple genres.  Playing through Tropico's 1-5, I must say this new one is my favourite.  Haemimont Games keeps upping the ante and it's awesome.The sales scheme confuses a lot of kids.  It is a AAA game worth $60 for $40.  The DLC are part of that initial cost.  At $5 each they are well priced.  The Expansions for $20 add plenty of content for the cost.  This is still cheaper than most AAA games and they were able to do it by parsing out the content as aforementioned.  The game is well worth it.  If this all bothers you, be patient and get it on sale, as Kalypso often does them along with bundles and charity discounts.Any way you make it to the isle, Tropico 5 is well worth whipping out your wallet, sending those Swiss bank account funds, & building your own pirate nation.  The replay value is literally endless.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Nothing more to say than what has already been said.  The game, while stepping forward in certain respects, has slid backwards in so many other ways.  The improvements to the military, trade, and dynasty aspects are easily undone by lack of follow through.  You now can get tanks... but there is still no control over the units and how they fight. You are helpless to sit back and hope they all don't attack the enemy force one at a time like a typical henchman.  The trade system requires boats for special deals with different countries/sides but I was unable to find the unit prices of any of the trade goods to plan my growth accordingly.  Then with the dynasty, it’s great to have some illegitimate children every once and a while, but can't I have legitimate children? Or choose their name or not get annoyed when I have to customize a dynasty member?Besides spelling errors, over the top (and borderline racist) caricatures of the various factions, and general half way approach I've been getting used to, they game is at least a decent waste of time.  I would not recommend purchasing it for anything less than 50% off.  After Kalypso’s other recent games, I honestly don’t know why I had high expectations.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												The game is actually good in most respects. I enjoyed being able to put more thought into the layout of the city I was building, and liked all the variation that was available. However, I never really understood the game. The tutorial shows you a bit about how the game works, but there's a lot that it doesn't tell you. You need to have public opinion on your side in order to get re-elected and keep playing, but if the public turns against you, you have to click on each person to figure out what needs they have personally in order to meet those needs. It would have been better if there was a page that told you exactly what you were lacking in so that you could meet the needs, but I didn't see any, and if any exist then it certainly doesn't come up in the tutorial.There's also the issue of money. You want your island to be profitable. The tutorial does not tell you how to do this. I ended up in extreme debt multiple plays because I didn't know how to stop the spending of money (You have to adjust the budget at EACH building btw).Basically I was left with the impression that there's a lot of things going on in the background and you are not privy to the knowledge without a lot of extra steps. I'm not saying that it's a bad game, but rather that it is not for me. I'll stick to more traditional city-building games.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Nothing more to say than what has already been said.  The game, while stepping forward in certain respects, has slid backwards in so many other ways.  The improvements to the military, trade, and dynasty aspects are easily undone by lack of follow through.  You now can get tanks... but there is still no control over the units and how they fight. You are helpless to sit back and hope they all don't attack the enemy force one at a time like a typical henchman.  The trade system requires boats for special deals with different countries/sides but I was unable to find the unit prices of any of the trade goods to plan my growth accordingly.  Then with the dynasty, it’s great to have some illegitimate children every once and a while, but can't I have legitimate children? Or choose their name or not get annoyed when I have to customize a dynasty member?Besides spelling errors, over the top (and borderline racist) caricatures of the various factions, and general half way approach I've been getting used to, they game is at least a decent waste of time.  I would not recommend purchasing it for anything less than 50% off.  After Kalypso’s other recent games, I honestly don’t know why I had high expectations.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												Tropico 5 to moim zdanie jeden krok w przód, ponieważ wprowadza parę ciekawych nowości tj. epoki, konstytucja czy kierownicy budynków. Plusem jest też to, że rozgrywka na danej wyspie w trybie kampanii jest zapisywana (przynajmniej w podstawowej) dzięki czemu możemy w pełni nacieszyć się epokami i nie musimy zaczynać zawsze od zera. Lecz nie dlatego dałem palec w dół, tylko dlatego że w pewnych, moim zdaniem, ważnych miejscach gra robi 2 kroki w tył. Jedną z nowych rzeczy jest ustalanie budżetu, które ma z góry ustalone kwoty. Oczywiście to nie jest rzecz, która psuje grę w dużym stopniu, ale zabiera mozliwość samodzielnego podjęcia decyzji o zarobkach pracowników co odbija się na budynkach mieszkalnych, w których też wybiera się, z góry ustalony wariant budżetu. Muszę budować domki, które mieszczą tylko 4 rodziny i zazwyczaj dają minimalny przychód, albo muszę zwięksazać zarobki pracowników, po to by mieszkali w lepszych (również 4 rodzinnych domkach), co powoduję mniejszy przychód. I dlaczego w pierwszych dwóch epokach muszę zbudować tak wiele tych domków?? Nie dość, że są stosunkowo drogie, to muszę jeszcze, zbudować ich kilkadziesiąt, żeby pomieścić wszystkich obywateli. Oczywiście, można wybudować czynszówkę w drugiej epoce, która z czasem traci "jakość", przez co obywatele nie chcą w nich mieszkać, a potrafią budować sobie szałasy, gdy są miejsca w domkach. Kolejną rzeczą jest polityka wew., która w tej części, moim zdaniem, kuleje, ponieważ, gdy jedna strona cię kocha, druga nienawidzi, czego nie było w poprzedniej części. Rozumiem że jest to część systemu epok, lecz przez to bardzo często poparcie jest mniejsze niż 50%, a potrzeba przynajmniej 51% by ruszyć z epoką do przodu lub by wygrać wybory, co jest KLUCZOWE w tej grze. Jest opcja fałszerstwa wyborów, lecz ona nie działa jak powinna. 2 razy sfałszowałem wybory i 2 razy przegrałem, DLACZEGO???? W poprzedniej części ZAWSZE wygrywało się sfałszowane wybory, były za to jakieś kary, ale mogłem grać dalej. Polityki zagranicznej nie będę oceniał ponieważ nie zagłębiałem się w nią. Kolejna rzecz: imigracja w Tropico 4 wystarczyło wybudować urząd imigracyjny i można było zgrubsza kontrolować napływ imigrantów, w Tropico 5 już nie. Oczywiście jest opcja konstytucyjna regulująca to, lecz ona nie działą tak jak powinna. Mam 4 porty, "państwo imigrantów" i przypływa 10-20 imigrantów jednym statkiem na 6-8???? gdzie ja w tym czasię będę już potrzebował 40 bezrobotnych, którzy też, za bardzo do pracy się nie palą, ponieważ czekają na wolne miejsce "ucznia" (co powodowało, że byli bezdomni). W Tropico 4 praktycznie na każdym statku przypływali imigranci, przez co czasem trzeba było blokować imigrację, bo przypływało ich za dużo, a w Tropico 5 jest ich zawsze za mało. Ktoś pewnie powie "przecież można zbudować parę klinik i wprowadzić zakaz antykoncepcji" tylko, że do klinik trzeba drugiej epoki i uniwersytetu (bez zapraszania pracowników z zagranicy), a antykoncepcję można zablokować dopiero w trzeciej epoce, więc wskaźnik urodzeń jest na początku słaby. Pisałem o portach i tutaj mam kolejny minus. Rozumiem konieczność większej ilości portów, by mieć więcej statków handlowych. Tylko dlaczego zazwyczaj towary które eksportuję, są w kilku różnych portach?? Nie można było wprowadzić jakiegoś filtra, który by sprawiał, że dany towar na eksport, byłby w tym samym porcie, a nie trzech różnych, przy tylko 1 statku przydzielonym do eksportu?? Duża ilość portów sprawia że tylko się traci pieniądze na ich utrzymanie, a muszą być "obsadzone" by mieć więcej statków handlowych. Pisałem też, o tym, że progres na wyspie jest przenoszony z misji na misję. Tylko, że przez to mamy do wyboru, aż DWIE wyspy (przynajmniem w podstawowej kampanii). Jeden krok w przód i jeden krok w tył. Kolejną rzeczą, która robi krok w tył, jest biuro budowlane. Po #1: budowlańcy NIE naprawiają uszkodzonych lub podtopionych (co jest ciekawym, nowym dodatkiem) budynków, trzeba zapłacić za naprawę takich budynków, gdzie w poprzedniej części budowlańcy, sami to robili, i to za DARMO, jeżeli nie było budynków do budowy. Przynajmniej wprowadzili opcję "napraw wszystkie budynki" czy "odbuduj wszystkie budynki", dzięki czemu nie trzeba było ich szukać. Po #2: w Tropico 4, zaznaczając biuro budowlane, wyświetlały się informację jakie budynki pracownicy aktualnie wznoszą, czego już w Tropico 5 nie znajdziemy, przez co gracz nie ma pojęcia, czy budowlańcy pracują, czy się po prostu opier...niczają. Turystyki nie będę oceniał, ponieważ nigdy jej nie lubiłem w tej serii i dlatego, że jeszcze nie doszedłem do tego momentu.Ogólnie oceniam grę pozytywnie i polecam ją, ze względu na dwie poprzednie części, które mi się podobały i mam nadzieję, że ta też mi się spodoba, ale radzę uzbroić się w cierpliwość, ponieważ gra może zniechęcić w kilku momentach. I zanim ktoś mi odpowie, że grałem za krótko itp. To odrazu mówię, że w poprzedniej części byłem "weteranem", co można sprawdzić. 140 godzin w Tropico 4 i około połowy tego czasu w Tropico 3 (lecz nie na steamie).Jeżeli moja recenzja nie jest profesjonalna, to dlatego, że rzadko to robie.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This game is a disaster and an unworthy sequel for this series. There is little control over what happens in the game and little useful information to understand . A lot of things got worse compared to Tropico 4. You can't set salaries or rents, houses stay empty while people live in shacks. You can't get satisfy the needs of the citizens in the early eras because most buildings are unavailable. You need far too many buildings of a given type to provide services. Combat is pathetic.All in all playing this game is no fun and a total waste of time.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												The game is actually good in most respects. I enjoyed being able to put more thought into the layout of the city I was building, and liked all the variation that was available. However, I never really understood the game. The tutorial shows you a bit about how the game works, but there's a lot that it doesn't tell you. You need to have public opinion on your side in order to get re-elected and keep playing, but if the public turns against you, you have to click on each person to figure out what needs they have personally in order to meet those needs. It would have been better if there was a page that told you exactly what you were lacking in so that you could meet the needs, but I didn't see any, and if any exist then it certainly doesn't come up in the tutorial.There's also the issue of money. You want your island to be profitable. The tutorial does not tell you how to do this. I ended up in extreme debt multiple plays because I didn't know how to stop the spending of money (You have to adjust the budget at EACH building btw).Basically I was left with the impression that there's a lot of things going on in the background and you are not privy to the knowledge without a lot of extra steps. I'm not saying that it's a bad game, but rather that it is not for me. I'll stick to more traditional city-building games.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Tropico 5 is a very good game.Pros:They have made the economy much harder to manage. In Tropico 4 it was just make some sugar farms and you were set.The era system has also been managed very well, new challenges come with every era and also new buildings, edicts and technologies...The tech tree adds a whole new perspective the game.You now have a Constitution where you can change different laws such as voting rights and immigration.Uprisings, Coups and especially invasions are now a real threat that has to be dealt with, In Tropico 4, foreign invasion never really threatened me at all.Better combat systems.Tasks actually have a meaning late-gameThe new trade system allows you to sell specific items to a nation of your choice at a higher price to normal.The swiss bank account actually means something now rather than something you can feel bad about as you earn twice as much money as the country does,Cons:You can't control any of your units you just have to hope for the best that they arrive at the combat zone.Economy is extremely hard to manage late game as more and more buildings are built.You can't activate martial law and have a happy military. The military loyalty is determined by the people's happiness, meaning that if you issue martial law,ironically, the military will probably start a coup.Teamsters and Construction workers are extremely slow, and if you put a building on low priority forget about it. I was looking around for any oil deposits and I saw a corn plantation on low priority still being built from the Colonial era.It literally takes a year to get some wood from one side of the island to the other.Almanac has been simplified, The economy page only tells you your expenses and revenue, no detail of income or expenditure.Budgets make a large bustling city cost you $1000 a second.Overall:8/10P.S: At the end penultimo blames the Illuminati.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												The game is great fun! A little more of the same Tropico, but with quite a few additions/changes that only become more apparent the longer you play!Money well spent!P.S. The music is gorgeous! Gorgeous I tell you!9/10Edit:Sadly, others seem to have received a different game to the one I received. My copy is enjoyable and really good fun with plenty to do and some really nice additions to the gameplay. My copy is also pretty much bug-free, there is a little bit of a buggy UI when selecting buildings in the Almanac, but other than that it is in very good shape. There are also some items of information missing, such as Mines from the list in the Raw Resources section of the Almanac and how many free slots/total slots available in Residential buildings. These are definitely not game breakers and will probably added in a patch as they shouldn't be difficult to implement. More of an oversight rather than a bug per se.Others though, it seems, have received a game that they are extremely disappointed by...Who's right? Who knows, but I can say that I'll be sinking a lot of hours into Tropico 5!If you do see past the vitriolic comments and give the game a try, not expecting a rehash of Tropico 4, then you won't be disappointed.After all, change is not for everybody.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Hi, my name is astrosoup. I am a veteran of the franchise, and I really like Tropico 5.I just can't wrap my mind around some of the criticisms being levied against this game. I read all the user reviews before booting it up, with phrases such as "gutting the franchise" and "total let-down" setting me up for a huge disappointment. I'm happy to report that this game is 100% Tropico and the rumors of its demise have been highly exaggerated.To begin, the interface has been incredibly improved. Clear categorization and images of each building help me find what I'm looking for much more easily than any version before it. Also, the game looks fantastic. To my eyes, its a little heavy on the saturation, but even still, Tropico has never looked better. Most of this has to do with the details of how buildings fit together so nicely. Tropico has a history of forcing you to put things in awkward places due to obscure rules about terrain leveling, etc. Alot of that is gone, and I find myself actually staring at my cities fondly, proud of what I have designed. Building textures look better than ever, and farms can fit the contours of your roads, buildings, etc. Even the decorative garden options look good! Anyone complaining about beautification options in this version has either a short memory or has never played Tropico before. These games have always been lacking in little things to make your island look nicer, but Tropico 5 does it better than ever. I have been enjoying the art of city-building, which is something Tropico has never delivered to me before.Also, the new campaign style is far improved over the old system. Like much they have done away with, the ritual of starting from scratch worked for Tropico 1, but never quite made sense in Kalypso's version. I never made it very far in the campaigns, simply because I got tired of constantly starting my island over. In Tropico 5, the campaign takes you through various time periods, with only a couple of islands. With each era, the game challenges you in a new way, keeping it feeling fresh and forcing you to change your play styles, while allowing you to build on your previous work. The hackneyed mission narratives have been tossed out in favor of a richer meta-narrative that spans all of your missions. Watching a third of my populace suffer in shacks while I desperately cling to power by throwing large amounts of money at foreign powers gives me a sense of what it is like to be a true developing world dictator- the artful mark of a good sim. I like how buildings seem to (so far) maintain their "look" as you move into a new era, as opposed to magically changing skins. It really keeps a sense of continuity and history, allowing me to look back fondly on my colonial roots. Also, assistance from NPCs, such as extending deadlines, or taking bonuses can be forfeited for Swiss bank funds, so that the size of your swiss bank account actually reflects the amount of extra help you did or didn't accept along the way. For the first time, in the 5th generation of the series, the swiss bank account actually means something to me! Furthermore, alot of the charming hangups that marvelously infuriated me in Tropico 1, and mildly annoyed me in 3 & 4, have finally been ironed out. Ships come on a regular schedule and get loaded immediately. Construction office run more smoothly- no more bursts of activity followed by months of stagnation. I now build about half the amount of construction offices I used to in order to compensate for this. Goods move efficiently. You don't need to build giant parking garages every 10 yards. In general, things just work better. All in all, it has been a major improvement.This is not to say the game is perfect. As others have mentioned, it would be nice to have a little more data available when making decisions, especially in terms of trade and the economy. I'd like to know the market price of goods before I build a production faciltity, for example. The system for clearing fog of war is expensive and not very well thought out. There are some peculiar design decisions here and there, but none of it is game-breaking. I should note that I do experience occasional crashes with my GeForce 660 video card. At least I'm assuming its the card, because Tropico 3 & 4 have always had trouble with it. So save often, even though its a bit of the chore. The autosave doesn't unfortunately doesn't happen often enough to have your back. Also, don't buy it quite yet for the multiplayer experience, until they fix the game speed issue (set to fastest) and the no-saves policy. This game is a fantastic step forward for Kalypso's stewardship of the Tropico franchise. Nothing will ever beat the original, but this one certainly beats 3 & 4. Most of the ire seems to be centered around the removal of peripheral features, such as locking people up in prisons, or setting individual wages, etc. Yet, for every building they removed they added a handful more. This is anything but a DLC 'money-grab' as some allege, as it is brimming with engaging new content, spanning several eras. Honestly, Kalypso took flak for making 4 a carbon copy of 3. I don't really miss anything they removed in the new version, and if I ever do, I have THREE PREVIOUS VERSIONS that I can go re-play. I, for one, am glad that they changed things up a bit for T5. It's still 100% Tropico, but in a spiffy new form.Also, they added a VERY DIFFICULT mode for both the economic and political game mechanics. Of course, I started the campain out on this, daring to hope that Kalypso has indeed returned a degree of difficulty into the franchise. I haven't lost or anything yet, but I did feel on a couple of occasions that my decisions did matter a tiny bit. So there is another positive change. Also, I am having to deny elections, so we shall see...Great work Kalypso. Please fix the crashing issue. Thanks for being responsive to the community. And thanks for treating our beloved franchise with respect.

												I don't like introducing myself so let's jump in to itTROPICO 5, should you buy it, of course my answer is NOIN THIS REVIEW I WANT TO ENCOURAGE YOU TO BUY TROPICO 4 AND NOT 5. This is why:If you never played tropico it is basicly a game about being a dictator on a tropical island (without genocides or crazy Sh*t)So let's start, tropico 4 VS 5In tropico 4 you want (economicly speaking) to produce much and high quality goods, or you can focus on MANY raw materials, mainly exotic fruits.in tropico 5 you want to produce only a certain thing beacuse you have trading offers which limit EXTREMELY and i mean EXTREMELY the potential of you building your economy, you can build a rum distilery but you can get 0 MONEY out of it beacuse you have no offers on your dockIn tropico 5 you can issue a lot more edicts like: no free food, contraception ban, social engieniring, socialsecurity etc etcIn tropico 4 you can issue some eddicts like: National day ,social security ,food for the people not so many as in Tropico 5 and i have to give 5 this.In tropico 5 you will be in debt every time, (but in the modern ages) and you should expect only forgin aid to help you beacuse without it you can't do anythingIn tropico 4 you will be in debt only if you can't manage the economy and when you are in debt you feel like : "Ooops i have done some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Sh*t" and you have to THINK on how to make the treasury full(er)In tropico 5 PEOPLE♥♥♥♥♥♥♥REBEL TO MUCH, ok i understand you can be a rebel but at some ok conditions and food+shelter+a clinic nearby you become a rebel, i tell you, you can gave 5 rebel attacks in no time and, no problem you will crush them secound time you play, but the frist time after you build your stuff some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ people attack you ITS HORIBLE, you have to focus on armies and not on food beacuse of them. Frist time it's fun, secound meh BUT THIRD they♥♥♥♥♥♥you off beacuse they have 0%%%% REASONS to rebel against you.In tropico 4 people rebel for serious things, like: they want a hospital and you didn't bought one even though you could. or they rebel if you pay them very little and dont provide them with shelter and hospitals and that seems very ok to me if you can't take care of your people they should rebel, not if they are bored like they do in 5.I can go on and on now but TRUST ME if you buy tropico 4 you will have a better time, all those positive reviews haven't played tropico 4Goodbuy (------------ You see what i did there? :D

content:

												Check if your graphics card is definetly able to support DirectX 11. Otherwise, you will face serious graphical bugs which make the game unplayable. After all this time, I would have expected backward compability like in Civilization 5 or other products. Personally, I don't need the fancy-pancy graphics stuff but a playable game with intersting mechanics. I was blinded by the enjoyable experience of Tropico 1 back then, wanted to revive the days as communist can exporteur, but nope. The store page didn't warn me enough about the lacking functionality if your have a too old graphics card (NVIDIA Geforce GT 230M works with soo many games, even with those sold in the same year).

												For what it's worth, it's pretty enjoyable. Let's get the cons out of the way though: El Presidente customization has been slaughtered, bringing it done to a bare minimum which was really disappointing. The Dynesty system wasn't that intuitive. And the difficulty still isn't much challenging. And there's no WASD support, which is just a pet peeve. Although, the new Era system is actually really interesting. It adds variation that i haven't seen done in my time with Tropico 4 (Which was just one singular era wiithout much deviation) although it feels like there's less buildings for some odd reason. Still, the game is very enjoyable for what it's worth. I reccomened this game decently. Oh, and multiplayer was ♥♥♥♥ed right off the bat, so still have to see that.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												The developers had a bold and commendable strategy, one which may even be without precedent: design an aweful user experience, cover it with a terrible user interface, add a couple of mostly-useless tutorials, and bury an otherwise incrediby fun game in it. This is my first Tropico game, for what it's worth, and I'm playing it on a free weekend. The core mechanics are a lot of fun. The UI is visually aweful, unresponsive at times, obtrusive at others, and incredibly dated. Windows randomly grab focus.The first time a disaster hit, my camera got rotated in some weird way. I had to go to google to discover how to rotate it (alt+mouse or mouse3+mouse, btw).Colourblind mode makes no sense (though a whole-hearted "thank you" for actually trying, at least!)I went to plant corn and a grid came up. Its name was 'grid: corn'. Hrm. Is red a place where corn is lacking or is it a place where corn won't grow well? I never did find that answer.The controls and their customization is aweful. UI elements became completely unresponsive at times (I haven't 100% figured out how to reproduce it yet to tell the dev).All kinds of windows will not just pull focus (as mentioned above) but close other ones you are in.I found myself frequently going to google to just figure out what something meant; I was completely lost with things that the tutorials didn't cover and for which no in-game help existed. I'd highly recommend reading the manual (if there is one,) before starting if you decide to play (this may be better for people who've played a Tropico game before?)If they'd overhaull the UI and UX, I'd absolutely buy it; I've greatly enjoyed the gameplay part for the weekend. In its current state, however, I would not recomment it whatsoever.

												I give Tropico 5 4.8 El Presidente Smoking Pipes out of 5.  Because El Presidente used one of his smoking pipes to stab someone who would dare run against them and broke off the tip.The game is amazing.  It is a straight upgrade compared to 4 with lots of new mechanics, buildings moved so they provide bonuses to each other, much more clear definitions of what farms and ranches are capable of using, lots of buildings removed and condensed, which is a good thing means less to manage!I have put up a post in the dicussions mentioning all the bugs I found after the campaign and a few sandbox games.  I have also put in the suggestions for Kalypso.The execution is amazing but the running did kind of trip at the starting gate and not is in a close running for first place despite the tripping in determining best game in the series.I can officially say I will buy every DLC that comes out.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												You win some, you lose some with Tropico 5. There were definitely some nice features that they pulled out from Tropico 4, which was definitely a shame. The addition of multiplayer makes the game pretty fun, it's nice to be able to work alongside, or against other players. The soundtrack doesn't have nearly the oomph that Tropico 4 did, I find myself muting it and going back to the 3rd and 4th soundtracks to keep the vibe.Thankfully, glitches aren't as abundant as they were in past games, but when they happen, they break a game you worked hours on. Mod support is okay, it's only as good as the community making the mods, and right now it's definitely not as large as other communities like Fallout and Prison Architect.All-in-all, this is a good vanilla gaming experience. Multiplayer is fun, and if this is your first Tropico game, you won't be set up for disappointment. It's a great city-builder, with many options to keep things fun for hours.

												Very solid, but kind of unnervingly repetative. That and the theme, while pretty catchy and somewhat funny at first, wore increasingly thin at record speeds.I get it, I'm Castro/Pol Pot/Hitler, w/e. I dunno, maybe I don't get off on the whole anti-hero thing as much as I thought I did.  This game exists in the uncanny-vally of villain games, in the dip between, say, Laharl from Disgaea and the Keeper from Dungeon Keeper. Sadism is fun and all but this was just sort of churlish.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												It is not a bad game but has such big flaws i can not reccomend this game.Tropico4 is miles ahead of this one with so much more to build, most of this game was stripped of content to charge you as dlc later.The combat is really bad too, no control at all, that is not a bad thing but i had 3 bases and many many barracks, and for no reason at all i had a uprising, they destroyed my army and suddenly game over, it just doesnt work right, at least let us turn this buggy part off?The Happiness is flaky too, something just doesnt tick in this one, jobs not being taken, homeless with empty homes, it just doesnt work, maybe it is the awful road placement?As for the Coop play? forget it, it is terrible, there still is no save game feature for coop games, yes thats right, how stupid is that?The best period i enjoy is the colonial, but you stay in this period for like 5minutes or its game over, its just stupid.The radio speach this time around seems to be aimed at 10yr olds too, seriously just grab Tropicool4.Rushed out game and no denying that and very overpriced for what you get.Oh and lets not forget the killer, you have to click every home, choose the upgrade tab and then choose Electrocution on every single home of any form to upgrade it, the most tedious thing i have done in a game ofr the last decade. Why we could not have upgrade all or make it auto if they fall within a powergrid. TERRIBAD.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												First Impressions:Tropico seems to suffer the reversed curse of Windows / Star Trek. The even numbers are great, the odd numbers...not so much.And why? It's the characterisation. Penultimo is competent and not the snivelling cowardly sycophant he needs to be and there's a Juanita replacement called Lucy - who is just as annoying. While 4 had wonderful cariactures, 3 and 5 have "realistic" characters - who just don't suit the game. All across the game there are fingermarks of designers saying "But we should say this is bad" - which really hurt the immersion. For instance, you can choose to have an Atheist Constitution while wearing a Fedora. While this is relevant in the 21st Century, the idea of Atheism would be far more abhorrent to the Crown than simple Independence - especially if you then join the Nazis. A better option would be to have a choice between Catholicism, Animism (Witch Doctors) and Godhood (El Presidente is God himself) - same choice, far better game immersion.Is it better than 4? No.Tropico works best when it's lampooning reality - this feels like the FOX NEWS History Channel when it should always be the Muppets.Secondary views:Nope - this is plain awful. There's swathes of this game that are borderline offensive and it's removed everything that 4 took from 3. I can't recommend it in good faith. Just a badly written game.TL;DR: A cynical pitch into brofist territory with pretty graphics and multiplayer hiding a fundamentally broken game.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												What the Tropico series seems to understand better than some other strategy games is that quality trumps quantity when it comes to strategic options.Especially in the earlier eras, you will find fewer choices in Tropico 5 than in Tropico 4.  Early ages especially have few buildings in each type. Building management options is based on a budget (affects service quality and wage at the same time).  In general, specific numbers are replaced with broad categories (see budget).However, these are all good things.  Ultimately, entry fees, rents and wages were largely either trial and error, following a guide or broad categories anyways in Tropico 4.  Tropico 5 doesnt offer a lot of options all the time, but each is distinct in at least some ways, and not to be taken lightly (especially constitution principles, which are logically harder to change than small picture policies).Overall, the eras system gives the game good pacing, the new algorithim provides challenge to more experiences players, and Tropico's humor is still alive and well.  You could do a lot worse.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Before proceeding, let me tell you this, this will be long and I will try to point out why I didn't like Tropico 5 in detail, if you want the resumed version just check it in the end.To start it off, I didn't enjoy Tropico 5 like I did with Tropico 4, really, it is FAR worst than 4, the humor is way more childish, voice actors changed for your loyal Penultimo that sounds nothing like him and honestly makes him far more boring and, worst of all, the story is just... lame. It felt like it was written in a rush, making it simple with a more than disapointing ending.BUT the game isn't compleatly bad, the mechanic is far more challenging and the era things aswell as the multiplayer are both good, which makes the game enjoyable. Sadly the game doesn't explain many of its new concepts, making it confusing and really frustrating, you'll have to dedicate a good while just checking each screen the game has to fully understand how everything in it works.Tropico 5 also adds a limit to your total population, making your growth stop at a rather bad point, max 2000 people, you'll start to feel such effects of a limited population way before too, at around 900. Some structures feel useless too, such as the subway and the garage, both say they'll increase the efficiency of nearby houses, but they don't really change.Speaking of apparently useless structures, many buildings have an awful tooltip, lacking explanation for how it works. During my first plays I made factory ranches, an upgraded version of ranches and then suddenly it stopped producing. I searched, read the tooltip again and again, checked efficiency, everything seemed normal, only after a lot of frustration I checked the forums to find out it required a supply of corn.Some new concepts are also interesting, but really badly planned out, such as the manager for buildings and dynasty members. Both should help you improve your buildings and offer some sort of use, but they really feel useless, it is REALLY had to see a change in a building with managers. Your dynasty members are basicly that too, improved managers and frankly nothing else. You could also see your swiss bank account has a new use, improving your dynasty members, which isn't that hard and after a while you just say ♥♥♥♥ it to the swiss bank account.Speaking of dynasty members, you can customize them and your character, but frankly? Customization is just AWFUL compared to Tropico 4. Meager 4 or 5 suits which you won't EVER see as your characters are really, really small. Remember how you had to use your presidente for all sort of things? Boosting constructions, moving him to make speeches, help improve a building, you actualy cared for the character and tried to keep track of him. In Tropico 5 you make and forget about him, what is the point of following him if he won't do♥♥♥♥♥♥ You can't control him either.Lastly, upgrades are now boring, really boring. In Tropico 4 you could upgrade something and it would change visually, even if it was a small detail it was a change and it was fun! You could see you had improved that building! In Tropico 5 nothing changes, absolutly nothing, I forgot how many times I ♥♥♥♥ed up because I forgot to upgrade a building because I had NO idea what was and what was not upgraded at that point.Resuming: Tropico 5 is not Tropico 4, see it as a different, harder and way more rushed version of it, otherwise you won't get to enjoy it and YOU WILL be frustrated.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												I played Tropico 3 before, and this is a great improvement:The spirit is the same, but the graphics are better (you bet...) and the Eras are a nice addition. The radio shut up a little bit, but Penultimo is still funny. You get to create a dynasty so you can use several dynasty members around the island who give various bonuses to relationships, effectiveness, etc. Multiplayer has been added too. You have to gather research points too to unlock new buildings, constitution options, edicts, etc. All these additions make the game more fun to play.On the bad side, the limo is gone!! :'(Regarding campaign mode:The campaign mode is not boring, i.e. from one mission to the next you do completely different things. You play on a few different islands, but you will "reuse" these islands in coming missions which makes the missions more look like a sandbox game while you can get straight to the point of the mission more easily since you already know the island. It's really good to bend the learning curve a bit: just play campaign! If you're completely new to Tropico the tutorial goes through the very basics (at some point it explains what the pause/play/fast forward icons do when you click on them...!!)I still have to try multiplayer, that might extend the life of the game.Great game, get it while it's at -75%!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Penultimo and El Presidente are back.  I am really fond of this iteration of Tropico, and I find I'm playing it a lot more than any previous version.  While I've heard some complaints about the interface (especially for the build menu), I found it pretty easy to figure out and having used it for awhile, I find it better than the menu in previous versions with one caveat:  I wish that it didn't show buildings that you can't build because you haven't reached the proper age or haven't researched the proper technology.  It's annoying when I see a building I want to build, and I forget I can't build it until much later.  I'm also not too fond of the research mechanism, since I see no real reason to have research in Tropico.  It feels like it was just tacked on to add a little extra depth, but it doesn't really provide any at all.  All in all, if you're a fan of previous versions of Tropico, this is a must have.  If you like City Builders, this is also a must have.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Tropico has been one of my personal favorite city builders and management sims ever second only to sim city 3000. This tropico Rights the wrongs of the 4th game and takes some of the good things from 3 and fleshes them out even more. Redesigned art assets give the game a fresh look and the trimmed down amount of buildings and menu screens makes managing your island much easier and allows you to get what you want done faster and with less pointless busy work. I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves city builders and or simulation style games. Its not a easy game but its relaxed enough you can enjoy it while sitting down enjoying a rum and coke. Opressing the people of your tropical paradise. This game makes you thankfully forget that tropico 4 ever happend.

Posted: June 11, 2014
												I bought this game out of the gate face value expecting the wait for linux to be a week, maybe 2 at the most. This expectation was based on the fact that Kalypso announced their linux plans as early as Thu, 08/22/2013 - 21:08. So my thought process was, "Kalypso has had some time to get linux under wraps and the only issue they should have is the directX11 substitution." Well I was wrong and lost out on $40 bucks for the foreseeable future, eventually they should release a linux version so I am not at a complete loss. Although it might take as long as Bethesda getting Skyrim DLC to the PS3, almost a year and a half later, but I did get it. After plenty of Xbox/Microsoft ridicule. After hearing about all the other bug problems that Kalypso has been having, like Rebels on steroids and game crash issues I do not plan on investing the time and energy tweaking directX on wine and all kinds of other dll issues only to be faced with the PC communities own bugs, nor should I have to when I pay retail for a "complete" product. So until Kalypso gets its♥♥♥♥♥♥together I have to give this game a negative review, its only fair on the customers part.After the Bethesda Skyrim fiasco and now Kalypso's linux and mac issues I hope I do not see an ugly trend forming in videogame development. Hopefully steam will make the linux transfers to steam boxes gracefuly and in time for this holiday season, but as an already disappointed customer I am not getting my hopes up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												First off: the game is by far too easy, and far too short.The main campain took me ~20 hours, same as Tropico 4: Modern Times, whilst the main campain of Tropico 4 took me over 80 hours.The economy is Tropico 5 far easier than in the previous games, no challenge at all.Effectively there are no factions in Tropico 5, everyone is always happy.No crime, no rebels, safe for the few episodes where rebels were part of the plot.Even the military part, was too easy, with the aircraft carrier and the towers being overbuffed.The nice idea of guiding an island through a century was not as well polished as I hoped for.You can just hit "upgrade all" at the start of a new age, and you will see nothing of a historical city core.The idea of a dynasty was great, too, but how can one El Presidente live for 200 years?Why did one El Presidente guide two islands at once?On the cover there were two El Presidentes, which would have been more logical.The last major drawback was that this game was more serious than the previos games.The speakers were less funny, less random interaction.Even Penultimo sounded clinically depressed.The core ideas of the game are great. Having islands that follow you throughout the times is nice. Alas, the game was centered on "newbs", with too little challenge.Also I guess many features were cut to have many DLCs later on.The graphics are very nice, but that is in my opinion only a minor part in a city-building game.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Penultimo and El Presidente are back.  I am really fond of this iteration of Tropico, and I find I'm playing it a lot more than any previous version.  While I've heard some complaints about the interface (especially for the build menu), I found it pretty easy to figure out and having used it for awhile, I find it better than the menu in previous versions with one caveat:  I wish that it didn't show buildings that you can't build because you haven't reached the proper age or haven't researched the proper technology.  It's annoying when I see a building I want to build, and I forget I can't build it until much later.  I'm also not too fond of the research mechanism, since I see no real reason to have research in Tropico.  It feels like it was just tacked on to add a little extra depth, but it doesn't really provide any at all.  All in all, if you're a fan of previous versions of Tropico, this is a must have.  If you like City Builders, this is also a must have.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												Would I recommend this game?  I want to.  But I can't, not right now...For one, the game requires a videocard that supports DirectX 11, (updating your drivers won't make a difference) which was not a problem for me since my desktop is fairly beefed up, however, running the game on my laptop or an older desktop is absolutely out of the question.  What's more, I didn't notice anything indicating the game would not run without DX11, and numerous people have apparently bought the game only to find out that it's unplayable.With that out of the way, a few other issues...The game has a seemingly steep learning curve- you'll have the basics figured out without much effort, and then BAM!  You find yourself in one no-win scenario after another.  After restarting campaigns a few times and even playing around in Sandbox mode, I realized the gameplay is actually just wonky sometimes.The game also reduces all the micromanagement I loved about Tropico 4.  You can't see who's visiting your buildings or other minutia that used to aid in figuring out how to resolve issues with your island.  Everything is sort of streamlined (or tries to be) which actually to me seemed a little too dumbed down.The dynasty system is a novel idea but nothing to get excited about.The variety of buildings comes drastically short.  I want to believe that that the reason for this is because, I don't know, the game was rushed.  However, I have this odd feeling it was intentional and a few months down the road we'll be seeing DLC with more buildings.  And then more DLC.  And so on and so forth. To be blunt, everything about the character customization sucks, and the rendering of the characters themselves is absolutely butt ugly.Drop down the price, fix some gameplay issues, add content, and I would definitely recommend.  Right now I feel like the game is an unfinished product.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												It's Tropico 4, but stripped down and with a new coat of paint. The progression throughout four ages, from collonial to modern, and the added dynasty of presidentes unfortunately strips away a lot of the charm and quiantness that was present in previous games. Instead of a single presidente lording it over his tiny banana republic trying to win Smelliest Cheese Competitions for the glory of Tropico, you now shepherd an island nation from humble beginnings to metropolis. Like the Modern Times expansion of Tropico 4, it's jarring and strange to see towering glass and metal skyscrapers next to your Cold War era pubs and houses. It makes the island look less cohesive and much less functional, since lots of towers constantly block your view no matter how you turn the camera. It's fun and challenging enough in its own right, but the goofy small island charm that made the series unique is diminished by it. It also seems to have taken a peek at other city builders and grabbed some elements here and there. From the Anno series, it takes the concept of trade routes and implements it quite superflouesly, to the point where you have to wonder why the feature is even there at all. From the Civ series it takes the tech tree, which is really just an artificial barrier that stops you from building the more advanced buildings straight away. If you want that cigar factory, be prepared to work for it.That's not to say this game isn't enjoyable. The unique sense of humor is still there, the campaign is suitably unpredictable and silly, the mechanics work (as do your builders, for the first time in Tropico history) and some of the new elements like the constitution are interesting and well-implemented. All in all it feels like a bare-bones game, with lots of room for DLC, but what's there works very well. If you enjoyed the previous Tropico games, you're most likely going to enjoy this one as well. If this is your first Tropico game, prepare to do some research into what certain buildings actually do, but once you've gotten past that hurdle, this is as good a place as any to dive in.(Note: these are my experiences from single player campaign. It's early days still, so the online component is predictably wonky. Sandbox mode does not have many options. There is no island editor for sandbox.)

												For fans of the series I think it's a logical chocie to get Tropico 5. I think it's quite decent step forward over Tropico 4, I found it to be more long term fun (as well as harder) then the previous one; the era system and other improvments such as the constitution suit well for Tropico 5.However on the downside in some areas Tropico 5 was stripped down, much less customization for your members; some options are also gone MIA, for example "work modes" are gone for the most part, many buildings were removed while often for the the better, experts will miss buildings like the Immigration Office or Prisons for more fine grained political control.Political backgrouds are also removed in favor of the new dynasty system, though this is actually a decent change.At the time of release, the multiplayer also has some issues such as hangs/crashes, no adjustable speed and no options to create a save game, but hopefully those will be amended in the the future.But it is also a new and fun experience to play Tropico 5 in multiplayer, though at this point it is still rather problematic to play and the dipomacy options are limited, but since it's a first for tropico, one can hope for fixes and adjustments by the developers.Despite all those flaws, Tropico 5 still provides a nice boost to fun and difficulty, it provides much of a challange to create a working island state, rebels, military revolts and uprisings are an actual threat now, and pleasing all factions can be diffcult. The eras require you to adjust your economy as well as profitable goods will change thoughout the eras.4/5

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												(The following review is mostly based on campaign/single player gameplay; I've yet to try the multiplayer portion)I find that the opening menu of Tropico 5 sums it up perfectly. The amazing Caribbean soundtrack causes immediate deja vu for fans of the series, to the point where I thought they had recycled the same song from the previous games, yet something about the song feels better, cleaner, more refined. That's Tropico 5. Familiar ground that, on the surface, looks unsettlingly similar to previous entries, yet hides the game that Tropico 3 and 4 should have been all along.I get the feeling that the majority of Tropico 5's target audience consists of people who enjoyed one or more of the previous four games. But, for the uninitiated, Tropico is one of the extremely scarce non-independant developed city building (aka management or simulation) games of the past decade. It centers around the idea of players taking the role as "El Presidente" of a Caribbean island, and building a small tropical society through agriculture, trade, tourism, and light-hearted political corruption. The first Tropico game was released in 2001 along with a sequel in 2003 and, though Tropico 2 was a major departure in theme from the rest of the series (a rather wonderful... piratey departure), both games gained something of a cult following. In 2009, Tropico 3 was released by a different developer and publisher as a 3D game, but by then most major city development games had vanished. The fact that Tropico survived was a pleasant surprise for fans such as myself. Though some would argue that the game lost a bit of its greatness in the transition, it stood on its own as a solid city builder in spite of its flaws. Two years and expansion pack later, Tropico 4 was released, and... it was Tropico 3. Though by no means bad, you had to dig quite deep to find additions that made it feel like a worthy sequel and not a copy. An overabundance of small DLC packs made it difficult for even the most diehard of fans to not feel cheated.With that mindset, skeptical eyes turn to Tropico 5 and, if many of the reviews out there are to be believed, the knee-jerk reaction to this game is that it is yet another iteration of the same formula. However, I feel that these reviews are overlooking how the small changes make an all-around better gaming experience. So what's changed?The most drastic change to the Tropico formula is the "era" and research system. Previously, Tropico focused primarily on the Cold War era, not-so-subtley hinting at the time and rule of Fidel Castro (he was even playable in earlier games), and only in the expansion pack for the fourth game did they try to shift the focus to 21st century society. Instead, the game now starts with Tropico as a 19th century royal colony, and El Presidente starts as a governer for the crown. Over time, you unlock new technologies, fight for your own independance, and establish new laws and decisions while new factions and global concerns crop up with each new era. Mechanically, this works brilliantly and fights off the biggest problems Tropico had with monotony over longer games. In addition to giving a perfect framework for Tropico's whimsical storytelling (more on that later), it adds a much needed sense of advancement to your society and promotes the use of strategies that would have been ignored in earlier games (such as how to deal with housing when you only have access to tiny houses and overpriced mansions). It all builds up to a much more refined modern era, complete with new industries like electronics and car production, as well as jabs at modern day political issues, which still fit perfectly into a banana republic setting.Another change is a more refined economic system across the board. For me, this is Tropico 5's selling point. You can tell a lot of thought went into how the pieces of the game work together. Though Tropico is still a "butterfly effect" kind of game where the desires, opinions, and actions of every single AI driven person on the island effect the way things work, the chaos is controlled where it needs to be. For example, I haven't run into a situation where a ship misses a shipment because all the dockworkers were off at the tavern (a frustration in previous games). All buildings now also have an "effectiveness" rating, which acts as an easily understood percentage of how well a building does what it's supposed to do (a plantation with 100 effectiveness produces 100% of its crops, maximizing its budget gives +20 efficiency, whereas missing part of the workforce drastically lowers it). All buildings also fit together in a cleaner way than they did before (many are smaller), and things like the placement of a plantation's crop field is infinitely easier to work with. There are also two brand new features that make the economy more controllable, one being the addition of "managers" who are people with specific skills that you can assign to have special effects on individual buildings, and the other being a revamped trading system where, in addition to the traditional system of trade ships showing up at your docks and buying all your excess products, you can sign deals with foreign powers and send your own ships to them to get better deals on your goods, which both encourages specialization in your city and adds an extra twist to global politics.The last, but least exciting addition is the idea of El Presidente's dynasty. In previous games, you had much greater control over the personality of your ruler, as well as his strengths and weaknesses. Instead, this concept is stretched out over multiple members of one ruling family who bundles their bonuses together. You gain new family members and increase their ranks through stashed away "Swiss Bank Account" money that you earn while playing (an interesting way to use the stolen money concept from previous games). Only one member of your family can be El Presidente at any given time, but the others can be deployed as managers in your city, or used in certain storyline-based events. It's an interesting system and it works well enough, but I can't help but think it didn't turn out quite the way it was supposed to. Ultimately, it ends up feeling less like a system of family and lineage, and more like a team of immortal El Presidentes for you to accumulate for their individual bonus effects. Fortunately, nothing about this system gets in the way of the game from anything other than an immersion standpoint.((NOTE! - I cut out a portion of this review so it would fit on Steam's review system. My apologies for being so long-winded! This portion of the review can be read here http://steamcommunity.com/app/245620/discussions/0/540742667604319054/ ))Overall, Tropico 5 is a very pleasant surprise. It's similar enough to earn criticism from some, but for those who felt the formula was strong and just needed some refining, the refinements are well worthy of a new game. It does fall short of perfect for some of the same reasons that previous Tropico games have, such as the lack of good explanations of some of the game's deeper concepts, its refusal to open the game up to any kind of modding, as well as clear signs that they plan to do a lackluster and exploitative DLC system similar to Tropico 4. But, for me, slipping into El Presidente's shoes may just feel better than it ever did before.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Well, take a real good look at this Maxxis. Look long and hard, because this is exactly the sort of game SimCity should have been.Tropico is a heap of fun. It has learning curve that is steep enough to keep you engaged, whilst not being so steep as to deter players or make them feel overwhelmed. Once you have learned all of the little tricks it's then that you beging to experience some of the emergent gameplay on offer. Want to rule as an iron fisted dictator that suppresses his population? Go ahead. Want to be a benevolent president who opens the country to free and fair elections? You can do that. Want to run a communist or capatalist state? The choice is yours. Some of the most interesting choice come through how to structure your economy, and how to run the social aspects of your island nation, and each of these decisions has an impact on your nation's relationship with the wider world. Trade will be impacted with each decision, as will your security.There's so much do do in Tropico 5. While the Tropico games have alsways been fun, Tropico 5 adds a tonne of options without sacrificing the core gameplay of the previous installments in the series. In that way it feels like both a great leap forward for the series while being comfortable for fans.But, above all, Tropico manages to do what SimCity couldn't - it's fun and it's functional. There appear to be no game-breaking bugs, and the whole experienced is polished and extremely smooth. While Tropico 5 might not be perfect, it comes pretty danmed close for those looking for a fun, funny and challenging city builder.Highly recommended.

												Would I recommend this game?  I want to.  But I can't, not right now...For one, the game requires a videocard that supports DirectX 11, (updating your drivers won't make a difference) which was not a problem for me since my desktop is fairly beefed up, however, running the game on my laptop or an older desktop is absolutely out of the question.  What's more, I didn't notice anything indicating the game would not run without DX11, and numerous people have apparently bought the game only to find out that it's unplayable.With that out of the way, a few other issues...The game has a seemingly steep learning curve- you'll have the basics figured out without much effort, and then BAM!  You find yourself in one no-win scenario after another.  After restarting campaigns a few times and even playing around in Sandbox mode, I realized the gameplay is actually just wonky sometimes.The game also reduces all the micromanagement I loved about Tropico 4.  You can't see who's visiting your buildings or other minutia that used to aid in figuring out how to resolve issues with your island.  Everything is sort of streamlined (or tries to be) which actually to me seemed a little too dumbed down.The dynasty system is a novel idea but nothing to get excited about.The variety of buildings comes drastically short.  I want to believe that that the reason for this is because, I don't know, the game was rushed.  However, I have this odd feeling it was intentional and a few months down the road we'll be seeing DLC with more buildings.  And then more DLC.  And so on and so forth. To be blunt, everything about the character customization sucks, and the rendering of the characters themselves is absolutely butt ugly.Drop down the price, fix some gameplay issues, add content, and I would definitely recommend.  Right now I feel like the game is an unfinished product.

												Awesome changes in Tropico 4 makes the game interesting throughout the whole playthrough instead of walking away from the computer for 5 minutes during late-game economy. I have only played the game for a few hours but here are some of the changes I have seen so far: - Even more emphasis on diplomacy and trade routes to be able to advance in the game. - Building's efficiency can be changed by hiring a manager, upgrade technology, and placement of the building. - Early-game housing provides their own food so that players can focus on creating an economic foundation. - Inclusion of research for new technology and buildings to be available. - Military types and strength dependent on education, technology, and buildings. - Ability to restrict population from eating food resources from a specific farm. - Exploration of the island needed to expand your empire.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												The Tropico series never fails to deliver on a fantastic City Building game, providing a style of gameplay which is easy to learn and difficult to Master which has become the core of the series. The game is divided into Eras that break up the game never allowing you to get bored or comfortable. Unlike other games in the same genre Tropico 5 also has an intresting Trade and Military functions as well as a political system that means your Island is more than a collection of buildings, following your own ideologies you can create your own socalist paradise or your own captalist utopia, a totaltarian police state or a liberal democracy and while in this persuit you have to tread carefully not to upset too many people with your Grand Ideas or else face a rebellion from the unwashed masses who cannot see your obvious genius, of course thats what tanks are for. The challenge of juggling the powers of the Tropican world will either cement your rule as absolute ruler of your own paradise island, your have you on a row boat far out in the sea being waved off by an upstart new Presidente who hardly knows what he's gotten himself into. Tropico 5 builds on the positives of past Tropico games, and delivers so much more, and anyone new to the series should check this out as it promises to provide hours of frustrating, fun, and rewarding gameplay.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												What I did not like:That number of free family homes are not shown.The creation of a dictator is well, plain horrid, bad graphics, 10 000 names to choose from but very little choices otherwise. What happened to more advance personality characteristics? The fog of war. How nearsighted are these people? Or how lazy? When building should be able to push the fog back a little at the time.What I miss:More advance banking.Not that it is a bad thing, but what happened to crime and jails? I simply loved the labour camps that made the criminals in to nice, proper farmers instead.Some more entertainment choices: Bread and circus people, bread and circus. Or perhaps Rum and can can girls.  Ministry could have been nice if you could make your family ministers.Sadly enough, I miss our dear Reverend Esteban that has exchanged communion wine with rum and the church with the pub. Palace updates.Penultimo and Sunny Flowers “radio show”. (Penultimo actually seems smarter and more honest.)That El president can give speeches from the palace.Ability to go down to street level and “walk” in your wonderful little town. What I miss in every single game in the series. The chance to place your palace and first dock by own choice. Set salary in a building to make sure it has labour.  What I liked.Its now shown what level of jobs are free and what education level the unemployed has.The police station double as fire station and they actually seem to be able to get where they are supposed to. Finally both gender can work the same places all over. I hated it in Tropic 4 when you lacked labour because those on that education level was of the wrong gender and those of the wrong gender went without a job. It always seemed to be more jobs for men than for women... Those lovely little country houses that has their own food production. That the buildings no longer look the same no matter what version your playing.Power-plant less big and ugly.It seems that a building dos not stop working because there is to much products piling up. (A big, BIG problem in Tropico 4, modern times).Seems like distribution of raw material works a a lot better. Also show what products are in the docks.What I simply loved.Updates can be done from any building and you can choose if you want to upgrade one building or all of them. No need to wait for Penultimo to give you the choice.The grid, I love the grid.That the buildings nicely fit in to the grid. Yes I suffer from “Prussian disease” but I love my nice, orderly streets and buildings.No more big, ugly parking-houses that gets overloaded after five minutes.  That the plantations and Ranch's show how much space they will use. All about the grid and the orderly banana republic.   That the plantation fields are not fixed in case one need a little guard tower. Again: those lovely little country houses with their own food production.Did I mention those lovely little country houses?That subway station don't become more and more expensive. The mines, those lovely new mines you can't build over by accident.The natural disaster edict, I LOVE the natural disaster edict.  There are a lot of great improvements, even if spooky with the immortal El presidente. A vampire in Tropico? Perhaps that's why you no longer can send  El presidente out to construction sites and production sites. (There is a lot of sun in the Caribbean). Not every one can keep it going as long as Fidel Castro. Would be nice if could choose successor from the family. Europa 1400 - The Guild would let you choose your heir when you died.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												I first began playing Tropico 4 last year and was impressed with the extensive campaign and dlc missions.  As many other reviewers have already mentioned, Tropico 4 was also full of humurous subplots and crazy characters.  Compared to its predecessor, Tropico 5 does not overwhelm you with tons of buildings, nor does it force you to repeatedly rebuild your island kingdom every mission.  On the other hand, the humor seems more subdued in this version, while the soundtrack (although a little more varied than Tropico 4) is still a little too repetitive for my taste. Overall, there is much to commend about Tropico 5.  The graphics are quite beautiful, the era progression system adds variety to the game, and there is enough crazy story in the missions to get you laughing (and keep playing).  Veteran dictators may find issues with certain details of Tropico 5 (e.g. the awkward AI combat system and the generic voice acting), but players looking for a fun and addictive city building game will be quite pleased with Tropico 5.

												Tropico 5 is...different. I am not saying it is bad, quite opposite it is a very enjoyable, relaxing and strategic game. What I mean by different is that they took the Tropico game and remade it all over again.The mines, farms, style, everything has changed. I was expecting something very similar to Tropico 3 and 4, but boy did I get a surprise. A very good one at that! It could almost be said this game is a spinoff...almost. I stromgly recommend this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												I have been a big fan of city building / resource management style games since I first picked up Caesar II. However, I've never picked up a Tropico title until now and I am blown away by the wonderful game play and quirky humor found within. Gameplay:Players familiar with Sim-City style city building will be immediately comfortable with the Tropico layout. Similar concepts like connecting buildings via roads and strategic placement of buildings with resources are all present. Managing the economy is fairly straightforward although it took a few games to catch on to how the trade contracts enabled through docks affected the overall economy. Combat is thankfully mostly automated so it doesn't distract too much from city building and management and adds a slightly more dynamic negative event in addition to the random acts of God. The progression of a game through the ages and how the form of government evolves the criteria for success was a new concept for me and very enjoyable.SoundThe sounds and music of the game pulls you into the tropical islander themed mood and is more than sufficient to emerse the player in the era of game play. Very well done.ReplayabilityAs with any game of this type, most players will run through a few guided campaign maps to familiarize themselves with the gameplay and then jump into true sandboxes. Thankfully a random map creation mode is readily available to churn out endless scenarios built to your liking. This makes replayability an easy checkbox to check.OverallLosing in Tropico 5 doesn't feel so bad. It seems the game can churn out any number of hilarious scenarios under which you will get booted from power. Accidentally import too much and go into deep debt? Oops...you got voted out and no your cheating didn't help enough. Didn't plan out your initial governorship very well? Man those 4 years flew by fast. This game will pull you in and hours will fly by.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												This game is much different from Tropico 1 and 4, with that so far it has its merits and a few things that I am missing from the series.Some of the changes:Much less banter like in 4, I really enjoyed some of the voice over work, made me laugh quite a bit.You play as your own character, I really enjoyed playing as past dictators in 1 and 4, unless I am missing something.Buildings unlock in 5 as you progress, in 4 you could place anything you could afford.  4 was a much more build oriented game with a nice story arch, there may still be a story arch in 5, but it is more multiplayer game than solo.Solo scenarios go very, very fast to begin, I am sure those extend quite a bit as you move farther into the game.I actually like the graphics of the building much better in 4.I preferred the direct quotes on the save pages in 4 vs. the dictator "fun facts" on the save pages in 5...I know nit picking :)Some of the things I do really enjoy so far with 5:The whole trade system is a huge improvement, its fun to direct and agree where your goods go.There are pirates, I like pirates.Using exploration to discover portions of your islands make a lot of sense, but so far no natives have killed my tiny explorers...I would kind of think they risk getting boiled in a pot, but maybe I have just been lucky so far.It does feel like I have to work harder to get my approval rating up and I have fewer choices to do so, especially early, I do like the challenge, but think more early choices would help the game.New music...and yes I know that's the Squirrel Nut Zippers on at least one song.I like that the building upgrades need to be researched and can't just be upgraded in 3 clicks like in 4, you have to work for those a bit more, not simply rake in money.So far, Tropico 5 does feel like a pretty big departure from 4.  I have seen 4 described as a fun city builder game with good challenges.  5 feels like it is going to be much more unpredictable and interactive as long as you get a good group of people you know to play along.My final recommendation on this is, grab Tropico 4, a great bargain now and a ton of fun.  I think Tropico 5 will continue to build on the series and this feels like the base of a new, evolving game.  5 is going to provide a lot of gaming enjoyment, but I think it needs more time to develop.  My biggest fear in buying the game was that it would be going online like Sim City 5 and have an EA-style launch disaster...it hasn't and so far as long as you have an up to date video card, Direct X 11 and a fast, newer machine, the game has not hit very few snags.  It is a good, positive launch, hopefully with much more to come.Check that a bit as there have been multiplayer server issues over the first weekend....we may have a collapse coming....lol.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This is the first version of Tropico that I've bought. I'll keep buying future versions.The story and mechanics of the game are really funny. I won't go into details since that could spoil things a bit.Haven't tried the multiplayer game type yet but I am so happy with the campaigns and sandbox games!Now for the negative things, please keep in mind that i really like the game and will, no questions ask, buy any future version.- Overlays are kind of random and hard to access- It is quite hard to figure out how to deal with things, e.g. the various types of happiness- Not using wasd-keys for navigation is surprisingly uncomfortable- The difficulty settings make things more difficult, but not by muchThe game was a bit buggy to begin with, but I feel it is OK now (I experience no bugs at this time as far as I know).Overall this is a very nice game that have kept me up far to late many times already :)

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												So far so good. It's similar enough to Trop4 to be familiar yet the dynamics are different enough to make it interesting. Would like to see more buildings but I suspect they'll come in future DLC. I like that the technology tree replaced blueprints which I found more annoying.One thing: I couldn't open my almanac while a dialog was open -- in Trop4 this made it possible to choose wisely if your options included lowering your status with a faction or foreign country. Now I had to try and remember whether I could afford to lose 10 respect with the Allies.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Just getting into the game but I can already see it is vastly more complex in every area than Tropico 4. The first Tropico game I thoroughly enjoyed was Tropico 4, but couldn't get into the earlier versions because they simply didn't seem quite as fun to me. This game seeks to expand on everything they did right with Tropico 4 and go further, more in depth, and add Multiplayer on top of it. If you liked/loved Tropico 4 you'll definitely want to pick this up. MAKE SURE YOU GO THROUGH THE TUTORIAL before making any decision as to whether or not you think it's a vast improvement over previous Tropico's. Most of the Negatives were I'm missing this, or this certain menu isn't there anymore, etc. IT'S ALL THERE FOLKS, just have to know where to go. I will say the Interface is a bit clunky, but once you get used to it you're off and running. :-)
